Fresno fared much better, due to an unseasonably wet December through February, but the rains ended abruptly in late February and the season ended with 8.40 inches. This was 74.8 % of Fresnos normal of 11.23 inches.||Wildfire 41, CalFire, Merced-Madera-Mariposa Unit, ignited on June 11 due to unknown causes. The location was Highway 41 at Highway 145, approx. 15 miles east-northeast of Madera in Madera County. The size was 15,262 acres. No fatalities or lost structures. The cost to contain the fire was $6,500,000.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Humboldt Fire injured 8 firefighters, destroyed 74 homes, and damaged 20 other buildings. The fire burned 23162 acres in an area located between Chico and Paradise before being contained on June 16th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Wildfires in Butte, Shasta, and Tehama counties spread quickly due to gusty winds, low humidity, and dry fuels.

CZ_NAME_STR: MOUNTAINS SOUTHWEST SHASTA COUNTY TO NORTHERN LAKE COUNTY (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Whiskey Fire damaged 7783 acres in southwest Shasta and northwest Tehama counties. The fire was contained on June 21st.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Wildfires in Butte, Shasta, and Tehama counties spread quickly due to gusty winds, low humidity, and dry fuels.

Numerous thunderstorms with little or no rain spread across the area late in the evening on June 20th. Approximately 1000 lightning strikes were detected that started numerous wildfires across northwestern California.

Numerous thunderstorms with little or no rain spread across the area late in the evening on June 20th. Approximately 1000 lightning strikes were detected that started numerous wildfires across northwestern California.

Numerous thunderstorms with little or no rain spread across the area late in the evening on June 20th. Approximately 1000 lightning strikes were detected that started numerous wildfires across northwestern California.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: This fire started in a lightning outbreak on 06/21/08.  This was the largest and longest lasting fire in Siskiyou County.  As of 0430 PDT on 07/01/08, this fire was 7988 acres in size and 3.98 million dollars had been spent in firefighting efforts.  The estimated containment date was 08/15/08.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lightning from a thunderstorm event on 06/21/08 ignited numerous fires across northern California.  Most of these were extinguished but one major fire in Siskiyou County was still active at the end of the month:  the Siskiyou Complex.  As of 0430 PDT on 07/01/08, this fire was 7988 acres in size and 23% contained with an estimated containment date of 08/15/08.  3.98 million had been expended in fire fighting efforts.

CZ_NAME_STR: MOUNTAINS SOUTHWEST SHASTA COUNTY TO NORTHERN LAKE COUNTY (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning on June 21st started a number of fires in western Tehama and southwestern Shasta counties. Several of these fires were combined as the SHU Complex which included the Whiskeytown Complex. By the end of June, 52,000 acres were burned with 6 firefighter injuries, 3 residences destroyed, and 2 additional buildings damaged. There were also 230 residences and 37 commercial buildings threatened. The fires in the complex extended into the northern Sacramento Valley (CA-Z015) and into the vicinity of Lake Shasta (CA-Z013). The fires had only 15 percent containment at the end of the month and are continued in the July Storm Data entry.  In addition, the Yolla Bolly Complex covered 3900 acres but with no injuries or threatened structures.  These fires had only 5 percent containment at the end of the month and are also continued in the July Storm Data entry.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms with little or no rainfall spread across interior Northern California on June 21st. Approximately 8000 lightning strikes were detected, sparking as many as 2000 wildfires across Northern California. These fires destroyed numerous structures and caused multiple deaths and injuries. Evacuations were ordered for affected communities. Smoke from the wildfires caused respiratory problems across the region. Due to a lack of resources, many fires were not initially attacked with fire crews and some fires were expected to continue to burn for the remainder of the fire season.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two fire complexes were initiated by lightning on June 21st. The Canyon Complex fires covered 12,922 acres and threatened 53 structures, but there were no injuries or destroyed structures.  The fires had only 5 percent containment by the end of the month and are continued in the July Storm Data entry.  The Cub Complex fires covered 3622 acres and had no injuries or threatened structures.  They were 15 percent contained by the end of the month and are continued in the July Storm Data entry.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms with little or no rainfall spread across interior Northern California on June 21st. Approximately 8000 lightning strikes were detected, sparking as many as 2000 wildfires across Northern California. These fires destroyed numerous structures and caused multiple deaths and injuries. Evacuations were ordered for affected communities. Smoke from the wildfires caused respiratory problems across the region. Due to a lack of resources, many fires were not initially attacked with fire crews and some fires were expected to continue to burn for the remainder of the fire season.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Butte Lightning Complex (BTU) consisted of 34 fires ignited by lightning strikes on June 21st and spread over 16,000 acres, extending into the central Sacramento Valley (CA-Z016). There were 6 minor injuries to firefighters reported, 2 structures destroyed, and 1200 residences threatened. Multiple evacuations and road closures were ordered.  The fires had only 25 percent containment by the end of the month and are continued in the July Storm Data entry.

Evacuations were ordered for affected communities. Smoke from the wildfires caused respiratory problems across the region. Due to a lack of resources, many fires were not initially attacked with fire crews and some fires were expected to continue to burn for the remainder of the fire season.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning strikes resulted in the development of the American River Fire Complex (located 11 miles northeast of Foresthill) and the Yuba River Complex (located 15 miles northeast of Grass Valley). Combined, the fires burned 7,142 acres, injured 12 firefighters, destroyed 1 residence, and threatened 116 additional structures. The fires had only 35 percent containment by the end of the month and are continued in the July Storm Data entry.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Butte Lightning Complex (BTU) consisted of 34 fires ignited by lightning strikes on June 21st spread over 16,000 acres. There were 6 minor injuries to firefighters reported (see CA-Z066 entry), 2 structures destroyed, and 1200 residences threatened. Multiple evacuations and road closures were ordered. The fires extended into the northeast foothills of the Sierra Nevada (CA-Z066), where most of the fires and injuries were located.  The fires had only 25 percent containment by the end of the month and are continued in the July Storm Data entry.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning from a thunderstorm event on 06/21/08 ignited numerous fires across northern California. The Bear Wallow Complex consists of two fires: Anthony Milne and Caribou. They started this day around 4:00 PM, but no resources were directed to the fire until July. It was still burning at the end of July. As of 0430 PDT on 08/01/08, this fire was 10376 acres in size and 14% contained with an estimated containment date of 08/15/08. 4.1 million had been expended in fire fighting efforts.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lightning from a thunderstorm event on 06/21/08 ignited numerous fires across northern California.  The Bear Wallow Complex consists of two fires:  Anthony Milne and Caribou.  They started this day around 4:00 PM, but no resources were directed to the fire until July. It was still burning at the end of July.  As of 0430 PDT on 08/01/08, this fire was 10376 acres in size and 14% contained with an estimated containment date of 08/15/08. 4.1 million had been expended in fire fighting efforts.

The Piute wildfire, in the Sequoia National Forest, was ignited on June 28 at 1359 PST by unknown causes. The location was 8 miles North of Twin Oaks in Kern County. The size was 37,026 acres. The fire was contained on July 25. There were no fatalities. 51 structures were lost to the wildfire, 45 of those being outbuildings. Damages were estimated at $5M. The cost to containment was $25M.

CZ_NAME_STR: MOUNTAINS SOUTHWEST SHASTA COUNTY TO NORTHERN LAKE COUNTY (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The SHU Fire Complex in southwestern Shasta and western Tehama counties burned approximately 87,000 acres before 100 percent containment was achieved on July 28th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with little or no rain spread across the area on June 21st. About 8000 lighting strikes were detected, sparking approximately 2000 wildfires across northern California. These fires destroyed numerous structures and caused multiple deaths and injuries. Evacuations were ordered for affected communities. Smoke from the wildfires caused respiratory concerns across the region. Due to the shear number of fires initiated and early season lower resource levels, many fires were not initially staffed. Many of these fires continued to burn through July and into August.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Canyon Complex was located west of Quincy and included 55 lighting initiated fires that burned a total of 37,753 acres. One residence and two outbuildings were destroyed. Two firefighter injuries were reported. The fires were 90 percent contained by the end of the month.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with little or no rain spread across the area on June 21st. About 8000 lighting strikes were detected, sparking approximately 2000 wildfires across northern California. These fires destroyed numerous structures and caused multiple deaths and injuries. Evacuations were ordered for affected communities. Smoke from the wildfires caused respiratory concerns across the region. Due to the shear number of fires initiated and early season lower resource levels, many fires were not initially staffed. Many of these fires continued to burn through July and into August.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Butte (BTU) Lightning Complex consisted of 41 fires initiated by lightning on June 21st and spread over 59,440 acres. There were 106 residences and eleven outbuildings destroyed. One civilian death and 65 injuries were reported this month in addition to six injuries in June. These are reported in the CA-Z066 entry. Multiple evacuations and road closures were ordered. The fires extended into the Northern Sacramento Valley (CA-Z015) and the Northeast Foothills/Sacramento Valley (CA-Z066) and were not contained until July 31st.

Due to the shear number of fires initiated and early season lower resource levels, many fires were not initially staffed. Many of these fires continued to burn through July and into August.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Butte (BTU) Lightning Complex Fire consisted of 41 fires initiated by lightning on June 21st and spread over 59,440 acres. There were 106 residences and 11 outbuildings destroyed. One civilian death was reported and 65 injuries this month in addition to the six injured in June. These are listed in the CA-Z066 report. Multiple evacuations and road closures were ordered. The fires extended into the Central Sacramento Valley (CA-Z016) and the Northeast Foothills/Sacramento Valley (CA-Z066) and were not contained until July 31st.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with little or no rain spread across the area on June 21st. About 8000 lighting strikes were detected, sparking approximately 2000 wildfires across northern California. These fires destroyed numerous structures and caused multiple deaths and injuries. Evacuations were ordered for affected communities. Smoke from the wildfires caused respiratory concerns across the region. Due to the shear number of fires initiated and early season lower resource levels, many fires were not initially staffed. Many of these fires continued to burn through July and into August.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Butte (BTU) Lightning Complex consisted of 41 fires initiated by lightning on June 21st and spread over 59,440 acres. One civilian death was reported in Concow on July 11th. There were 65 injuries this month (mainly firefighters) in addition to the six injured in June. There were 106 residences and 11 outbuildings destroyed. Multiple evacuations and road closures were ordered. The fires extended into the Northern Sacramento Valley (CA-Z015) and the Central Sacramento Valley (CA-Z016) and were not contained until July 31st.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The American River Fire Complex consisted of ten fires which were located about 11 miles to the northeast of Foresthill. There was a total of 20,541 acres destroyed from late June through July. There were two residences destroyed. One firefighter injury was reported. A helicopter was damaged while delivering protective building wrap, but there were no injuries. The fire was reported 100 percent contained on July 30th.

Due to the shear number of fires initiated and early season lower resource levels, many fires were not initially staffed. Many of these fires continued to burn through July and into August.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The SHU Fire Complex in southwestern Shasta and western Tehama counties burned approximately 87,000 acres before 100 percent containment was achieved on July 28th.

The Silver Complex wildfire occurred in the Sierra National Forest. The ignition date was June 21 at 1610 PST. The cause was lightning, and the location was from Fishcamp north to the Merced River Canyon. The size was 1,161 acres. The wildfire was contained on July 3. There were no fatalities or damages. The cost to containment was $3,340,000.

The Clover wildfire was located in the Sequoia National Forest. The ignition date was May 28 at 1300 PST. The cause was lightning. The wildfire was located 8 miles North of Kennedy Meadows in Tulare County. The size was 15,300 acres. The fire was contained on July 20. There were no fatalities or damaged properties. The cost to containment was $8.31M.

The Oliver wildfire was on state forest land, by the Merced-Madera-Mariposa Unit. The location was north of Ponderosa Basin and the size was 2789 acres. The ignition date was June 21 at 1610 PST. The cause was lightning. The wildfire was contained on July 5. There were no fatalities or damaged properties. The cost to containment was $12,217,857.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning from a thunderstorm event on 06/20/08 ignited numerous fires across northern California.  The Blue 2 Wildfire started this day around 8:00 PM, but no resources were directed to the fire until July. It was still burning at the end of July.  As of 0430 PDT on 08/01/08, this fire was 6459 acres in size and 30% contained with an estimated containment date of 08/30/08. 6.8 million had been expended in fire fighting efforts.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lightning from a thunderstorm event on 06/20/08 ignited numerous fires across northern California.  The Blue 2 Wildfire started this day around 8:00 PM, but no resources were directed to the fire until July. It was still burning at the end of July.  As of 0430 PDT on 08/01/08, this fire was 6459 acres in size and 30% contained with an estimated containment date of 08/30/08. 6.8 million had been expended in fire fighting efforts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning from a thunderstorm event on 06/21/08 ignited numerous fires across northern California.  The Siskiyou Complex was still burning at the end of July.  As of 0430 PDT on 08/01/08, this fire was 58456 acres in size and 46% contained with an estimated containment date of 08/30/08. 25.4 million had been expended in fire fighting efforts.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lightning from a thunderstorm event on 06/21/08 ignited numerous fires across northern California.  The Siskiyou Complex was still burning at the end of July.  As of 0430 PDT on 08/01/08, this fire was 58456 acres in size and 46% contained with an estimated containment date of 08/30/08. 25.4 million had been expended in fire fighting efforts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Gap Wildire burned 9,443 acres of land in the Los Padres National Forest. The fire was located in the Santa Ynez Mountains north of the community of Goleta. Numerous evacuations were ordered as many neighborhoods in the foothills were very close to the fire. Property damage was limited to four outbuildings and one recreational vehicle. Only several minor injuries to firefighters were reported. The total cost of the fire including suppression and property damage was approximately $21 million.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the month of July, the Gap Wildfire charred 9,443 acres of forest in the Los Padres National Forest. The fire was located in the Santa Ynez Mountains north of the community of Goleta. Numerous small neighborhoods in the canyons were forced to evacuate due to the proximity to the fire. The only significant damages reported were four outbuildings and one recreational vehicle. Only minor firefighter injuries were reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Ridge Fire began during a period of hot, dry weather on July 3rd, at 1:34 PM. The fire burned 263 acres of brush on Yucaipa Ridge before it was extinguished. One firefighter was treated for heat exhaustion.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Ridge Fire burned 263 acres of brush on Yucaipa Ridge.

The Tehipite Fire occurred in Sequoia National Park. The ignition date was July 19 at 1215 PST. The cause was lightning. The location was 20 miles northeast of Dunlap in Fresno County. The size of the wildfire was 1,331 acres. Estimated date of containment was October 15. There were no fatalities or lost structures. The cost to containment was $500,000.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning from a thunderstorm event on 07/22/08 ignited another round of wildfires across northern California.  The Panther Wildfire started this day around 3:00 AM. It was still burning at the end of July.  As of 0430 PDT on 08/01/08, this fire was 5338 acres in size and 0% contained with an estimated containment date of 08/28/08. 1.4 million had been expended in fire fighting efforts.  This fire caused one firefighter death on 07/27/08.  He was doing reconnaissance work when a wind shift caused him to become entrapped.  The autopsy stated he died of burns and smoke inhalation.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lightning from a thunderstorm event on 07/22/08 ignited another round of wildfires across northern California.  The Panther Wildfire started this day around 3:00 AM. This fire caused one firefighter death on 07/27/08.

The Telegraph wildfire was located in the CalFire Merced-Madera-Mariposa Unit, near Mariposa in Mariposa County. The ignition date was July 25 at 1410 PST. The cause was human, due to target shooting. The size was 34,091 acres. The wildfire was contained on August 5. There were no fatalities. There were 130 properties lost, of which 100 were outbuildings. Property damages were estimated at $25M. The cost to containment was $36.5M.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning from a thunderstorm event on 07/22/08 ignited another round of wildfires across northern California. The Panther Wildfire started this day around 3:00 AM. It was still burning at the end of August. As of 0800 PDT on 09/01/08, this fire was 48108 acres in size and 75% contained with an unknown estimated containment date. 15.0 million had been expended in fire fighting efforts. This fire caused one firefighter death on 07/27/08.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lightning from a thunderstorm event on 07/22/08 ignited another round of wildfires across northern California. The Panther Wildfire started this day around 3:00 AM. This fire caused one firefighter death on 07/27/08.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Canyon Complex was located west of Quincy and included 55 lightning initiated fires that burned a total of 37,831 acres by the end of August. There were several buildings destroyed and firefighters injured and these were reported in the July Storm Data report. The fires were 97 percent contained by the end of August.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with little or no rain spread across the area on June 21st. About 8000 lighting strikes were detected, sparking approximately 2000 wildfires across northern California. These fires destroyed numerous structures and caused multiple deaths and injuries. Evacuations were ordered for affected communities. Smoke from the wildfires caused respiratory concerns across the region. Due to the shear number of fires initiated and early season lower resource levels, many fires were not initially staffed. Some of these fires continued to burn into August, when near complete containment was finally achieved.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning from a thunderstorm event on 06/21/08 ignited numerous fires across northern California. The Siskiyou Complex and the Blue 2 complex were still burning at the end of July...and have been combined as one entity. As of 0800 PDT on 09/01/08, this fire was 78384 acres in size and 95% contained with an estimated containment date of 09/02/08. 62.5 million had been expended in fire fighting efforts.

The size of the wildfire was 1,331 acres. Estimated date of containment was October 15. There were no fatalities or lost structures. The cost to containment was $500,000.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning from a thunderstorm event on 06/21/08 ignited numerous fires across northern California. They started this day around 4:00 PM, but no resources were directed to this fire until July. It was still burning at the end of August, and consisted of the Bear Wallow and South Ukonom fires. In late August, this fire was transferred to NIMC and was considered to be low priority. Thus, at the end of August, no current status information was available. However, information was available later on and as of 0630 PDT on 09/11/08, this fire was 47998 acres in size and 75% contained with an estimated containment date of 09/30/08. 13.8 million had been expended in fire fighting efforts.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lightning from a thunderstorm event on 06/21/08 ignited numerous fires across northern California. However, information was available later on and as of 0630 PDT on 09/11/08, this fire was 47998 acres in size and 75% contained with an estimated containment date of 09/30/08. 13.8 million had been expended in fire fighting efforts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Craig wildfire was located near Lake Oroville and burned 2001 acres before being 100 percent contained on August 11th. The fire began on the 3rd from unknown causes. No damage or injuries were reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire burned 2000 acres in Butte County in early August.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were at least 17 lightning fires started in Butte, Sutter, and Yuba Counties. These fires were quickly fought by ground crews and aerial attacks. Most of the fires were extinguished on the first day, with the remaining two contained by August 8th. No injuries or structural damage was reported. The lightning also briefly knocked out power to northern Chico.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms over interior Northern California generated lightning with limited rainfall. Approximately 17 new lightning fires were reported in Butte and Yuba Counties. The fires were relatively small and quickly contained.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning from a thunderstorm event on 06/21/08 ignited numerous fires across northern California. The Siskiyou Complex and the Blue 2 complex were still burning at the end of September...and have been combined as one entity. As of 0800 PDT on 09/25/08, this fire was 87800 acres in size and 95% contained with an estimated containment date of 09/30/08. No update on expenditures was available, but as of 08/01/08, 62.5 million had been expended in fire fighting efforts.

The Tehipite wildfire was ignited on July 19 at 1215 PST. The cause was lightning. The location was 20 miles northeast of Dunlap in Fresno County in Sequoia National Park. The size was 11,085 acres. The wildfire was ongoing at the end of the month. There were no fatalities or properties damaged. The cost to containment was $733,000.

The Hidden wildfire was located in Sequoia National Park, 12 miles North-Northeast of Three Rivers in Tulare County, and was ignited on September 10 at 1724 PST. The case was lightning and the size was 3,366 acres. There were no fatalities or property damage. The cost to containment was  $8,913,311. The wildfire was contained on September 30 at 1700 PST.

The Cascadel wildfire was located in the Sierra National Forest. The ignition date was September 11 at 2000 PST. The cause was human, from target shooting. The location was 3 miles East-Northeast of North Fork in Madera County. The size was 280 acres. The wildfire was contained on September 17 at 1700 PST. There were no fatalities or properties damaged. The cost to containment was $3,100,000.

CZ_NAME_STR: LOS ANGELES COUNTY MOUNTAINS EXCLUDING THE SANTA MONICA RANGE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Marek Wildfire burned 4,824 acres of land in the Angeles National Forecast. Given the proximity of the wildfire to some foothill communities, numerous structures were destroyed or damaged. In total, 39 residences were destroyed and 9 severely damaged. In addition, two commercial buildings were destroyed and one severely damaged. Over $4 million was spent to fight the fire.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of very hot temperatures, low relative humidity and gusty offshore winds helped to fuel two significant wildfires in Los Angeles county. The Marek Fire burned 4,824 acres in the Angeles National Forest, just north of Glendale. The Sesnon Fire burned 14,703 acres in the Santa Clarita Valley of Los Angeles County, near the community of Porter Ranch. Both wildfires occurred within the urban-wildland fire interface, destroying or damaging numerous homes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Sesnon Wildfire burned 14,703 acres of land in the Santa Susana Mountains. Given the proximity of the fire to the urban-wildland fire interface, numerous homes were destroyed in the communities of Poter Ranch, Twin Lakes and Indian Hills. In total, 15 homes were destroyed and 11 severely damaged while 63 outbuildings were destroyed. The total cost to fight the fire was over $12 million.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of very hot temperatures, low relative humidity and gusty offshore winds helped to fuel two significant wildfires in Los Angeles county. The Marek Fire burned 4,824 acres in the Angeles National Forest, just north of Glendale. The Sesnon Fire burned 14,703 acres in the Santa Clarita Valley of Los Angeles County, near the community of Porter Ranch. Both wildfires occurred within the urban-wildland fire interface, destroying or damaging numerous homes.

The Juliet Fire began at 10:49 AM on October 13th, 2008 at the Camp Pendleton Marine Corps base in Oceanside, California. Mandatory evacuations were in place for several housing areas on the base, as well as portions of Oceanside and Fallbrook. The fire burned 4,026 acres before being contained on the evening of the 15th. One firefighter sustained minor injuries and two commercial greenhouses near the base were destroyed.

The Shockey Fire began at 2:45 AM on October 14th, 2008 in Morena Village, CA along Highway 94 at Shockey Truck Trail. Approximately 300 homes were evacuated in Lake Morena and Campo.  The 200 acre fire was contained by 6 PM. No structures were damaged or destroyed. Two firefighters sustained minor injuries.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Tea Fire burned 1,940 acres of land in the foothills of the Santa Ynez mountains near the community of Montecito. The fire ignited when strong north winds, gusting to 72 mph, blew some embers from a bonfire started by several individuals. The winds spread the fire very quickly, consuming most of its acreage in one burn period. The fire destroyed approximately 210 residences and severely damaged 9 others. Westmont College in the foothills of Montecito experienced significant destruction, including the Physics building and numerous staff housing. Initial property damage estimates are not available at this time.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An extended period of offshore winds affected Southern California. North to northeast wind gusts in excess of 65 MPH were reported in some areas. The strong winds, combined with very dry conditions, helped fuel two significant wildfires. The Tea Fire, near Montecito in Santa Barbara county, burned 1,940 acres. The Sayre Fire, north of Sylmar in Los Angeles county, burned 11,262 acres. Both fires produced significant loss of residences.

The fire ignited when strong north winds, gusting to 72 mph, blew some embers from a bonfire started by several individuals. The winds spread the fire very quickly, consuming most of its acreage in one burn period. The fire destroyed approximately 210 residences and severely damaged 9 others. Westmont College in the foothills of Montecito experienced significant destruction, including the Physics building and numerous staff housing. Initial property damage estimates are not available at this time.

CZ_NAME_STR: LOS ANGELES COUNTY SAN FERNANDO VALLEY (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Sayre Fire burned 11,262 acres of land in the foothills of Los Angeles county near the community of Sylmar. The fire, started under unknown circumstances, was fueled by northeast winds gusting in excess of 60 MPH as well as very dry conditions. The Sayre Fire produced significant property damage. An estimated 487 residences were destroyed with the most significant damage occurring in a mobile home park. Initial property damage estimates are in excess of $3.5 million.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An extended period of offshore winds affected Southern California. North to northeast wind gusts in excess of 65 MPH were reported in some areas. The strong winds, combined with very dry conditions, helped fuel two significant wildfires. The Tea Fire, near Montecito in Santa Barbara county, burned 1,940 acres. The Sayre Fire, north of Sylmar in Los Angeles county, burned 11,262 acres. Both fires produced significant loss of residences.

The Sayre Fire, north of Sylmar in Los Angeles county, burned 11,262 acres. Both fires produced significant loss of residences.

The Freeway Complex Fire began in the Santa Ana River bottom near Corona on November 15, 2008. Dry, Santa Ana winds caused the fire to quickly spread into the Chino Hills and the nearby cities of Yorba Linda, Anaheim Hills, and Brea. The Freeway Complex Fire burned 30,305 acres and forced the evacuation of about 40,000 people. The fire damaged 127 homes, 2 commercial properties, and 32 outbuildings. The fire destroyed 187 homes, 2 commercial properties, and 11 outbuilding.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Freeway Complex Fire began in the Santa Ana River bottom near Corona on November 15, 2008. Dry, Santa Ana winds caused the fire to quickly spread into the Chino Hills and the nearby cities of Yorba Linda, Anaheim Hills, and Brea. The Freeway Complex Fire burned 30,305 acres and forced the evacuation of about 40,000 people. The fire damaged 127 homes, 2 commercial properties, and 32 outbuildings. The fire destroyed 187 homes, 2 commercial properties, and 11 outbuilding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A vegetation fire fueled by gusty winds spread to a single family home near La Quinta and partially destroyed the roof.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level trough coupled with a 125 MPH jet max and strong onshore pressure gradients brought light rain and strong winds to Southern California on March 22nd. Gusty winds knocked down trees, freeway signs, and power lines in the mountains and deserts. Two fires were reported during this time, both of which caused damage to structures and trees.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A vegetation fire fueled by gusty winds spread through Lake Cahuilla Park near La Quinta. The fire destroyed playground equipment, an awning of a building, and 35 palm trees.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level trough coupled with a 125 MPH jet max and strong onshore pressure gradients brought light rain and strong winds to Southern California on March 22nd. Gusty winds knocked down trees, freeway signs, and power lines in the mountains and deserts. Two fires were reported during this time, both of which caused damage to structures and trees.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The fire began in sparse desert brush near a residential neighborhood. Strong, gusty winds spread the fire towards the neighborhood, resulting in the damage of two homes and the evacuation of approximately 50 other homes. No major injuries were reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A 50 acre brush fire in Palm Springs, driven by strong gusty winds, damaged two homes and led to the evacuation of 50 other homes. The fire began in the late afternoon, burning desert scrub near a residential neighborhood. The fire was contained later that evening.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Jesusita Wildfire burned 8,733 acres of land in the hills above the city of Santa Barbara. The fire was driven by a combination of a large dead fuel bed and gusty Sundowner winds. Automated sensors in the vicinity of the fire reported northerly wind gusts in excess of 60 MPH for many hours which were supported by observations from the fireline. Overall, 80 homes were destroyed and another 15 homes were badly damaged. No deaths were reported, but at least 30 firefighters reported some type of injury. Suppression costs were in excess of $17 million with no report of the amount of property damage.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Jesusita Fire burned over 8,700 acres in the hills above the city of Santa Barbara. This wildfire was driven by a combination of a large dead fuel bed and Sundowner winds gusting over 60 MPH. The damage as a result of this fire was significant with 80 homes destroyed and another 15 homes badly damaged. No deaths were reported but at least 30 firefighters were injured battling the fire.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Jesusita Wildfire burned 8,733 acres of land in the hills above the city of Santa Barbara. The fire was driven by a combination of a large dead fuel bed and gusty Sundowner winds. Automated sensors in the vicinity of the fire reported northerly wind gusts in excess of 60 MPH for many hours which were supported by observations from the fireline. Overall, 80 homes were destroyed and another 15 homes were badly damaged. No deaths were reported, but at least 30 firefighters reported some type of injury. Suppression costs were in excess of $17 million with no report of the amount of property damage.

This wildfire was driven by a combination of a large dead fuel bed and Sundowner winds gusting over 60 MPH. The damage as a result of this fire was significant with 80 homes destroyed and another 15 homes badly damaged. No deaths were reported but at least 30 firefighters were injured battling the fire.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A four acre fire began around 1145 PST in Otay Mesa along Airway Road near Caliente Avenue. The fire spread through light grass and into a pile of tires. A shed and an abandoned house were destroyed by the blaze. The fire was contained by about 1245 PST. No injuries were reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A small fire fueled by gusty winds destroyed a shed and an abandoned house in Otay Mesa.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two separate vegetation fires were started by an arsonist around 1447 PST on May 27th. The fires spread over the next twenty-four hours, burning a total of 503 acres. The fires caused the evacuation of parts of the Lake Perris State Recreation Area and the closure of several roads. No damage or injuries were reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two vegetation fires began on May 27th near the Lake Perris State Recreation Area. The fire led to an evaction of the Lake Perris State Recreation Area campground and several roads were closed in the area.The 503 acre fire was contained around 1700 PST on May 28th. The cause of the fire was determined to be arson. No damage to structures or injuries were reported.

Thunderstorms developed over western Fresno County during the evening of June 4th, and rapidly grew in intensity. One severe thunderstorm had a reflectivity of 73 dBz, and a VIL (vertically integrated liquid) of 43 g/kg. Hail up to an inch in diameter fell near the town of Helm, and outflow winds were estimated at around 60 mph.||The low finally moved onshore on the 5th, and lifted northeast into northern Nevada that evening. An upper-level trough remained over California, with an unseasonably cold airmass aloft. Upper-level impulses moving through the trough continued the threat of afternoon and evening mountain convection, with isolated light showers drifting over the San Joaquin Valley at times. Temperatures fell to some 10-15 degrees below normal, and stayed well below normal for the next week.||The Grouse wildfire that was sparked by lightning on May 30th continued through the month of June. The ignition time was 1400 PST on May 30th, the location was 3 miles southwest of Yosemite Valley in Mariposa County.  The size of the fire was 3047 acres. The cost to containment was $2.9 million. The containment date was July 13th.

The Harden wildfire located in Yosemite NP, ignited on June 7th at 2301 PST due to lightning. The location was 13 miles north of Yosemite Valley in Mariposa County. The size was 1661 acres. Containment was on July 10th. Cost to containment was $880,000.

Unsettled weather remained across inland Central California through much of early and mid June due to upper level low pressure and pulses of energy in the upper atmosphere. Scattered thunderstorms were common during this time period over the Southern Sierra Nevada. Daytime temperatures were typically 10-20 degrees cooler than normal for many locations.||A hiker on Half Dome in Yosemite National Park was killed when he fell while climbing. Conditions at the time were stormy with brief bursts of heavy rain...lightning and hail. ||A wildfire was ignited on June 17th at 1232 PST by lightning. The Shotgun wildfire was located 25 miles northeast of Porterville in Tulare County. The size was 900 acres and containment was 50% on July 10th. The cost for containment was $40,000.

The Lion Wildfire, located in Sequoia National Forest, ignited on 6/30/09 at 1030 PDT due to lightning strikes. The location was 3 miles northwest of the Blackrock Ranger Station on the Kern Plateau in Tulare County. The size was 2023 acres. There were no fatalities or structures lost directly due to the wildfire. The cost to containment was  $528,190.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire started on July 26th along the Middle Fork of the Stanislaus River, near Mt. Knight, in Stanislaus County.  The fire had burned 2734 acres by the end of July and continued to burn into August.  It brought multiple local road closures and smoke to the nearby area.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Knight Fire started on July 26th, burning a forested area by the Middle Fork of the Stanislaus River.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were 6130 acres of forest burned in rugged terrain along the Middle Fork of the American River.  Local forest service roads were closed due to the fire, as were several campgrounds.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Knight Fire burned an area of forest along the Middle Fork of the American River.  The fire started on July 26th and was 100 percent contained by August 11th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm lightning strikes starting at least 43 fires in Lassen National Forest on August 1st. The largest of the Hat Creek Complex fires were the Sugarloaf, Brown, and the Butte fires. There were 11,269 acres of forest burned in the Complex.  Other impacts included evacuations of campgrounds in the Hat Creek Recreation area, road closures of portions of State Highway 89 and State Highway 44, and the closure of the Pacific Crest Trail.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Hat Creek Complex and SHU Lightning Complex fires were started by lightning strikes from thunderstorms on the evening of August 1st.  Approximately 1800 lightning ground strikes were recorded in Northern California.  The Hat Creek Complex continued until containment on August 12th.  THe SHU Lightning Complex continued until containment on August 17th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm lightning strikes started numerous fires in Shasta County on the evening of August 1st. The SHU Complex consisted of 40 fires, with the largest being the Gomez, Cave, Cassel, the Goose, and the Chalk fires.  Dozens of homes were evacuated and a number of area roads were closed. There were 17,623 acres of forest burned prior to containment on August 17th.  This fire complex included burned acreage in CA-Z013.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Hat Creek Complex and SHU Lightning Complex fires were started by lightning strikes from thunderstorms on the evening of August 1st.  Approximately 1800 lightning ground strikes were recorded in Northern California.  The Hat Creek Complex continued until containment on August 12th.  THe SHU Lightning Complex continued until containment on August 17th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm lightning strikes started numerous fires in Shasta County on the evening of August 1st. The Complex consisted of 40 fires, with the largest being the Gomez, Cave, Cassel, the Goose, and the Chalk fires. Dozens of homes were evacuated, and a number of area roads were closed. There were 17,623 acres of forest burned prior to containment on August 17th.  This fire complex included burned acreage in CA-Z014.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Hat Creek Complex and SHU Lightning Complex fires were started by lightning strikes from thunderstorms on the evening of August 1st.  Approximately 1800 lightning ground strikes were recorded in Northern California.  The Hat Creek Complex continued until containment on August 12th.  THe SHU Lightning Complex continued until containment on August 17th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Harrington fire in the Marble Mountain Wilderness portion of the Klamath National Forest was started by lightning on 8/02/09 around 5 PM PDT.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Harrington fire in the Marble Mountain Wilderness portion of the Klamath National Forest was started by lightning on 8/02/09 around 5 PM PDT. As of 09/01/09, it was at 142 acres and was 100 percent contained.  As of 09/01/09, the cost of the fire was 482,000 dollars.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The La Brea Wildfire burned 89,489 acres of land in the mountains of Santa Barbara county in the Los Padres National Forest. The cause of the fire was determined to be a cooking fire at an illegal marijuana operation in the forest. Fortunately only two structures were destrouyed: a hunter's cabin and a unused ranger's cabin. The main conditions driving this wildfire were hot temperatures, very low relative humidity and a very old and dry fuel bed. Overall, the estimated cost to suppress the fire was $23 million.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In the month of August, the La Brea Wildfire burned over 89,000 acres in the Los Padres National Forest in the county of Santa Barbara. The fire was fueled by very hot temperatures, low relative humidity and significant fuels.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Elephant Wildfire burned 445 acres of woodland.  Highway 70 travel was limited at one point to one way traffic with a pilot car, causing travel delays.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Elephant Fire burned an area of forest along Feather River Canyon, near Rock Creek.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Red Rock fire in the Marble Mountain Wilderness portion of the Klamath National Forest was started by humans on 8/21/09 around 7 PM PDT.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Red Rock fire in the Marble Mountain Wilderness portion of the Klamath National Forest was started by humans on 8/21/09 around 7 PM PDT. As of 09/01/09, it was at 1382 acres and was 85 percent contained.  Fire fighting efforts were transferred to a local unit on 09/01/09, and full containment is estimated to occur on 9/5/9.  As of 09/01/09, the cost of the fire was 3.7 million dollars.

CZ_NAME_STR: LOS ANGELES COUNTY MOUNTAINS EXCLUDING THE SANTA MONICA RANGE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Station Wildfire burned 160,577 acres across the mountains of Los Angeles County in the Angeles National Forest from late August through mid-September. The suspected cause of the fire was arson. The Station Fire destroyed 209 structures, including 89 residences. In addition, two Los Angeles County firefighters were killed on August 30th while evacuating their fire camp. The total suppression cost for the fire was over $93 million.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Station Wildfire started on August 26th in the mountains of Los Angeles County in the Angeles National Forest. The fire burned intensely into the middle of September. When the fire was contained, it had burned over 160,000 acres and destroyed numerous homes. In addition, two Los Angeles County firefighters were killed when evacuating their fire station.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Cottonwood Fire began four miles East of Hemet on August 27th at approximately 5:13 PM PDT. The fire spread East along California Highway 74 towards Idyllwild in the San Bernardino National Forest. The fire burned 2,409 acres before being contained on August 31st. No structures were damaged, and five firefighters sustained heat related injuries. The cause of the fire may have been due to a power pole, but is still under investigation.

The Cottonwood Fire began four miles East of Hemet on August 27th at approximately 5:13 PM PDT. The fire spread East along California Highway 74 towards Idyllwild in the San Bernardino National Forest. The fire burned 2,409 acres before being contained on August 31st. No structures were damaged, and five firefighters sustained heat related injuries. The cause of the fire may have been due to a power pole, but is still under investigation.

The Oak Glen III Fire started on August 30th around 1:46 PM PDT near the community of Oak Glen in the San Bernardino National Forest. Mandatory evacuations were ordered for parts of Oak Glen. The fire burned 1,159 acres before being contained on September 8th. Approximately 2,000 homes were threatened. One residence and one outbuilding were destroyed, and one other residence was damaged. Four injuries were reported, though the details are unknown. The fire cost approximately 6.9 million dollars to fight.

The Pendleton Fire began at approximately 3:30 PM PDT on August 31st near Yucaipa. Evacuations were ordered for 1,100 homes and some roads were closed. One residential structure and one outbuilding were destroyed in the 860 acre fire, which was contained on September 3rd. One injury was reported. The cause of the 1.49 million dollar fire is still under investigation.

The Oak Glen III Fire started on August 30th around 1:46 PM PDT near the community of Oak Glen in the San Bernardino National Forest. Mandatory evacuations were ordered for parts of Oak Glen. The fire burned 1,159 acres before being contained on September 8th. Approximately 2,000 homes were threatened. One residence and one outbuilding were destroyed, and one other residence was damaged. Four injuries were reported, though the details are unknown. The fire cost approximately 6.9 million dollars to fight.

The location was 9 miles northwest of Tuolumne Meadows in Yosemite NP. The original cause was from lightning. The size was 1255 acres. ||The Power fire in Sequoia National Forest, ignited on September 27th early in the morning. The cause was unknown. The location was Highway 190 near Springville in Tulare County. The size was 400 acres. The fire was contained on September 29th at a cost of $500,000.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Red Rock fire in the Marble Mountain Wilderness portion of the Klamath National Forest was started by humans on 8/21/09 around 7 PM PDT. As of 09/02/09, it was at 1382 acres and was 90 percent contained.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Red Rock fire in the Marble Mountain Wilderness portion of the Klamath National Forest was started by humans on 8/21/09 around 7 PM PDT. As of 09/02/09, it was at 1382 acres and was 90 percent contained. Fire fighting efforts were transferred to a local unit on 09/01/09, and full containment was estimated to occur on 9/5/9. As of 09/01/09, the cost of the fire was 3.7 million dollars.  No dollar figures are available after that date.

The Pendleton Fire began at approximately 3:30 PM PDT on August 31st near Yucaipa. Evacuations were ordered for 1,100 homes and some roads were closed. One residential structure and one outbuilding were destroyed in the 860 acre fire, which was contained on September 3rd. One injury was reported. The cause of the 1.49 million dollar fire is still under investigation.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Oasis Fire burned 1575 acres in the Cache Creek Wilderness in eastern Lake County.  There were 4 firefighters injured, but no structures damaged or destroyed.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Oasis Fire burned in the Cache Creek Wilderness in eastern Lake County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning started a number of fires over the northern Sierra Nevada Mountains including the Telegraph Fire near Copperopolis (200 acres) and the San Antonio Fire near Arnold (5 acres), both located in Calaveras County.  The other fires were small and quickly extinguished.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought about 1500 recorded lightning strikes to northern California.  One lightning strike injured a woman at a sporting event in Stockton and a number of small wildfires were started across the area.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Silver Fire burned 307 acres of forest in steep terrain in the Plumas National Forest in Plumas County.  The fire burned to about 10 miles west of Quincy and was also near Silver Lake and the community of Meadow Valley.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Silver Fire burned in the Plumas National Forest in Plumas County, about 10 miles west of Quincy.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Guiberson Wildfire burned 17,500 acres of land between the cities of Fillmore and Moorpark. The fire, which was started by a smoldering compost pile, was driven the first couple of days by a moderate Santa Ana wind event with northeast wind gusts to around 55 mph reported in and around the fire. The fire fortunately only destroyed one out building, but did result in 10 injuries. The total cost to suppress the fire was nearly $10 million.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Guiberson Wildfire burned over 17,000 acres in the valleys of Ventura County. The fire itself was driven by a moderate Santa Ana wind event with gusty northeast winds to around 50 mph reported in and near the fire.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Guiberson Wildfire burned 17,500 acres of land between the cities of Fillmore and Moorpark. The fire, which was started by a smoldering compost pile, was driven the first couple of days by a moderate Santa Ana wind event with northeast wind gusts to around 55 mph reported in and around the fire. The fire fortunately only destroyed one out building, but did result in 10 injuries. The total cost to suppress the fire was nearly $10 million.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Guiberson Wildfire burned over 17,000 acres in the valleys of Ventura County. The fire itself was driven by a moderate Santa Ana wind event with gusty northeast winds to around 50 mph reported in and near the fire.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The fire broke out just after 1200 PDT in the hills between Norco and Riverside just East of the Interstate 15 between Fourth and Fifth streets. The Fire consumed 150 acres and destroyed a storage building.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two wildland fires broke out in Norco On September 22. The fire in the hills east of the city burned 160 acres destroyed a storage building, while the 85 acre fire in the Santa Ana River bottom caused minor damage to one home. No injuries were reported.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A second fire began around 1330 PDT in the Santa Ana River bottom near Norco. The fire burned 85 acres and caused minor damage to one home.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two wildland fires broke out in Norco On September 22. The fire in the hills east of the city burned 160 acres destroyed a storage building, while the 85 acre fire in the Santa Ana River bottom caused minor damage to one home. No injuries were reported.

A few wildfires continued during the month of September in the Sierra Nevada.  ||The Power fire in Sequoia National Forest, ignited on September 27th early in the morning. The cause was unknown. The location was Highway 190 near Springville in Tulare County. The size was 400 acres. The fire was contained on September 29th at a cost of $500,000.

The Sheep Fire started along Sheep Creek Road near Lytle Creek around 1311 PST on October 3rd. The fire spread rapidly towards Wrightwood, scorching a total of 7,128 acres before being contained on October 10th. The fire forced approximately 5,000 residents to evacuate and destroyed one residence, four other structures, five cars, four RVs, and 2 pieces of heavy equipment. Eight firefighters were injured. The fire cost over eight million dollars to fight. Investigators say the fire was started by a human, but it is still unclear whether it was intentional or not.

A brush fire was started along Highway 76 near Verdugo Canyon Road when a tractor crashed into a power pole around 1130 PST on November 16th. The fire burned about 145 acres before being contained on the evening of the 17th. Four firefighters sustained injuries fighting the blaze, and no damage was reported.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The McKinley Fire began at approximately 1213 PST on May 20th near the intersection of September Way and April Drive in Home Gardens, near Corona, California. The fire was started by mowing equipment and quickly spread towards the southeast. No homes or other structures were threatened. The fire grew to 1,028 acres before being contained around 0500 PST on the 21st. One firefighter sustained a minor ankle injury while fighting the blaze. No other damage or injuries were reported.

The Camp Pendleton Fire began at approximately 0823 PST on July 13th at the Camp Pendleton Marine Base, California. The fire started due to training exercises at the base on the southwest range. No structures were damages and no injuries occurred. The fire grew to 3500+ acres before being contained around 1700 PST on the 14th.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Stetson Fire began at approximately 1000 PST on July 15th near the intersection of Stetson Avenue and Stanford, near East Hemet, California. The cause of the fire is unknown. The fire burned 0.5 acres before being contained around 1124 the same day. Two homes had minor exterior damage, with one outbuilding and a playhouse destroyed. An adult male was treated on the scene for difficulty in breathing and declined transport to a medical facility. No other damage or injuries were reported.

The Cactus Fire began at approximately 1400 PST on July 15th near the intersection of Red Mountain road and Owl Creek, near the city of Sage, California. The fire, along with a few other small fires in the Sage-Anza-Pinyon area, was started by lightning and burned a total of 706 acres before being contained at 0600 PST on the 18th. Mandatory evacuations of the residents of Cactus Valley and R3, Limb Road and Old Ranch Road were ordered around 1930 PST on the 15th. Residents were not allowed back into the area until the night of the 18th. No damage or injuries were reported with this fire.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Skinner Fire began at approximately 1442 PST on July 15th near the intersection of Crown Valley Road and De Portola Road near the city of Temecula, California. The fire was started by lightning and grew quickly to 200 acres within a few hours. Residents in the area were evacuated and allowed to return to their homes around 2100 PST on the 15th. The fire grew to 503 acres before being contained around 0600 PST on the 18th. No damage or injuries were reported with this fire.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Saddle Fire began at approximately 1447 PST on July 15th near the intersection of Oak Glen Road and Red Mountain Road, near the city of Sage, California. The exact cause of the fire is not listed, however, multiple lighting-caused fires occurred in this area on the 15th. The Saddle Fire burned 80 acres before being contained around 0600 PST on the 18th. An evacuation order was issued at the onset of the fire, with residents being allowed back to their homes at 2100 PST on the 15th. One outbuilding was damaged. No other injuries or damage were reported.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Maywood Fire began at approximately 1038 PST on July 17th near the intersection of Santa Rosa Mine Road and Christmas Tree Lane in Good Hope, near Perris, California. The cause of the fire is yet unknown, but was contained around 1545 PST on the same day. Two firefighters were evaluated by paramedics for heat-related injuries.

The Bull wildfire occurred in Sequoia National Forest. The ignition date was 7/26/10 at   1346 PDT. The cause was human. The location was 8 miles North of Kernville, CA in both Kern County and Tulare County. The size was 16,442 acres and full containment was estimated on 8/10/10. There were no fatalities. There were 8 primary and 6 outbuildings lost to the fire. The cost was estimated on 8/5/10 at $10,991,701.||The West wildfire was managed by the Kern County Fire Department. The ignition date was 7/27/10 at 1416 PDT. The cause was human. The location was 5 miles south of Tehachapi, CA in Kern County. The size was 1658 acres. Containment occurred on 8/1/10. No fatalities occurred. There were 23 primary and 41 outbuildings lost to the fire. Cost was $6,543,253.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Dutch Fire started at 1620 PDT on 07/31/10, and the cause is under investigation.  It was contained at 1800 PDT on 08/04/10 at 371 acres.  2.2 million dollars was expended on fire fighting efforts.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Dutch fire broke out in the Klamath National Forest at 1620 PST on the afternoon of 07/31/10.

The Slope Wildfire in Yosemite National Park ignited on July 25, 2010 at 1445 PDT. The cause was lightning. The location was northwest of White Wolf in Tuolumne County. The size was 1709 acres. This fire was not contained until early October due to rainfall. The cost was $75,000. There were no fatalities or property damages reported.

The Sheep Wildfire occurred in Sequoia/Kings Canyon National Park. The ignition date was July 16, 2010, at 1200 PDT, and the cause was lightning. The location was 1.5 miles southwest of Cedar Grove in Fresno County along the Tulare County border. The size was 9007 acres (3119 acres in Kings Canyon NP, 5888 acres in Sequoia Forest). The wildfire was extinguished by rain between October 3-6. There were no fatalities or lost structures, and the cost was $1,567,000.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The El Toro fire began at approximately 0654 PST on August 3rd near the intersection of El Toro Road and Lindell Road near the city of Lake Elsinore, CA. The cause of the fire was determined to be motorized cutting equipment used to dismantle an abandoned vehicle. The fire grew to 32 acres before being contained around 1800 PST on August 3rd. Paramedics evaluated one firefighter for minor injuries on-site and transported another firefighter to a local hospital for heat-related injuries. No damage was reported.

The Vernon Wildfire occurred in Yosemite National Park. The ignition date was August 8, 2010, at 0000 PDT. The cause was lightning. The location was 21 Miles North-Northwest of Yosemite Valley in Tuolumne County. The size was 909 acres. The fire was contained on October 3. No fatalities or damages occurred. The cost was $50,000.

The Post Wildfire occurred in Kern County near Lebec, and was managed by the Kern County Fire Department.  The Ignition date was August 24, 2010 at 1227 PDT. The cause was unknown and the size was 1312 acres. Containment was made on August 28, 2010. There were no fatalities or structures lost, and the cost was $5,139,691.

Lightning caused three brush fires near Inspiration Point, Keys View and Upper Boy Scout Trailhead within the Joshua Tree National Park at approximately 1200 PST on August 26th. The fire grew to 110 acres and burned on rocky slopes with scattered pinon pines, junipers, Joshua trees and other desert brush. The road to Keys View from the Park Boulevard junction was temporarily closed to the public.

The Sheep wildfire occurred in Sequoia/Kings Canyon National Park. The ignition date was 7/16/10 at 1200 PDT. The cause was lightning. The location was 1.5 miles southwest of Cedar Grove (Fresno County along the Tulare County border). The size was 9007 acres (3119 acres in Kings Canyon NP, 5888 acres in Sequoia Forest). Containment was reported on Oct 3, 2010. Rain on Oct 3-6 extinguished the fire. The cost for containment was $1,567,000 as of 10/3/10.

The Sheep wildfire occurred in Sequoia/Kings Canyon National Park. The ignition date was 7/16/10 at 1200 PDT. The cause was lightning. Containment was reported on Oct 3, 2010. Rain on Oct 3-6 extinguished the fire. The cost for containment was $1,567,000 as of 10/3/10.

The Vernon wildfire occurred in Yosemite National Park. The ignition date was  8/7/2010 at midnight. The cause was  Lightning and the location was 21 Miles North-Northwest of Yosemite Valley (Tuolumne County). The size was 909 acres and containment was achieved on 10/3/10. There were no fatalities or lost structures and the cost to containment was $50,000.

The Slope wildfire was ignited on 7/25/10 at 1445 PDT. The cause was lightning. The location was Northwest of White Wolf (Tuolumne County). The size was 1709 acres. Wet weather in early October put the remainder of the fire out. There were no fatalities or lost structures and the cost to containment was $75,000.

The Buckhorn wildfire occurred in the Sierra National Forest and the ignition date was 8/7/10 at 2300 PDT. The cause was Lightning. The location was 27 miles Northeast of North Fork, CA (Madera County). The size was 281 acres. The containment was September 28, 2010. Rain on Oct 3-6 further extinguished the fire. No fatalities or lost structures, and the cost to containment was $125,000.

The Canyon wildfire occurred in Sequoia National Forest and the ignition date was 9/12/10 at 1354 PDT. The cause was by human activity. The location was 8 miles West of Lake Isabella, CA (Kern County). The size was 9820 acres. Containment was achieved on 9/19/10 at 1800 PDT. There were no fatalities. There was 1 primary structure lost. The cost to containment was $11,250,000.

The Long Canyon fire started around 1100 PST on September 23rd in the Cleveland National Forest in eastern Orange County, west of the Ortega Highway near the Riverside County line. Some structures were threatened, but the fire generally burned away from the populated areas, 40 acres total. Three firefighters and one police officer suffered non-life threatening heat-related and smoke inhalation injuries. One of the Cleveland National Forest's fire engines was destroyed by fire, cause unknown, no injuries.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Center Fire (850 acres) destroyed or damaged 19 homes in the Big Pine, CA area.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Center Fire destroyed or damaged 19 homes in the Big Pine, CA area.

CZ_NAME_STR: NORTHEAST SISKIYOU AND NORTHWEST MODOC COUNTIES (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Scorpion Wildfire started on 07/15/2011. The cause is still under investigation.  By the time it was contained on 07/18/2011, it had burned 2945 acres and cost $545,000.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Scorpion Wildfire started on 07/15/2011. The cause is still under investigation.  By the time it was contained on 07/18/2011, it had burned 2945 acres and cost $545,000.

The Eagle fire started around 0940 PST on July 21, off Eagles Nest Road and Camino San Ignacio, roughly five miles east of Warner Springs. Only one outbuilding was destroyed, and the fire generally burned in unpopulated areas to a total size of 14,140 acres. Eighteen fire personnel suffered non-life threatening injuries. The cause of the fire was determined to be arson. Lost Valley Boy Scout Camp and the Borrego Palm Canyon Campground were evacuated while the fire was battled and reopened soon after the fire was fully contained on Saturday the 23rd.

The Lion wildfire occurred in Sequoia National Forest. The ignition date was July 8th at   1300 PDT. The cause was lightning. The location was 20 miles northeast of Springville in Tulare County. The size was 20,428 acres. Containment was 91% as of August 16, and  being managed for resource objectives. There were no fatalities or structures Lost. The cost to reach containment was $1,640,000.

The Avalanche wildfire occurred in Yosemite National Park. The ignition date was July 31 at 1142 PDT. The cause was lightning. The location was 7 miles Southwest of Yosemite Valley in Mariposa County. The size was 1,050 acres. There were no fatalities or lost structures and the cost to containment was $550,000.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Gilman fire started around 1500 PST on August 6, along Gilman Springs Road east of Highway 60 near Moreno Valley. The fire burned rapidly though grass and brush to a total of 945 acres before it was finally contained around 1700 PST on the 7th. Highway 60 was closed from Gilman Springs Road to Jack Rabbit Trail and all trapped motorists were evacuated. No structured were damaged, but four hand crew members were treated for smoke inhalation, while battling the fire.  The cause of the fire is unknown.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Onion Wildfire was started by lightning on 08/19/2011.  By the time it was contained around 09/10/2011, it had burned 560 acres.  No fire fighting cost estimates were available.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Onion Wildfire was started by lightning on 08/19/2011.  By the time it was contained around 09/10/2011, it had burned 560 acres.  No fire fighting cost estimates were available.

The Ken fire started around 1200 PST on August 22, on the northbound side of I-15 just north of the Kenwood exit near Lytle Creek. Lane closures of I-15 were required for most of the day on the 22nd and finally reopened around 1200 PST on the 23rd. During its 300 acre burn, the Ken fire knocked down a power pole, one home, 2 shipping containers and 3 outbuildings (sheds) at Matthews Ranch. Two US Forest Service firefighters suffered injuries, one knee and one heat-related. The cause of the fire is unknown. The fire was fully contained around 1700 PST on the 24th.

The motor wildfire occurred in Sierra National Forest. The ignition date was August 25 at 1207 PDT. The cause of the fire was human - a motor home fire along Highway 140. The location was near El Portal in Mariposa County. The size was 5231 acres. Containment was reached on September 4 at 1800 PDT. There were no fatalities or lost structures and the cost to containment was $8,385,000.

The Oasis fire started around 1244 PST on August 27 off Oasis Road south of Highway 138 and Pinion Hills, near the LA/San Bernardino County line. The fire, sparked by lightning from a nearby thunderstorm, burned though a total of 355 acres before it was finally contained around 1730 PST on the 30th. Three firefighters were treated for minor injuries while fighting the blaze. No damage was reported with this fire.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Onion Wildfire was started by lightning on 08/19/2011.  By the time it was contained around 09/10/2011, it had burned 560 acres.  No fire fighting cost estimates were available.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Onion Wildfire was started by lightning on 08/19/2011.  By the time it was contained around 09/10/2011, it had burned 560 acres.  No fire fighting cost estimates were available.

The Hill fire started around 1143 PST on the 2nd, south of Oak Hills in the Cajon Pass. During the firefight, a mandatory evacuation of 1500 residents was ordered for the triangular area south of Joshua Road, from I-15 to west of Baldy Mesa Road. Evacuation order was lifted at 1300 PST on the 3rd. One firefighter was evacuated out for a medical emergency and another suffered heat exhaustion. One home was heavily damaged and two mobile homes and two outbuildings were destroyed on the 2nd. The fire burned a total of 1,158 acres before being fully contained around 1630 PST on the 4th.

The Canyon wildfire was caused by lightning and occurred on 9/4/11 at 1132 PDT. The location was 5 miles Southeast of Tehachapi in Kern County. The size was 14,585 acres. Containment was reached on 9/10/11. There were no fatalities. There were 32 primary structures lost and 68 outbuildings. The cost to containment was $10 million.

A dry southwest flow aloft set up over the area on the 6th along the leading edge of a upper level trough over the Pacific Northwest and northern California, bringing dry weather through the 8th. However, an upper level low moved from the Great Basin into central California on the 9th. This atypical movement of the low occurred because it was cut off from the prevailing westerly winds aloft. These systems usually move into the area from the Pacific Ocean. This low changed the flow aloft over the region to southeasterly, drawing moisture into central California from Arizona and northwestern Mexico. This warm, unstable airmass brought showers and thunderstorms to much of interior central California from the 9th through the 14th. Isolated thunderstorms continued over the Sierra Nevada crest on the 15th, as residual moisture remained over the area while the southeasterly flow transitioned to a more southwesterly direction. ||The low meandered across central and southern California during these several days. This low allowed for unstable conditions over the entire district; quite a few locations in the San Joaquin Valley received at least a trace of rain. On the 9th, thunderstorms produced little rainfall, but they did cause quite a few wildfires due to lightning over the mountains in Kern County (around Keene, Breckenridge, and just to the east of Arvin and Bakersfield). As for the 10th, numerous thunderstorms developed over Kern County and much of the southern San Joaquin Valley during the evening. In addition, more wildfires developed over the Kern County mountains A severe thunderstorm warning and numerous significant weather advisories were issued throughout Kern County that evening; these storms moved westward into San Luis Obispo County later that night. Afternoon showers and thunderstorms redeveloped mainly over the Tehachapi Mountains and the Southern Sierra Nevada daily on the 11th, 12th, and 13th, and a few showers occurred over the south end of the San Joaquin Valley, including Bakersfield, on the 13th. Thunderstorms that developed over the Piutes during the afternoon of September 11th were nearly stationary, and runoff from these storms caused road flooding in the area south of Lake Isabella. ||The South Lightning Tennessee Fire occurred in Tulare county 5 miles north of Fountain Springs. Reports indicated that the fire began on 9/11/11 at 1200 PDT due to heavy lightning strikes from thunderstorms. ||The Tamarack wildfire occurred just northeast of Yosemite Valley in Mariposa County on 9/13/11 at 1912 PDT. This wildfire was caused by extensive lightning. The size was 480 acres. The fire was contained on 10/6/11. There were no lost fatalities or structures. Cost to containment was $75,000. ||The Breckenridge wildfire Complex occurred in the Kern County Mountains, 10 miles NE of Bakersfield. The fire started on the 10th and was contained on the 17th, and caused by lightning strikes. The size was a whopping 25,213 acres. There were no fatalities or structures lost. The cost to containment was $7.1 million. ||The Comanche wildfire Complex in Kern County mountains occurred on 9/10/11 at  0400 PDT, about 8 miles Southeast of Arvin, caused by lightning. The size was a whopping 29,338 acres. Containment was reached on 9/16/11. There were no fatalities or lost structures. The cost to containment was $6.8 million. ||The Keene wildfire Complex occurred because on lightning on 9/10/11 at 1200 PDT. The location was along the Highway 58 corridor from Keene to Mojave in Kern County. The size was 10,479 acres. Containment was reached on 9/15/11. There were no fatalities or Structures Lost. The cost to containment was $8,839,174.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The John Fire burned 5,353 acres, but no structures.  Two firefighters were injured during the fire.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving upper level low and monsoon moisture fueled thunderstorms over the Mojave Desert.  Many storms produced flash flooding and severe weather.
