The Windy Point fire started around 1753 PST on the 24th, west of the Palm Springs Tramway in steep, rocky terrain. During the firefight, State Highway 111 was closed in both directions. The fire burned 541 acres before being fully contained around 1700 PST on the 26th. At no time were any structures damaged or threatened and despite the rocky terrain, no injuries occurred.

The Great fire started around 1153 PST on the 1st, on the south side of Highway 78 at Scissors Crossing, near Shelter Valley. During the firefight, Highway 78 between San Felipe Rd in Scissors Crossing and Wynola Rd was closed. Only one firefighter sustained minor injuries and no structures or homes were threatened or damaged. The fire burned a total of 2,135 acres before being fully contained around 0600 PST on the 6th.

A pickup truck drove off of Highway 18 near Crestline on the 12th and burst into flames. The fire eventually spread to 15 acres with around 400 firefighters battling the flames. The driver of the truck had only minor injuries, but one firefighter suffered a broken ankle while fighting the fire. No homes were threatened, but Highway 18 was closed through the following day. At the time the fire broke out, the Crestline Ridge RAWS was reporting sustained NNW winds 25 to 35 mph with frequent gusts to 45 mph, making for very difficult working conditions.

The Banner fire started around 1315 PST on the 24th, near the intersection of Highway 78 and S-2, east of Julian near Shelter Valley. No structures or homes were damaged or destroyed, but at one point, 50 residences and one commercial building were threatened. Three firefighters were also injured during the incident, although details of those injuries are unknown. The fire burned a total of 5,321 acres before being fully contained on the 28th.

The George wildfire occurred in the Sequoia National Forest. The Ignition date was  6/1/12 at 1539 PDT. The cause was unknown. The location was 28 miles east of Porterville in Tulare County in the Southern Sierra. The size was 1707 acres. Containment was reached on  6/15/12. There were no fatalities or structures lost. The cost was $6,100,000.

The Gaines wildfire occurred in the CalFire Merced-Madera-Mariposa Unit. The ignition date was 6/12/12 at 1243 PDT. The cause was unknown. The location was in Catheys Valley, Mariposa County, in the Southern Sierra foothills. The size was 1667 acres. Containment was reached on  6/14/12 at 1800 PDT. There were no fatalities or structures lost and the cost was $600,000.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Highland fire started around 1220 PST on the 16th, near the intersection of Potrero Road and Wolfskill Extension Truck Trail, near Beaumont. No structures or homes were threatened or evacuated. No injuries were reported. The fire burned a total of 2,171  acres before being fully contained at 1700 PST on the 18th. The cause of the fire is unknown and under investigation.

The Old fire started around 1300 PST on the 17th, northeast of Campo off of Old Highway 80. Approximately 200 structures were threatened and evacuated. One residence and one RV were destroyed in the blaze. Eastbound Highway 94 was closed at Church Road and Old Highway 80 was closed at Crestwood and Live Oak Springs. The fire burned a total of 995 acres before being fully contained on the 19th. There were 2 reported fire fighter injuries.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The View fire started around 2015 PST on the 17th, at the intersection of Desert View and Cottonwood Roads, near the city of Cabazon. No structures or homes were damaged or destroyed. No injuries were reported. Fifteen families within the community were evacuated, but no evacuation shelter was needed. The fire burned a total of 376 acres before being fully contained at 1700 PST on the 18th.

The Woods Creek wildfire occurred in Sequoia/Kings Canyon NP. Ignition date was  7/15/12 at 0928 PDT.  The cause was Unknown.  The location was 8 miles ENE of Roads End in Cedar Grove (Fresno County).  The size was 325 acres.  Containment was reached on 7/23/12.  There were no fatalities or lost structures.  Cost to containment was $2,740,000.

The Sand wildfire was manages by the Kern County Fire Department.  Ignition date was  7/17/12 at 1254 PDT.  It was caused by humans.  The location was Highway 58 East of Tehachapi (Kern County).  The size was 1428 acres.  Containment was reached  7/19/12 at 1800 PDT.  There were no fatalities.  Two structures on a family farm were destroyed, as was a beloved cultural landmark, locally known as SS Minnow, which was on display along Highway 58 just east of Tehachapi.

The Cascade wildfire occurred in Yosemite NP.  The ignition date was  6/15/12 at 1300 PDT. The cause was lightning. The location was in Yosemite Valley (Mariposa County). The size was 1115 acres.  There were no fatalities and no structures lost.  The cost to containment was $75,000.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Volcano fire started around 1045 PST on the 1st, near the intersection of Tenaja Road and Via Volcano, in La Cresta (near Murrieta). Voluntary evacuations were in place for residents in the area at a local high school. One unidentified structure was destroyed. Three firefighters received minor injuries; one was transported by paramedics for treatment. The fire burned a total of 350 acres before being fully contained around 0700 PST on the 2nd. The cause of the fire was determined to be motorized equipment used to clear brush.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Fort Complex wildfire was started by lightning on 08/05/12.  It consisted of four fires, the largest and longest lasting of which was the Goff fire.   It was still burning and growing at the end of the month.  By that time it burned 19,474 acres and $15.8 million was spent on wildfire fighting efforts.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Fort Complex, made up of several fires, the largest and longest lasting of which was the Goff fire.   The fires were started by lightning on 08/05/12, and the Goff fire was still burning and growing at the end of the month.

The Chihuahua fire was started by lightning around 1213 PST on the 9th, along Chihuahua Valley Road near Sunshine Summit, northwest of Warner Springs. There were 250 residences and 100 other structures threatened by the fire, leading to mandatory evacuations of the residences and a Boy Scout camp along Chihuahua Valley Road. A hard closure was in place on Chihuahua Valley Road at Highway 79. No structures were destroyed, but two firefighters received unknown injuries. The fire burned a total of 2007 acres before being fully contained around 1730 PST on the 12th.

The Vallecito Lightning Complex was started by lightning around 1900 PST on the 12th. This complex was composed of 3 larger fires greater than 500 acres and 3 smaller fires of 5 acres or less. The Vallecito Fire burned 519 acres just southeast of Julian. The Stewart Fire burned 10,632 acres near Scissors Crossing northeast of Julian. The Wilson Fire burned 11,669 acres, also near Scissors Crossing northeast of Julian. The Cooper, Wynola and Shoots Fires, together, burned around 7 acres. Evacuations were in place for these areas. No structures were destroyed, but 4 firefighters received unknown injuries. All fires were reported 100% contained on the 19th around 0530 PST after burning a grand total of 22,828 acres in eastern San Diego County.

The Buck fire started around 1156 PST on the 14th due to lightning, along Sage Road between Lewis Valley Road and Buck Road near the town of Sage in Riverside County. Voluntary evacuations were in place. Four residences were destroyed. Five firefighters received minor injuries and one civilian received burn injuries. The fire burned a total of 2681 acres before being fully controlled around 0700 PST on the 20th.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Vista fire started around 1052 PST on the 20th, along Vista Road at Rawson Road in Winchester in Riverside County. No evacuations were needed and no structures were threatened or destroyed. Two firefighters received minor injuries. The fire burned a total of 500 acres before being fully controlled around 1900 PST on the 20th (same day). The cause of the fire was determined to be a flare used to kill small animals, called a Gopher Gasser.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Antelope wildfire was started by lightning on 08/21/12.  It was contained by 08/28/12.  It burned 650 acres and $715000 was spent on wildfire fighting efforts.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Antelope wildfire was started by lightning on 08/21/12.  It was contained by 08/28/12.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Fort Complex wildfire was started by lightning on 08/05/12. It consisted of four fires, the largest and longest lasting of which was the Goff fire. That fire was contained by 09/11/12. By that time it burned 23,653 acres and $28 million was spent on wildfire fighting efforts.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Fort Complex, made up of several fires, the largest and longest lasting of which was the Goff fire. The fires were started by lightning on 08/05/12, and the Goff fire was contained by 09/11/12.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Likely wildfire was started by human activities on 09/05/12. It was contained by 09/14/12. By that time it burned 9838 acres and $4.2 million was spent on wildfire fighting efforts.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Likely wildfire was started by human activities on 09/05/12.  It was contained by 09/15/12.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Canyon fire started around 1052 PST on the 6th as three separate fires, near the intersection of Lambs Canyon Road and Gilman Springs Road near Beaumont in Riverside County. One firefighter received minor fire-related injuries and was transported by paramedics for treatment. The fire burned a total of 3 acres before being fully contained around 1150 PST the same day. The cause of the fire is unknown. CHP closed the #2 lane on northbound Highway 79 for a time.

The Shockey fire started around 1114 PST on the 23rd, near the intersection of the Shockey Truck Trail and Highway 94, east of Campo in San Diego County. As the fire burned rapidly, approximately 25 structures were threatened. Two residences were damaged, 11 other residences destroyed along with 14 outbuildings and 11 vehicles. Mandatory evacuations were in place for approximately 125 residents in the communities of Tierra del Sol, Boulevard and Jewell Valley. Shelters were opened at Mountain Empire High School (animal sheltering as well) and the Campo Tribal Shelter. Three child care facilities voluntarily evacuated as well. Highway 94 was closed from the Shockey Truck Trail east to Jewell Valley and the Mexican border. Three firefighters received unknown injuries. A 69-year old male was found dead in his home due to burn injuries and smoke inhalation. The fire burned a total of 2556 acres before being fully contained around 1900 PST on the 26th. The fire started in an area where target shooting occurs, but the exact cause of the fire is still unknown.

A wildfire of unknown cause started at 1055 PST, Monday, Nov. 5, 2012 on the east side of Interstate 15, northeast of the I-15/215 merge, in the Pitman Canyon area. The fire initially burned downwind/downhill in a south southeast direction. A spot fire started on the west side of the freeway and rapidly burned uphill. The Matthews Ranch area was evacuated. No homes were damaged, but a shipping container was destroyed, along with some of the guardrails along I-15. Interstate 15, between the Cajon Pass and the I-15/I-215 merge was closed in both directions all afternoon, reopening on the 6th, except for the slow lanes which remained closed for guardrail repair. Two firefighters sustained unknown injuries while battling the blaze. The fire burned 375 acres before being fully contained at 1830 PST on the 6th.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire (cause still under investigation) started at 1643 PST, February 28 in the Santa Ana River bottom, burning heavy fuels near the intersection of Rio Road and Calle Hermosa in Jurupa Valley. Voluntary evacuation were in effect on Greenbrier Drive and Grassy Trail in the city of Riverside. There were no injuries, but one structure and one outbuilding were damaged. Power lines were also reported down in the river bottom area. The fire burned 311 acres before being fully contained at 1800 PST on March 3rd.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds knocked down power lines in the hills of Napa County which started several wildfires. This included a 75 acre fire near Yountville that destroyed a barn and a 20 acre fire near Soda Springs that burned a historic slaughterhouse on a ranch. A larger fire, known as the Yellow Fire, burned near Knights Valley in Sonoma County and consumed over 125 acres.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Late on April 30 and into May 1, hot weather, followed by increasingly strong northeast winds which gusted up to 60 MPH in the North Bay Hills, lead to critical fire weather conditions. Powerlines were felled by the strong winds and this helped contribute to several fires in Napa County.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Summit fire started near N. San Gorgonio Avenue and Summit Drive in Banning (Riverside County) around 1138 PST on the 1st. The brush fire burned rapidly toward the northwest, driven by Santa Ana winds of 30-40 mph, destroying one residence and one out building. The fire threatened 450 homes in and around Cherry Valley, CA. Mandatory evacuations were in place for approximately 750 people there. Two firefighters received unknown injuries. The fire burned a total of 3166 acres before being fully contained around 1700 PST on the 4th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Springs Fire burned 24,251 acres of land across southeastern Ventura county. The wildfire was fueled by abnormally dry vegetation, strong northeast winds and very low relative humidity (less than 5%). Six commercial properties were damaged and 10 firefighter injuries were reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong northeast Santa Ana winds developed across the mountains and inland valleys of Ventura and Los Angeles counties. Wind gusts as high as 74 MPH were reported. In Ventura county, the Santa Ana winds combined with hot and very dry conditions to help spread the Springs Fire which scorched over 24,000 acres.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Springs Fire burned 24,251 acres of land across southeastern Ventura county. The wildfire was fueled by abnormally dry vegetation, strong northeast winds and very low relative humidity (less than 5%). Six commercial properties were damaged and 10 firefighter injuries were reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong northeast Santa Ana winds developed across the mountains and inland valleys of Ventura and Los Angeles counties. Wind gusts as high as 74 MPH were reported. In Ventura county, the Santa Ana winds combined with hot and very dry conditions to help spread the Springs Fire which scorched over 24,000 acres.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Van Buren wildfire started around 0724 PST on the 2nd in the median of Van Buren Boulevard at Jurupa Road in Jurupa Valley (Riverside County). Jurupa Rd was closed from Van Buren to Rutile and Van Buren closed from Jurupa to Rutile. Evacuations were ordered for a few hours. The fire burned 12 acres, but destroyed two homes, an RV and 5 out buildings, with damage to two additional residences. No injuries were reported. The fire was fully contained around 1330 PST on the 2nd. The cause of the fire is likely a discarded cigarette.

CZ_NAME_STR: SANTA LUCIA MOUNTAINS AND LOS PADRES NATIONAL FOREST (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large fire in the Stony Valley section of Ft. Hunter Liggett burned about 600 acres before being contained by base fire personnel. The blaze resulted in intermittent closures of Nacimiento-Fergusson Road.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Ongoing critical fire weather conditions across the area continued in May, with a large fire burning on Ft. Hunter Liggett.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Grand Fire burned 4,346 acres of land in far northern Ventura county, just west-southwest of the community of Gorman. The combination of persistent and gusty northwesterly winds and very dry fuels helped the fire to spread.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Grand Fire burned 4,346 acres in mid-may with a good chunk of the burned acreage in northern Ventura County, just west-southwest of Gorman. Persistent and gusty northwesterly winds helped to spread the fire.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Powerhouse Fire burned 30,274 acres of land across the Antelope Valley and mountains of Los Angeles county. The fire started on May 30th and burned into early June. The combination of strong onshore (southwesterly) flow and very dry fuels allowed for rapid fire spread.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Powerhouse Fire burned 30,274 acres in the Antelope Valley as well as the Los Angeles county mountains. The fire started in late May and continued into early June.

CZ_NAME_STR: LOS ANGELES COUNTY MOUNTAINS EXCLUDING THE SANTA MONICA RANGE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Powerhouse Fire burned 30,274 acres of land across the Antelope Valley and mountains of Los Angeles county. The fire started on May 30th and burned into early June. The combination of strong onshore (southwesterly) flow and very dry fuels allowed for rapid fire spread.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Powerhouse Fire burned 30,274 acres in the Antelope Valley as well as the Los Angeles county mountains. The fire started in late May and continued into early June.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Powerhouse Fire burned 30,274 acres of land across the Antelope Valley and mountains of Los Angeles county. The fire, which started on May 30th, was driven by the combination of very dry fuels and gusty onshore (southwesterly) winds. The fire was eventually declared contained on June 12th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Powerhouse Fire burned 30,274 acres of land across the Antelope Valley and the mountains of Los Angeles county. The fire, which started on May 30th, was driven by the combination of gusty onshore (southwesterly) winds and very dry fuels.

CZ_NAME_STR: LOS ANGELES COUNTY MOUNTAINS EXCLUDING THE SANTA MONICA RANGE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Powerhouse Fire burned 30,274 acres of land across the Antelope Valley and mountains of Los Angeles county. The fire, which started on May 30th, was driven by the combination of very dry fuels and gusty onshore (southwesterly) winds. The fire was eventually declared contained on June 12th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Powerhouse Fire burned 30,274 acres of land across the Antelope Valley and the mountains of Los Angeles county. The fire, which started on May 30th, was driven by the combination of gusty onshore (southwesterly) winds and very dry fuels.

The Hathaway Fire, cause unknown, started at 1057 PST, June 9, east of Hathaway Canyon on the northern portion of the Morongo Indian Reservation. It burned in very steep, rugged terrain in the San Gorgonio Wilderness. No evacuations or road closures were in effect and no damage was reported. Ten unknown injuries were reported. The fire burned 3825 acres before being fully contained around 0600 PST on June 20.

The Carstens Wildfire was in the Sierra NF.  The ignition date was 6/16 and the cause was human - unattended campfire.  The location was 1 Mile North of Mid Pines (Mariposa County) and the size was 1708 acres.  Containment was reached on 6/26 and the cost to containment was $9.8 million.

A wildfire of unknown cause started at 1330 PST, June 20, south of Highway 38 & Bryant Street, west of Yucaipa in San Bernardino County. The fire started above the Mill Creek Wash near Mentone and burned through grass and small brush in the draws and canyons near Highway 38. Evacuations were ordered for 20-30 homes in the city of Yucaipa along Highway 38. The fire burned several fences and trash cans and partially damaged one home. State Route 38 was closed at Bryant, with only fire department vehicles allowed through. All residents had to have proper identification in order to get through the area. No injuries were reported. The fire burned 534 acres before being fully contained around 0600 PST on the July 1st.

The Chariot Fire started around 1155 PST on July 6, near Chariot Canyon Road at Oriflamme Canyon Road in Vallecito, San Diego County. The location is east of Sunrise Highway and about 9 miles southeast of Julian. The rugged terrain and poor access hindered control efforts. The cause of the fire is still unknown. Laguna, El Prado, Fosters and Horsehaven Campgrounds were evacuated of an unknown number of campers. Twenty campers were evacuated from Shriners Camp to a shelter in Alpine.  Sunrise Highway/County Road 1 was closed from SR-79 to Old Highway 80. The fire threatened 120 residential structures and destroyed 118 structures, of undetermined type, plus 2 commercial buildings. The communication site on Monument Peak, as well as other nearby campgrounds in the Cleveland National Forest were threatened as well. Approximately 7 firefighters sustained unknown injuries. The fire burned 7,055 acres before being fully contained around 1700 PST on July 15.

The Mountain Fire started around 1243 PST on July 15, near the junction of Highway 243 and Highway 74. It burned east of Mountain Center, through the Apple Canyon and Bonita Vista areas, and then along the Desert Divide and southern portion of the San Jacinto Wilderness. CAL FIRE Investigators have determined the cause of the Mountain Fire to be an electrical equipment failure on private property. Mandatory evacuations were ordered for the Idyllwild and Fern Valley areas, including the San Jacinto State Park Wilderness, Forest Service Wilderness and Forest Service campgrounds. Other evacuations include the Trails End Community at the top of Morris Ranch Road, the Andreas Canyon Club, south of Palm Canyon Drive in Palm Springs, Bonita Vista, Pine Springs and the Zen Mountain Center off Apple Canyon Road. Portions of Highways 74 and 243 were closed in this area. Several trails and campgrounds were closed as well. The Palm Springs Tram was shut down for the duration of the fire. The fire destroyed 3 mobile homes and 3 residences and damaged one other residence in Bonita Vista. In Pine Springs, 1 commercial building, a workshop, garage and cabin were destroyed. In addition, 11 other outbuildings and 4-6 vehicles were destroyed. Any possible injuries are unknown. The fire burned 27,531 acres before being fully contained around 1700 PST on July 30th.

The Rancho Widlfire was in the Kern County Mountains and managed by the Kern Fire Department.  The ignition was 7/19 and the cause was known. The location was 2 Miles North of Lebec (Kern County) and the size was 712 acres.  Containment was reached on 7/22 and the cost to containment was $1.4 million.

The Water wildfire was ignited by human causes on 7/23 and the location was along I-5 southbound 3 Miles North of Lebec (Kern County) and the dize was 612 acres.  Containment was reached on 7/25 and the cost to containment was $620,741.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Butler wildfire burned all month.  Initially it was part of the Orleans Complex. At the beginning of September, it was combined with the Forks Fire, becoming part of the Forks Complex.  At that time, the fire covered 21230 acres.  It was 45% contained and 27.2 million dollars had been expended on firefighting efforts.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This fire was human caused. It started around 10:30 PM on 07/31/2013.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Salmon Complex wildfire burned all month. It was renamed the Forks Complex at the beginning of September, and the Butler fire was included with it.  As of the end of August, the fire covered 14754 acres and was 100 percent contained.  22.4 million dollars were spent on firefighting efforts.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This fire was human caused.  It started around 10:30 PM on 07/31/2013.

The Aspen Fire was in the Sierra NF and the ignition was on 7/22/13.  The cause was lightning and the location was 7 Miles North-Northwest of Big Creek (Fresno County) and the size was 22,992 acres.  Containment was reached on 9/8/13 and the cost to containment was $32,289,100.

The Falls Fire started around 0900 PST on the 5th, off of the Ortega Highway near Decker Canyon, in Riverside. The cause of the fire is still unknown. Due to the fire burning on the Trabuco Ranger District, the San Mateo Wilderness, El Cariso Campground, Blue Jay Campground, the Firefighter Memorial Picnic Area and Wildomar OHV area were closed. Road closures included the Ortega Hwy 74 from Lake Elsinore west to San Antonio Parkway. Intermittent road openings were allowed to residents only. Evacuations were ordered for Lakeland Village, Rancho Capistrano and Decker Canyon residents. Evacuation perimeter is between Grand/Ortega and Grand/Corydon. No structures were threatened and no injuries. Minor guardrail damage occurred as a result of a rock fall along the Ortega Highway. The fire burned 1416 acres before being fully contained around 1700 PST on the 9th.

The Silver Fire started due to lightning around 1305 PST on the 7th, along Poppet Flats Road near Hwy 243, south of Banning in Riverside County, with a critical rate of spread. Strong Banning pass breezes forced extreme growth according to fire personnel and smoke reduced visibility into Palm Springs on the first day. Mandatory evacuations for the communities of Poppet Flats, Twin Pines and Silent Valley. Evacuation warnings/voluntary were also issued for Diamond Zen Center, Pine Cove & Camp Azalea. Residents were instructed to evacuate through Hwy 243, south through Hwy 74 in Idyllwild to Hemet. Forty-seven people from the Twin Pines Ranch (Boys Youth Camp) were escorted down the mountain. The fire eventually split into two directions, moving into Poppet Flats, Silent Valley Club, Twin Pines and Cabazon, prompting mandatory evacuations to be expanded to the lower Cabazon area-Peach Street, Plum Street, Eucalyptus Street, and Riza Avenue, Ida Avenue, Helen Avenue East to Elm Street. Repeater sites, containing equipment for Department of Transportation, Department of Parks and Recreation, Cal Fire, CHP and Riverside County Fire, at Mt. Edna and Vista Grande were in the path of the fire. Black Mountain was evacuated and closed as a precaution. Boulder Basin and Black Mountain campgrounds on Black Mountain road were closed through august 15th.  Highway 243 was closed from 10.3 miles west to 1.5 miles west of Banning. 537 residences were threatened, 2 damaged and 26 destroyed, along with one commercial building and 21 outbuildings. Injuries to 12 firefighters and one civilian were reported. The fire burned 20,292 acres before being fully contained around 1840 PST on the 12th. This fire also had high media coverage, including national.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Rim Fire was a wildfire that started on August 17th at around 3:15pm PDT in Tuolumne County. It was located in the Groveland Range District of Stanislaus National Forest. The fire grew to be the 3rd largest wildfire in California's history, at 257,314 acres. For the TOTAL FIRE EVENT: It cost approximately $127.2 million, caused 10 injuries, burned 11 residences, 3 commercial properties, and 98 outbuildings. For the month of AUGUST ONLY: 222,777 acres, $60 million, 5 injuries, 11 residences, 3 commercial properties, and 97 outbuildings.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Rim Fire was a wildfire that began in the Groveland Range District of the Stanislaus National Forest on August 17th.

The Shirley wildfire occurred in the Sequoia NF and the ignition occured on 8/18/13 due to lightning strikes. The location was Democrat and Alta Sierra (Kern County).  The size was 794 acres and containment was reached on 8/22/13.  The cost to containment was $1.9 Million.

The Tenant wildfire was in the Sequoia NF and the ignition date was 8/18 caused by lightning.  The location was near Democrat (Kern County) and the size was 411 acres.  Containment was reached on 8/22 and the cost to containment was $950,000.

The Gobblers Fire started around 1336 PST on the 19th, burning in steep, inaccessible terrain west of Gobblers Knob, near Stockton Flats at the upper end of Lytle Creek. The Gobblers Fire began as a result of thunderstorms and lightning that started over twenty fires on the San Bernardino National Forest. The steep terrain and fuels involved created roll-out (burning debris rolling downhill), which helped spread the fire. Closures of the fire area and roads into the fire include Stockton Flats, Coldwater Canyon and Paiute Canyon yellow-post sites, Forest Road 3N06 above the shooting range, and Forest Road 3N33 closed at the 3N31 junction. No structures were threatened or destroyed and no injuries reported. The fire burned 413 acres before being fully contained on the 26th.

CZ_NAME_STR: SANTA LUCIA MOUNTAINS AND LOS PADRES NATIONAL FOREST (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Mission Wildfire broke out on Fort Hunter Liggett on August 22 and quickly grew to consume 4500 acres. One private home was threatened but not destroyed. The fire was contained on August 26.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: August represented another dry month across the area. Fuel moisture continued to run near all time record low values and this contributed to rapid fire growth for several small fires across the area. The Mission Wildfire, on the grounds of Fort Hunter Liggett, was the most substantial fire.

The Fish widlfire was in the Sequoia NF and the ignition date was 8/23/13.  The cause was lightning and the location was 25 Miles Northeast of Springville (Tulare County). The size was 2060 acres and containment was reached on 9/5/13.  The cost to containment was $4.52 Million.

The Windy Peak wildfire was in Sequoia-Kings Canyon NP and the ignition was 8/23/13 and the cause was from lightning strikes.  The location was 14 Miles North of Cedar Grove (Fresno County).  The size was 681 acres and containment was finally reached on 10/20/13.  The cost to containment was $80,000.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The last report on the Forks Complex stated that it was 37246 acres in size and was 90% contained.  The estimated containment date was 10/1/13, and 59.8 million dollars was expended in fire fighting efforts.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This fire was human caused. It started around 10:30 PM on 07/31/2013. At the beginning of September, the Forks fire (formerly part of the Salmon Complex) was grouped with the Butler Fire (formerly part of the Orleans Complex).  The new grouping was named the Forks Complex.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Rim Fire was a wildfire that started on August 17th at around 3:15pm PDT in Tuolumne County. It was located in the Groveland Range District of Stanislaus National Forest. The fire grew to be the 3rd largest wildfire in California's history, at 257,314 acres. For the TOTAL FIRE EVENT: It cost approximately $127.2 million, caused 10 injuries, burned 11 residences, 3 commercial properties, and 98 outbuildings. For the month of SEPTEMBER ONLY: 34,358 more acres, additional $65.8 million, 5 additional injuries, 0 new residences, 0 new commercial properties, and 1 new outbuildings.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Rim Fire was a wildfire that began in the Groveland Range District of the Stanislaus National Forest on August 17th.

The Rim Fire was partly in Stanislaus NF and Partly in Yosemite National Park. The ignition date was 8/17/13 at 1525 PDT.  The cause was human and the location was 2 Miles Northeast of Buck Meadows.  The size was 257,135 acres and containment was reached on 10/6/13 (92% contained as of 9/30/13).  Structures Lost: 97 Outbuildings, 11 Primary, 3 Commercial and the cost to containment was $126.3 Million as of 9/30/13.  There were no fatalities and known injuries related to the fire.  The Rim Fire was the largest wildfire ever on record in the California Sierra Nevada and the 3rd largest in California history.

Angora wildfire was in Sequoia NF and the ignition date was 9/8/13. The cause was lightning and the location was 20 miles NE of Springville (Tulare County).  The size was 134 acres.  Containment was reached on 9/13/13.  Cost to containment was $915,233.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Clover Fire developed in the community of Igo, 10 miles southwest of Redding, and forced many people to evacuate their homes. The fire grew to 8,073 acres, killed one 56-year old male who chose not to evacuate his home, and injured six people. The fire destroyed 68 residences and 128 outbuildings, and it damaged 5 additional residences and 10 outbuildings. Cost of the fire is unknown.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Clover Fire began in the CAL FIRE Shasta-Trinity Unit in Shasta County, in the community of Igo, CA.

The Sierra fire started around 1459 PST on the 24th along the Northbound I-15 and Sierra, near Glen Helen in San Bernardino County. Mandatory evacuations were ordered from Glen Helen to Swarthout Canyon Road west of I-15 with 75 residences affected. No structured were damaged in this incident. The fire burned 200 acres before being fully contained around 1400 PST on the 27th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Rim Fire was a wildfire that started on August 17th at around 3:15pm PDT in Tuolumne County. It was located in the Groveland Range District of Stanislaus National Forest. The fire grew to be the 3rd largest wildfire in California's history, at 257,314 acres. For the TOTAL FIRE EVENT: It cost approximately $127.2 million, caused 10 injuries, burned 11 residences, 3 commercial properties, and 98 outbuildings. For the month of OCTOBER ONLY: approximately 179 more acres, additional $1.4 million, 0 additional injuries, 0 new residences, 0 new commercial properties, and 0 new outbuildings.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Rim Fire was a wildfire that began in the Groveland Range District of the Stanislaus National Forest on August 17th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Downed power lines ignited a wild fire along Berryessa Knoxville Road in Napa County on the north side of Lake Berryessa. The fire spread quickly due to 40-50 MPH wind and consumed over 400 acres but was contained by early afternoon. No structures were damaged or destroyed.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds moved through the area during the early morning hours of Friday, October 4. Winds gusted high enoguh to down trees and powerlines, causing several wildfires to ignite and spread quickly.

The De Luz fire began on October 5th around 2015 PST near the intersection of Vandergrift Road and Ammunition Road, ONeill Lake on the Camp Pendleton Marine base. There were 100 residences and one commercial structure threatened, but only one outbuilding damaged. The on-base medical facility, as well as the De Luz and O'Neill base housing, was evacuated. The fire burned 2236 acres before being fully contained on October 8th around 1700 PST.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind blowing down powerlines started the silverado fire near the intersection of Silverado Trail and Soda Canyon Road north of Napa. Approximately 300 acres were consumed with mandatory evacuations.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds gusted across the greater Bay Area during the evening and overnight hours of November 21 into the early morning of November 22. Numerous trees and power lines were knocked down by the winds, causing power outages for thousands of residents and even sparking wildfires across the North Bay.

CZ_NAME_STR: SOUTHERN MONTEREY BAY AND BIG SUR COAST (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Pfeiffer Fire started on December 17th 2013 around midnight in the vicinity of Pfeiffer Ridge in the Monterey Ranger District of Los Padres National Forest. The fire burned 917 acres. Thirty four (34) residence and 4 outbuildings were damaged/destroyed. The fire was declared contained on December 20 2013 at 6:00 p.m.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Pfeiffer Fire started on December 17th 2013 around midnight in the vicinity of Pfeiffer Ridge in the Monterey Ranger District of Los Padres National Forest. The fire burned 917 acres. Thirty four (34) residence and 4 outbuildings were damaged/destroyed. The fire was declared contained on December 20 2013 at 6:00 p.m.

The Soda Wildfire was in Sequoia NF.  Ignition date was 1/13/14 and the cause was known.  Location was 20 miles E of Springville (Tulare County) and the size was 1274 acres.  Containment was likely reached when the fire received 9 inches of snow on Jan 30-31.  Cost to containment was $168,000.

CZ_NAME_STR: LOS ANGELES COUNTY MOUNTAINS EXCLUDING THE SANTA MONICA RANGE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Colby Wildfire burned 1,952 acres of land in the hills above the San Gabriel Valley. The fire was started by an illegal campfire and it destroyed 5 homes.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Colby Wildfire started in the hills above the San Gabriel Valley. The fire was fueled by the combination of an extended period of dry, northeast winds and very dry vegetation. The fire destroyed 5 homes and burned 1,952 acres.

CZ_NAME_STR: LOS ANGELES COUNTY SAN GABRIEL VALLEY (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Colby Wildfire burned 1,952 acres of land in the hills above the San Gabriel Valley. The fire was started by an illegal campfire and it destroyed 5 homes.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Colby Wildfire started in the hills above the San Gabriel Valley. The fire was fueled by the combination of an extended period of dry, northeast winds and very dry vegetation. The fire destroyed 5 homes and burned 1,952 acres.

The Pierce Fire began around 1537 PST on the 15th near the intersection of Avenue 66 and Pierce Street in Thermal. Initially reported at 10 acres, the fire burned at a moderate rate of spread through medium to heavy brush, increasing rapidly to 200 acres over just a few hours. Road closures were in effect along north and southbound Highway 86 between Avenue 86 and Avenue 80, as well as Avenue 66 from Avenue 86 to Pierce Street. The fire burned a total of 350 acres before being fully contained at 2234 PST on the 15th. The fire downed power lines in the area and destroyed one outbuilding. No injuries to firefighters or civilians were reported.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Etiwanda fire began on April 30th around 0700 PST in the San Bernardino National Forest near Rancho Cucamonga in San Bernardino County. The fire was due to an escaped illegal campfire a few days prior, when strong winds blew embers that ignited in Day Canyon. A mandatory evacuation order was issued for Rancho Cucamonga residents from Haven Avenue to Carnelian Street, north of Hillside Road, as well as the area West of Etiwanda, North of Wilson and East of Day Creek Wash. Schools evacuated included Day Creek Intermediate School, Los Osos High School, Heritage Intermediate School and Caryn Elementary. The fire burned rapidly south, threatening 600-800 structures. 2143 acres before being fully contained on May 6. Three firefighters sustained unknown minor injuries and one structure was damaged.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Etiwanda fire began on April 30th around 0700 PST in the San Bernardino National Forest near Rancho Cucamonga in San Bernardino County. The fire was due to an escaped illegal campfire a few days prior, when strong winds blew embers that ignited in Day Canyon. A mandatory evacuation order was issued for Rancho Cucamonga residents from Haven Avenue to Carnelian Street, north of Hillside Road, as well as the area West of Etiwanda, North of Wilson and East of Day Creek Wash. Schools evacuated included Day Creek Intermediate School, Los Osos High School, Heritage Intermediate School and Caryn Elementary. The fire burned rapidly south, threatening 600-800 structures. 2143 acres before being fully contained on May 6. Three firefighters sustained unknown minor injuries and one structure was damaged.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Bernardo Fire started on May 13, at 10:00 AM PDT, just south of Del Norte High School, in a construction trench off Nighthawk Lane and Camino San Bernardo. Over the next few hours the wildfire intensified due to the strong Santa Ana winds driving it southward. This prompted the evacuation of several schools (with the exception of Del Norte High School), in addition to at least 20,000 homes. Within several hours, the fire covered at least 800 acres. The rapid southward spread of the fire caused mandatory evacuation orders to be issued for portions of 4S Ranch, Del Sur, Black Mountain Ranch, Rancho Santa Fe, and other residential communities. Late on May 13, the Bernardo Fire reached a size of 1,600 acres. By 2300 PST on the 13th, the portion of the fire within 4S Ranch and Del Sur had been completely extinguished. Later on the 14, all of the evacuation orders were lifted for that area. By the morning of the 15th, the fire was 75% contained and no longer expanding. On the 16th, the Bernardo Fire was reported to be 90% contained, but some structures were still threatened by the fire. The Bernardo Fire was reported 100% contained on the 17th at 1915 PST, burning a total of 1548 acres. The San Diego Unified School District closed all its schools citywide on May 15, but reopened most of them on May 16. The cause of the Bernardo Fire was ruled accidental; starting in a small trench being dug by a construction crew and spread rapidly through the dry brush at the site. In all, 50 structures were threatened, and 3 unknown injuries per Cal Fire.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Mid-May was marked by a period of very hot, dry and windy conditions. This included an unusually strong Santa Ana wind event with a 1036 mb surface high over the northern Great Basin. Wind speeds were as high as 40-45 mph in SW California and 60 to 80 mph in the foothills and mountains. Over the course of four days, 8 major fires raged across San Diego County due to various causes. Several other smaller brush fires, including the Freeway Fire (56 acres near Naval Weapons Station on Camp Pendleton). At one point on the 15th, 9 fires were burning at once, many in and around residential/populated areas of north San Diego County. In total, these fires burned just under 27,000 acres, causing over $50 million in property damage and the cost to fight the fires themselves. Only minor injuries were reported and no deaths directly attributed to the fires.

The Shirley wildfire started on May 13, 2014 and was contained on June 21, 2014. The fire was located 4 miles west of Wofford Heights in Kern County. It burned 2545 acres and 4 structures were lost. There were no fatalities. The cost of containment was $12.15 million.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Tomahawk Fire started on the 14th around 0845 PST on the Naval Weapons Station Seal Beach Detachment Fallbrook (also known as Fallbrook Naval Weapons Station). The Tomahawk Fire was the second largest of the San Diego County fires in terms of size, behind the Pulgas Fire. Evacuation orders were issued for several schools and housing areas, as well as the Fallbrook Naval Weapons Station and the closed San Onofre Nuclear Generating Station. During the evening of the 18th, the fire was reported to be 100% contained after burning a total of 5400 acres. No injuries reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Mid-May was marked by a period of very hot, dry and windy conditions. This included an unusually strong Santa Ana wind event with a 1036 mb surface high over the northern Great Basin. Wind speeds were as high as 40-45 mph in SW California and 60 to 80 mph in the foothills and mountains. Over the course of four days, 8 major fires raged across San Diego County due to various causes. Several other smaller brush fires, including the Freeway Fire (56 acres near Naval Weapons Station on Camp Pendleton). At one point on the 15th, 9 fires were burning at once, many in and around residential/populated areas of north San Diego County. In total, these fires burned just under 27,000 acres, causing over $50 million in property damage and the cost to fight the fires themselves. Only minor injuries were reported and no deaths directly attributed to the fires.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Poinsettia Fire started on the 14th, around 0930 PST, in the city of Carlsbad,  near the intersection of Poinsettia Lane and Alicante. After the fire burned through dry brush and crossed El Camino Real, evacuation orders were issued to 11,600 homes and businesses in Carlsbad, as well as two elementary schools and a middle school. By the end of the day on the 14th, the fire had destroyed eight homes, an 18-unit condominium complex, and two commercial buildings. Three other homes sustained minor damage. The Carlsbad Unified School District closed all schools May 15th and 16th. The Encinitas school district, which straddles Carlsbad, was closed both days as well. At 1600 PST on the 14th, the fire covered more than 400 acres, threatening additional structures. Early on the 16th, the fire had burned 400 acres and was 85% contained. As a result, all of the evacuation orders were lifted. The fire was reported to be 100% contained by 1600 PST on the 17th, after reaching a size of 600 acres. The Poinsettia Fire was the most destructive of the San Diego County wildfires. It caused property damage estimated at $22.5 million. As of July 10, 2014, the cause of the fire is still listed as undetermined. A body was also discovered in the fire damage near a transient encampment, but the cause of death has not been attributed to the fire.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The River Fire broke out at 1112 PST on the 14th, in Oceanside, starting in the San Luis Rey River riverbed. Homes and an elementary school in the area were evacuated. The Oceanside Unified School District closed all schools on the 15th. On the evening of the 16th, the fire was 100% contained, after it had burned 105 acres of land, confined to the river bed. A man was arrested on the 15th and charged with arson, after witnesses saw him adding brush to the flames, but authorities do not believe he started the fire. Official cause is still unknown.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Highway Fire, near Bonsall and Fallbrook, started at 1200 PST on the 14th near Interstate 15 and California State Route 76, near Old Highway 395 in the Deer Springs area. Several schools and about 600 residents were evacuated. Olive Hill Road was closed from Mission to Highway 76 due to wildfire, evacuating the Olive Hill area.  Highway 15 was also closed in both directions, along with old 395/Highway 76. By 1700 PST on the 15th, the fire was 100% contained, after burning 441 acres. No homes were damages or destroyed and no injuries reported. The heavy fuels in this area had not burned since the Gopher Canyon Fire in 1970. The cause of the fire is still under investigation.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Cocos Fire, previously known as the Twin Oaks Fire and later the Washingtonia Fire, was a wildfire that ignited around 1730 PST on the 14th in the hills south of California State University, San Marcos and burned 400 acres by later in the evening. Flames were reported near homes, and the southeastern part of the city was ordered evacuated. By the morning of the 15th, the Cocos Fire was the top priority for county firefighters. The Cocos Fire quickly spread into western Escondido with a big flare up near noon that day; then the sea breeze took replaced the Santa Ana, pushing the fire back toward the east with thick smoke on I-15 and additional evacuations in Escondido. It grew overnight to 800 acres and was only 5% contained. |Road closures/evacuations included:  Del Dios highway from Via Rancho Parkway to Rancho Drive, evacuating the Del Dios community; Mt. Israel Road, Harmony Grove Road from Elfin Forest to Kauana Loa Drive, Country Club Road to Kauana Loa Drive, Twin Oaks Road in San Marcos; San Elijo Hills evacuated as well. All schools in the San Marcos Unified School District were closed on the 15th and 16th. California State University, San Marcos, was evacuated on the 14th, along with the surrounding neighborhoods, in the midst of administering spring finals, and remained closed for the rest of the week. Additionally, commencement exercises scheduled for the weekend were also cancelled. Palomar College also closed the 15th and 16th, and postponed its commencement ceremonies until the following week.  At 1730 PST on the 22, the Cocos Fire was reported to be 100% contained after torching 1.995 acres. The fire destroyed more than 40 buildings, including 12 single family homes, and damaging at least 2 other homes. The Harmony Grove Spiritualist Association, a 13-acre spiritualist retreat founded in 1896, was particularly hard hit with most of the buildings and residences (22 structures) on the property destroyed. Property damage from the fire is estimated at more than $5.7 million. Three minor injuries have been reported. On July 9, the San Diego County Sheriff's Department said that they believe the Cocos Fire was intentionally set by a juvenile, who is now scheduled to appear in juvenile court.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Pulgas Fire broke out around 1345 PST on the 15th at Camp Pendleton near Interstate 5 at Las Pulgas Road, to the north of Oceanside. Las Pulgas Area personnel were ordered to evacuate to the School of Infantry Parade deck behind the mess hall. The fire burned 500 acres acres within the next couple of hours. It became the largest of the fires, burning a total of 15,000 acres before being fully contained on the afternoon of the 21st. Road closures included the Las Pulgas gate closed to all traffic except emergency vehicles, Stuart Mesa Road north of Assault Craft Unit-5, Basilone Road from Marine Corps Air Station Camp Pendleton to Camp Horno, as well as Las Pulgas Road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Combat or San Mateo Fire (previously known as the Talega Fire), started around 1024 PST on the 16th near the Camp Talega area of the base, near Basilone Road. By the mid-afternoon, the fire had burned about 25 acres. All non-essential personnel were ordered to be sent home. Evacuation orders were given to personnel in nearby areas of the base including some housing facilities and a school. By the 17th, the fire had grown to 800 acres and was 25% contained. Very late at night on the 20th, the San Mateo Fire was reported 100% contained after burning a total of 1500 acres. The cause of the wildfire is still under investigation. No injuries reported.

The Hunters wildfire was managed by CalFire.  Ignition was 5/26/14 and the cause was unknown. The location was 5 miles south of Coulterville, CA (Mariposa County) and the size was 677 acres.  Containment was reached on 6/2 and the cost to containment was $4.4 Million.  There were two residences lost and one outbuilding.  There were no fatalities and unknown injuries.

The Shirley wildfire started on May 13, 2014 and was contained on June 21, 2014. The fire was located 4 miles west of Wofford Heights in Kern County. It burned 2545 acres and 4 structures were lost. There were no fatalities. The cost of containment was $12.15 million.

The Ranch wildfire started on July 1, 2014 and was contained on July 19, 2014. The fire was located 5 miles west of Alta Sierra in Kern County. It burned 70 acres. There were no structures and no fatalities. The cost of containment was $5.9 million.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning and dry fuels combined on July 1st to form 15 fires that collectively made up the Modoc July Complex fire. The last report on this fire on 07/25/14 stated that the fire held at 1641 acres and was 100% contained. As of 07/06/14, 1.4 million dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.

The last report on this fire on 07/25/14 stated that the fire held at 1641 acres and was 100% contained. As of 07/06/14, 1.4 million dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.

The Banner Fire started around 0930 PST on July 3 in the Banner, California area, near Route 78 in San Diego County. It quickly spread westward and expanded to 150 acres, threatening the town of Julian. Portions of Route 78 were closed, and mandatory evacuation was ordered for 200 homes; however, the evacuation order was lifted later that evening, as the containment increased. Two homes were destroyed. On July 4, four injuries were reported. On July 6, at 0815 PST, the Banner Fire was 100% contained. However, the road closures still remained in effect through the day, as the firefighting crews continued to monitor the burn areas for potential flare-ups. The cause of the fire is still under investigation.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning and dry fuels combined on July 3rd to spark the Gulch fire. The last report on this fire on 07/09/14 stated that the fire held at 1469 acres and was 100% contained. As of 07/09/14, 1.6 million dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lightning and dry fuels combined on July 3rd to spark the Gulch fire. The last report on this fire on 07/09/14 stated that the fire held at 1469 acres and was 100% contained. As of 07/09/14, 1.6 million dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire broke out in the town of Collinsville around 2pm on July 4th, which destroyed 8 homes, damaged 3 more homes, burned boats and vehicles. The fire displaced 25 residents and caused an estimated 2.5 million dollars in damage. The cause of the fire was unknown, though the dry and windy conditions (20-25mph gusts) along with 4th of July celebrations may have been a factor.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry and warm weather conditions with gusty west-southwest winds of 10 to 20 mph gusts to 25mph helped to fan the flame of a fire in Collinsville, CA.

The Nicholls wildfire started on July 11, 2014 and was contained on July 19, 2014. The fire was located 26 miles west of Ridgecrest in Kern County. It burned 1680 acres. There were no structures were lost and no fatalities. The cost of containment was $7.0 million.

CZ_NAME_STR: MOUNTAINS SOUTHWEST SHASTA COUNTY TO NORTHERN LAKE COUNTY (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Bully Fire in Shasta County began on the afternoon of July 11th as weather conditions were becoming drier and warmer. The fire started near Plantina Road at Bland Road west of Igo and Ono communities, caused by a vehicle driving over dry vegetation. By the time it was contained, the fire grew 12,661 acres, destroyed 20 structures, injured 21 people, and resulted in 1 death. The fire was estimated to have resulted in approximately 20 million dollars in damage and fire suppression efforts.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warming trend developed Friday, July 11th and into the weekend from a warm high pressure system building westward over California. This resulted in temperatures in the 90s to low 100s with dry weather. Weather conditions combined with very dry fuels allowed the ignited Bully Fire to grow rapidly over several days.

The Dark Hole wildfire started on July 16, 2014 by lightning. It was being managed for resource benefit, but began being actively contained after the El Portal fire started nearby on July 26, 2014. It was fully contained on August 19, 2014. The fire was located 4 miles north of Yosemite Valley in Mariposa County. It burned 1080 acres. There were no structures lost and no fatalities. The cost of containment is unknown.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Sand Fire began east of Highway 49, 5 miles north of Plymouth (south of Placerville) on the afternoon of July 25th. The fire was caused by a vehicle driving into dry vegetation, and was considered a CalFire incident. The fire burned in both Amador and El Dorado Counties, reaching 4,240 acres by the time it was 100% contained on August 2nd. It burned 20 residences, and 47 outbuildings, and there were 2 injuries reported with the fire.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Building high pressure resulted in hot, above normal temperatures and generally light, dry northerly winds. Weather conditions combined with very dry fuels allowed Sand Fire incident to grow into 4,240 acres in Amador and El Dorado Counties.

The El Portal wildfire began July 26, 2014 and was contained on August 4, 2014, 1 mile east of El Portal in Mariposa County. The fire burned 4689 acres, of which 1092 acres were in Yosemite National Park and 3597 acres in Stanislaus National Forest. The cause is under investigation. There were 2 structures lost and no fatalities. Cost of containment was $10.6 million.

The French wildfire began July 28, 2014 and was contained on August 19, 2014, 18 miles east of Oakhurst in Madera County. The fire burned 13,837 acres. It was human caused.   There were no structures lost and no fatalities. Cost of containment was $21.4 million.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: This complex consists of several wildfires combined into one unit for management purposes.  The Whites, Leef, and Ray's Fire are all included here.  All of these wildfires were started by lightning on 07/29/2014, but many, if not all, of them were not fought until August.  The Man Fire, caused by lightning on 08/12/2014, is also included in this complex.  As of 09/01/14, the fires covered 40093 acres and was 77% contained. 42.4 million dollars were spent on firefighting efforts. Two structures were lost.

The Way fire began on August 18, 2014 and was contained on August 27, 2014. The fire was located 3 miles Northwest of Wofford Heights in Kern County. The fire burned 4,045 acres. The cause is under investigation. There were 12 structures lost and no fatalities. Cost of containment was $6.9 million.

The Junction wildfire started on August 18, 2014 and was contained on August 25, 2014. The fire was located 1 mile northwest of Oakhurst in Madera County. It burned 612 acres. There were 47 structures destroyed and 6 damaged. Many of the structures were outbuildings, motor homes and storage containers. There were no fatalities. The cost of containment was $4.9 million.
