The Bridge Fire was located 10 miles East of Mariposa in Mariposa County. It began on September 5, 2014 and grew to 300 acres before being contained on September 12, 2014. There were no fatalities, 3 injuries to fire fighters, and no structures lost. Cost of containment was $5.4 million.

The Meadow fire was located in Yosemite National Park, 5 miles East of Yosemite Valley, east of Half Dome in the Little Yosemite Valley. It was started by lightning on July 19, 2014, but was not discovered until August 15, 2014. The fire only grew to 10 acres and was being managed for resource objectives until September 7, 2014 when strong winds developed and began to rapidly spread the fire. The fire grew to 4772 acres before being contained on September 29, 2014. There were no fatalities and no structures lost. However, access to Half Dome was closed for several days. Cost of containment was $4.9 million.

The Silverado Fire began around 1009 PST on the 12th along Silverado Canyon Road in the Cleveland National Forest of the Santa Ana Mountains. The fire burned at a critical rate of spread, threatening power lines and forcing evacuations and road closures. Mandatory Evacuations ordered from 30331 Silverado Canyon east to the end of the road (fire gate), approx. 50 residences affecting approximately 220 people. The American Red Cross opened an evacuation center at 1530 at El Modena High School at 3920 East Spring Street. Orange, CA for residents who cannot return home. The Orange County Animal Care connected with residents and incident command for animal coordination. East of 30311 Silverado Canyon Road was closed. The 12kV line servicing Silverado residents was down. One pole and the downed lines needed to be replaced. There were 71 customers without power in Silverado Canyon. After burning a total of 1600 acres, the Silverado Fire was completely contained by 2000 PST on the 13th. Evacuation orders were lifted the following day.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The King Fire destroyed 12 residences and 68 other buildings. There were 10 firefighters injured, and 97,099 acres burned by the end of the month. Hundreds of residents were evacuated. The fire was caused by arson and was estimated to have cost more than 90 million dollars for fire suppression efforts.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire broke out near Pollock Pines around 6:37 pm on September 13th. Hot and dry conditions with southwest winds 10-20 mph caused rapid growth of the fire. The fire doubled in size to 114 square miles in a strong surge on September 17th. The fire was fully contained on October 9th.

The Courtney fire was located 3 miles East of Oakhurst in Madera County and burned toward the community of Bass Lake. The fire began on September 14, 2014 and burned 320 acres before being contained on September 22, 2014. The cause of the fire was under investigation, but is believed to be human caused. The fire resulted in evacuations of several hundred residents and visitors for several days. There were 30 residences, 19 outbuildings, 13 vehicles, and 4 recreational vehicles destroyed as well as 4 residences, 3 outbuildings and 2 vehicles damaged. Cost of containment was $4.4 million.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Boles fire started on the afternoon of 09/15/14 and spread quickly due to strong winds.  It  devastated the town of Weed in northern California.  In a matter of hours 222 structures were lost, including many homes and part of a lumber mill.  As of September 21st, the fire was 479 acres in size and was 100 percent contained.  6.2 million dollars were spent on firefighting efforts.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Boles fire started on the afternoon of 09/15/14 and spread quickly due to strong winds.  It  devastated the town of Weed in northern California.  In a matter of hours 222 structures were lost, including many homes and part of a lumber mill.  As of September 21st, the fire was 479 acres in size and was 100 percent contained.  6.2 million dollars were spent on firefighting efforts.

The Dog Rock fire started October 7, 2014. It was caused by sparks generated by hot metal fragments from a vehicle along highway 140 between El Portal and the entrance to Yosemite National Park. Highway 140 was closed in the vicinity of the fire, restricting entrance into Yosemite National Park for 5 days. The fire burned 311 acres before being contained on October 12, 2014. Cost of containment was $2.5 million.||There was one fatality. An air tanker fighting the fire crashed on October 7, 2014, killing the pilot.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Round Fire began in the far northern Owens Valley north of Bishop and west of Highway 395. Strong southerly winds spread the fire generally north and west into Mono County. Only one structure, a hay shed, was destroyed in Inyo County. Much more damage occurred in Mono County.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Round Fire began in far northern Inyo County and spread northwest into Mono County on strong southerly winds.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Extreme downslope winds in the lee of the Sierra prompted rapid spread of the Round Fire, which raced up a drainage and burned 40 homes in Swall Meadows.  The size of the fire was 6,537 acres according to CalOES. Precipitation arrived early in the morning on the 7th which dramatically slowed the fire, although the fire was not completely contained until the 12th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong front pushed into the West on the 6th, bringing widespread high winds along with areas of enhanced downslope winds in the lee of the Sierra.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds (estimated gusts 30 knots) spread a vegetation fire to a house in Yucca Valley.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds spread a vegetation fire in Yucca Valley to a house.

The Lake Fire began on June 17th around 1440 PST on Jenks Lake Road West near Camp de Benneville Pines in the eastern San Bernardino Mountains. The fire burned rapidly south and east near Highway 38 south of Big Bear toward the Morongo Valley in heavy timber.  Evacuations: 120 people from Camp de Benneville Pines, 1 person from Camp Ta Ta Pochon, 24 people from Camp Alpine Meadows, 23 people from Camp Edwards, and 10 people from Camp Tulakes. Mandatory evacuations were in place from east of Angelus Oaks to Onyx Summit on both sides of Hwy 38. All Hiking Trails into the San Gorgonio Wilderness Area were closed due to the proximity of the fire to many hiking trails. The Pacific Crest Trail (PCT) was closed from Whitewater Preserve to Onyx Summit. Highway 38 was closed between Angelus Oaks to Lake Williams. Jenks Lake Road was closed as well. The Mojave Desert Air Quality Management District issued a Smoke Advisory for Yucca Valley, Morongo Valley, Lucerne Valley and surrounding communities. The Lake Fire burned a total of 31,359 acres before being fully contained around 2115 PST on August 1. The fire was human-caused, but still under investigation. Approximately 10 structures were damaged or destroyed, including one home and 3 outbuildings.

The Sky wildfire started on June 18, 2015. The fire was located 2 miles northeast of Yosemite Forks in Madera County. It burnt 500 acres. There were no fatalities or structures lost. The cost of containment was $4.9 million.

The Corrine wildfire started on June 18, 2015 and was contained on June 25, 2015. The fire was located 2 miles north of Auberry in Madera County. It burnt 920 acres and three out buildings were lost. The cost of the wildfire is unknown.

The North fire began along Interstate 15 at the Cajon Summit in the early afternoon of the 17th. A mandatory evacuation order was issued for the Baldy Mesa area between Phelan and Hesperia. Interstate 15 was closed in both directions for hours with several cars still on the road. The fire burned rapidly on and near Interstate 15, destroying 20 vehicles and damaging 10 others, as well as destroying 5 homes. The fire burned a total of 3500 acres surrounding the interstate before being fully contained later that evening. The cause of the fire is unknown.

The McCabe fire began in July 18, 2015 and was contained on July 20, 2015. It was located 16 miles northwest of Los Banos, CA and burned 1333 acres. There were no structures lost and no fatalities. The cost of containment was $725,000.

The Cabin fire was started by lightning on July 19, 2015 and continued to burn into August. It was located 8 mile northeast of Camp Nelson in Tulare County. The fire remained around 2 acres in size until July 30, 2015, then became active and burned 800 acres by the end of the day on July 31.

The Tulare Lightning Complex began on July 21, 2015 and was contained on July 26, 2015. The fire was located 1 mile South of Springville and burned 446 acres. There were no structures lost and no fatalities. The cost of containment was $1.2 million.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Wragg Fire burned 8050 acres in Napa and Solano counties. There were 2 outbuildings destroyed , 4 outbuildings and 1 residence damaged.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Breezy southwest winds combined with dry fuels to intensify the development of wildfires, including the Kyburz and Wragg Fires.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The fire covered 75 acres. A vehicle fire started the fire east of Whitehall, which spread to both sides of US Highway 50. The vehicle that started the fire was destroyed, and there was one minor injury to a firefighter. Highway 50 was shut down through the rest of the afternoon into the next day. There were 15 people in the area evacuated.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Breezy southwest winds combined with dry fuels to intensify the development of wildfires, including the Kyburz and Wragg Fires.

The Cutca fire began at approximately 1500 PST on the 24th. The fire burned in steep and inaccessible terrain east of Cutca Valley and south of Long Canyon 2 miles north of the Palomar Observatory in the Cleveland National Forest. The fire burned a total of 150 before being fully contained on the 29th. The cause of the fire is unknown. No structures were threatened, no injuries, and no evacuations ordered.

The Willow Fire began on July 25, 2015 and continued to burn for the remainder of July and into August. It was human caused and was located 2 miles west of Wishon, CA. It burned 3383 acres as of July 31.

The Willow Fire began on July 25, 2015 and continued to burn for the remainder of July and into August. It was human caused and was located 2 miles west of Wishon, CA. It burned 3383 acres as of July 31.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were 2304 acres burned, with a total of 6 firefighters injured. Two firefighters from the US Forest Service and 2 from CAL Fire suffered burns while fighting the fire. One of the firefighters had serious burns and required further hospitalization. There were 2 structures destroyed, 1 damaged. Wildfire suppression costs were estimated to be $18 million.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire started in the Sierra Nevada Mountains at Steep Hollow Creek in the You Bet area, west of Alta, CA on July 25th at approximately 2:37 pm. The fire was not fully contained until August 10th. The cause is still under investigation.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The fire started Monday afternoon along Browning Street, about two miles north of Elverta Road, off Highway 99 and Baseline Road in Elverta, Sacramento County. The fire spread into Placer County. One home, six cars and a tractor were destroyed by the fire.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry northwest winds enhanced wildfires, including the Rocky Fire in Lake County and a property damaging grass fire in Elverta, in northern Sacramento County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Rocky Fire burned 18,000 acres by the end of July, and caused the evacuation of 650 people. The fire ultimately burned 68,000 acres by August 14, with 43 residences, 53 outbuildings destroyed; 8 structures damaged.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry northwest winds enhanced wildfires, including the Rocky Fire in Lake County and a property damaging grass fire in Elverta, in northern Sacramento County.

The Advance Fire was started by lightning on July 30, 2015 and was contained on August 2, 2015. It was located 5 miles north of Three Rivers, CA and burned 86 acres. The cost of containment is unknown.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Frog Wildfire was started by lightning at around 1645 PST on 07/30/2015.  As of 0330 PST on 08/01/2015, the fire covered 1000 acres and was 10 percent contained.  400,000 dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts. On the evening of July 30, 2015, 38 year-old Black Hills National Forest Engine Captain, David Dave Ruhl, while scouting on foot during initial attack of the Frog Fire on the Modoc National Forest, was entrapped and killed.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Frog Wildfire was started by lightning at around 1645 PST on 07/30/2015.  As of 0330 PST on 08/01/2015, the fire covered 1000 acres and was 10 percent contained.  400,000 dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Frog Wildfire was started by lightning at around 1645 PST on 07/30/2015. As of 0330 PST on 08/07/2015, the fire covered 4782 acres and was 100 percent contained. 3.9 million dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Frog Wildfire was started by lightning at around 1645 PST on 07/30/2015. As of 0330 PST on 08/07/2015, the fire covered 4782 acres and was 100 percent contained. 3.9 million dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.

The Willow Fire began on July 25, 2015 and was contained on August 11, 2015. It was human caused and was located 2 miles west of Wishon, CA, in the Sierra National Forest. It burned 5702 acres. There were no structures lost and no fatalities. The cost of containment was 19.7 million.

The Willow Fire began on July 25, 2015 and was contained on August 11, 2015. It was human caused and was located 2 miles west of Wishon, CA, in the Sierra National Forest. It burned 5702 acres. There were no structures lost and no fatalities. The cost of containment was 19.7 million.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Rocky Fire started on July 29th, and burned 50,000 additional acres between August 1-14. A total of 69,438 acres were burned, with 43 residences, and 53 outbuildings destroyed. There were also 8 structures damaged. Cal Fire law enforcement said a faulty gas water heater in an outbuilding was blamed for the Rocky Fire. |The Jerusalem Fire started to the south on August 9th, and ultimately merged with the Rocky Fire.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Continued drought, with periods of heat, and low humidity continued to enhance wildfire danger through much of August, especially in the Coastal Range.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Lowell Fire started on July 25th, with most fire growth and damage occurring in July. The cause is still under investigation. There were a total of 2304 acres burned, with a total of 6 firefighters injured (occurred and documented in July). Two firefighters from the US Forest Service and 2 from CAL Fire suffered burns while fighting the fire. One of the firefighters had serious burns and required further hospitalization. There were 2 structures destroyed, 1 damaged. Wildfire suppression costs were estimated to be $18 million.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Continued drought, with periods of heat, breezy winds and low humidity increased wildfire danger through early August.

The Cabin fire was started by lightning on July 19, 2015 and continued to burn through then entire month of August. The fire was 96% contained as of September 1, and was burning into the footprint of the 2011 Lion Fire. It was located 8 mile northeast of Camp Nelson in Sequoia National Forest. The fire remained around 2 acres in size until July 30, 2015, then became active and burned 6980 acres by the end of August. There were no structures lost and no fatalities. Cost of containment was $7.7 million as of September 1, 2015.

The Rough Fire was started by lightning on July 31, 2015 in the Kings River Drainage, 5 miles north of Hume Lake and 2.5 miles southwest of Spanish Mountain. The fire burned actively through August and continued into September. As of September 2, it had burned 79,963 acres. The fire was burning in the Sierra National Forest, Sequoia National Forest, and Sequoia & Kings Canyon National Parks. The fire closed Highway 180 east of Grant Grove and closed all of Kings Canyon National Park. The fire threatened infrastructure in the Hume Lake area as well as in Cedar Grove and several other small communities. There were 5 structures lost. The cost of containment as of September 2, was 57.8 million.

The Rough Fire was started by lightning on July 31, 2015 in the Kings River Drainage, 5 miles north of Hume Lake and 2.5 miles southwest of Spanish Mountain. The fire burned actively through August and continued into September. As of September 2, it had burned 79,963 acres. The fire was burning in the Sierra National Forest, Sequoia National Forest, and Sequoia & Kings Canyon National Parks. The fire closed Highway 180 east of Grant Grove and closed all of Kings Canyon National Park. The fire threatened infrastructure in the Hume Lake area as well as in Cedar Grove and several other small communities. There were 5 structures lost. The cost of containment as of September 2, was 57.8 million.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Jerusalem Fire started on August 9th, and burned 25,118 acres, with 6 residences, and 21 outbuildings destroyed. The cause is still under investigation.|The Jerusalem Fire merged with the larger Rocky Fire to the north.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Continued drought, with periods of heat, and low humidity continued to enhance wildfire danger through much of August, especially in the Coastal Range.

The Rough Fire was started by lightning on July 31, 2015 in the Kings River Drainage, 5 miles north of Hume Lake and 2.5 miles southwest of Spanish Mountain. The fire burned actively through August and September. As of September 30, it had burned 151,623 acres. The fire was burning in the Sierra National Forest, Sequoia National Forest, and Sequoia & Kings Canyon National Parks. The fire closed Highway 180 east of Grant Grove and closed all of Kings Canyon National Park for several weeks. The fire threatened infrastructure in the Hume Lake area as well as in Cedar Grove and several other small communities. There were 4 structures lost. The cost of containment as of September 30, was 118.9 million. The fire was 85 percent contained on September 30, and continued to burn in the interior areas into October.

The Rough Fire was started by lightning on July 31, 2015 in the Kings River Drainage, 5 miles north of Hume Lake and 2.5 miles southwest of Spanish Mountain. The fire burned actively through August and September. As of September 30, it had burned 151,623 acres. The fire was burning in the Sierra National Forest, Sequoia National Forest, and Sequoia & Kings Canyon National Parks. The fire closed Highway 180 east of Grant Grove and closed all of Kings Canyon National Park for several weeks. The fire threatened infrastructure in the Hume Lake area as well as in Cedar Grove and several other small communities. There were 4 structures lost. The cost of containment as of September 30, was 118.9 million. The fire was 85 percent contained on September 30, and continued to burn in the interior areas into October.

The Tenaya fire began on the evening of September 7, 2015, in Yosemite National Park, approximately 2 miles north of Yosemite Valley. The cause is under investigation. The fire burned 415 acres before being contained on September 16. There were no structures lost. The cost of containment was $1.9 million.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were 70,868 acres were burned in the Butte Fire, the 7th most destructive fire in California history. There were 475 residences and 343 outbuildings destroyed, and 45 structures damaged. In the fire there were 2 civilian fatalities and 1 injury. The cause has tentatively been attributed to a PG&E power line coming in contact with a live tree.  Extensive damage was done to power lines and poles. PG&E has identified 505 locations where equipment needs to be fixed.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extreme fire behavior with winds and very dry fuels combining to enhance rapidly moving fires which destroyed hundreds of homes and caused multiple deaths in the Valley and Butte Fires. The Valley Fire is considered the 3rd most destructive wildfire in California history, the Butte Fire the 7th most destructive.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were 76,067 acres burned in the Valley Fire. The Valley Fire was the 3rd most damaging fire in California history. At least 1958 structures were destroyed including; 1280 homes, 27 multi-family structures, 66 commercial properties, and 585 other minor structures such as outbuildings and sheds. There are 93 structures that have been damaged including: 41 homes, 7 commercial properties, and 45 other minor structures. In the fire there were 4 firefighters injured, 4 civilian fatalities. The cause of the fire is under investigation. Westerly winds gusting to over 40 mph were recorded in the area, causing a rapid surge in the early hours of the fire. One theory suggests that these winds may have been caused by a down burst from showers along the coast interacting with very dry air near the surface.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extreme fire behavior with winds and very dry fuels combining to enhance rapidly moving fires which destroyed hundreds of homes and caused multiple deaths in the Valley and Butte Fires. The Valley Fire is considered the 3rd most destructive wildfire in California history, the Butte Fire the 7th most destructive.

The Chimney Fire started on June 1, 2016 on BLM land near the Chimney Peak Campground, 10 miles West of Pearsonville, CA in Tulare County. It was human caused. It burned 1324 acres before being contained on June 7, 2016. Coast of containment was $2.8 million.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Pony Wildfire was started by lightning around 0245 PDT on 06/07/16.   As of the last report on 28/0430 PDT, the fire covered 2858 acres and was 63 percent contained.  17.5 million dollars were spent on firefighting efforts.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Pony Wildfire was started by lightning around 0245 PDT on 06/07/16.   As of the last report on 28/0430 PDT, the fire covered 2858 acres and was 63 percent contained.  17.5 million dollars were spent on firefighting efforts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Sherpa Fire burned 7,474 acres in the mountains of Santa Barbara county.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A hot and dry atmosphere, gusty winds and very dry vegetation lead to two significant wildfires across Southern California. The Sherpa fire and Pine fire burned over 7,500 acres total across the mountains of Santa Barbara and Ventura counties.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Border Fire began from unknown causes on the 19th of June. A local couple was killed on their property by the fire. Five structures and eleven outbuildings were destroyed, with one other home suffering damage. The fire also destroyed numerous power and phone lines. Firefighters acquired 100% containment on the fire June 30th, after 7,609 acres had been burned.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Border Fire started June 19th, in the middle of a intense heatwave. The fire burned several thousand acres and multiple structures before it was contained.

CZ_NAME_STR: LOS ANGELES COUNTY MOUNTAINS EXCLUDING THE SANTA MONICA RANGE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The San Gabriel Complex, which consisted of the Fish and Reservoir fires, scorched 5,399 acres in the mountains of Los Angeles county. The fire started in late June and continued into early July.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Yet again, the combination of very dry vegetation and hot and dry weather contributed to a wildfire in the mountains of Los Angeles county. The San Gabriel Complex, consisting of the Fish and Reservoir fires, burned 5,399 acres.

The Erskine Fire began on June 23, 2016 along Erskine Creek Road, 1 mile southwest of Lake Isabella in Kern County. The fire spread rapidly due to strong, gusty winds, hot temperatures and dry conditions on June 23 through 25. The growth of the fire slowed as winds decreased by June 26, however the fire continued to burn through early July before being contained on July 9. It burned 48,019 acres. The fire closed Highway 178 east of Bakersfield for several days with evacuation of numerous small communities in the Lake Isabella area. The fire destroyed 285 residences and 1 commercial building as well as damaging 12 other residences. There were 2 fatalities as an elderly couple were unable to escape the rapidly moving fire. The cost of containment as of July 9, was $23 million.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Trailhead Fire started on June 28th and continued into early July. The cause is still under investigation. There were a total of 5646 acres burned, with a total of 3 firefighters injured. The were 2600 structures threatened, with extensive evacuations in the area around Todd Valley and Forest Hill.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A period of heat and low humidity increased wildfire danger at the end of June.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Pine Fire, which started in late June and burned into mid July, burned 2,304 acres in the mountains of Ventura county.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A hot and dry atmosphere, gusty winds and very dry vegetation lead to two significant wildfires across Southern California. The Sherpa fire and Pine fire burned over 7,500 acres total across the mountains of Santa Barbara and Ventura counties.

The Erskine Fire began on June 23, 2016 along Erskine Creek Road, 1 mile southwest of Lake Isabella in Kern County. The fire spread rapidly due to strong, gusty winds, hot temperatures and dry conditions on the June 23 through 25. The growth of the fire slowed as winds decreased by June 26, however the fire continued to burn through early July before being contained on July 9. It burned 48,019 acres. The fire closed Highway 178 east of Bakersfield for several days with evacuation of numerous small communities in the Lake Isabella area. The fire destroyed 285 residences and 1 commercial building as well as damaging 12 other residences. There were 2 fatalities on June 23, 2016 as an elderly couple were unable to escape the rapidly moving fire. See June Storm Data for details. The cost of containment was $23 million.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Trailhead Fire started on June 28th and continued until containment on July 18th. The cause is still under investigation. There were a total of 5646 acres burned, with a total of 3 firefighters injured. The were 2600 structures threatened, with extensive evacuations in the area around Todd Valley and Forest Hill.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A period of heat and low humidity increased wildfire danger at the beginning of July.

CZ_NAME_STR: LOS ANGELES COUNTY MOUNTAINS EXCLUDING THE SANTA MONICA RANGE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The San Gabriel Complex, which started in late June, was finally contained in early July. In total, the fire burned 5,399 acres in the mountains of Los Angeles county.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of very dry vegetation and hot and dry weather continued to lead to several wildfires across Southern California. Some fires that started in June (Sherpa, Pine and San Gabriel Complex) continued to burn into June. Additionally, two more significant fires (Sand and Sage fires) developed during the month.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Pine Fire, which started in late June, was finally contained in mid July. In total, the fire burned 2,304 acres in the mountains of Ventura county.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of very dry vegetation and hot and dry weather continued to lead to several wildfires across Southern California. Some fires that started in June (Sherpa, Pine and San Gabriel Complex) continued to burn into June. Additionally, two more significant fires (Sand and Sage fires) developed during the month.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Sherpa Fire, which started in mid June, was finally contained in early July. In total, the fire burned 7,474 acres in the mountains of Santa Barbara county.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of very dry vegetation and hot and dry weather continued to lead to several wildfires across Southern California. Some fires that started in June (Sherpa, Pine and San Gabriel Complex) continued to burn into June. Additionally, two more significant fires (Sand and Sage fires) developed during the month.

The Deer fire began on July 1, 2016, 6 miles east of Arvin in Kern County. It burned 1785 acres before being contained on July 10, 2016. There were no structures lost. Cost of containment was $5 million.

The Curry Fire began on July 1, 2016, 7 miles southwest of Coalinga in Fresno County.  The cause is under investigation, but was believed to be human caused. It burned 2944 acres before being contained on July 5, 2016. There were no structures lost. Cost of containment was $2 million.

CZ_NAME_STR: LOS ANGELES COUNTY MOUNTAINS EXCLUDING THE SANTA MONICA RANGE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Sage Fire burned 1,109 acres in the Santa Clarita Valley.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Due to very dry vegetation and continued hot and dry weather, two more significant wildfires developed across Los Angeles county. The Sand Fire burned over 40,000 acres while the Sage Fire burned 1,109 acres.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Checkpoint Fire was short lived but significant. It burned 12 acres and several small structures over 3.5 hours, caused 1 minor injury to a firefighter, and caused a partial closure of I-15 during rush hour.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Small wildfire that began and was extinguished on the 18th of July.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Roblar Fire began on the 21st and grew to over 1,000 acres in just 24 hours. The fire would consume a total of 1,245 acres before it was contained on the 30th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire that grew rapidly on Camp Pendleton on July 21st and wasn't extinguished until July 30th.

CZ_NAME_STR: LOS ANGELES COUNTY MOUNTAINS EXCLUDING THE SANTA MONICA RANGE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Sand Fire burned 41,432 acres in the mountains of Los Angele county, just above the Santa Clarita Valley. The fire burned into early August before reaching full containment.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Due to very dry vegetation and continued hot and dry weather, two more significant wildfires developed across Los Angeles county. The Sand Fire burned over 40,000 acres while the Sage Fire burned 1,109 acres.

The Goose fire began on July 30, 2016, 2 miles southeast of Prather, CA in the foothills of Fresno County. The cause is under investigation, but is believed to be human caused. It burned 1800 acres as of July 31, but continued burning into August. A portion of Highway 168 was closed for 3 days due to the fire. The cost of containment was $1.2 Million as of July 31.

The Goose fire began on July 30, 2016, 2 miles southeast of Prather, CA in the foothills of Fresno County. The cause is under investigation, but is believed to be human caused. It burned 1800 acres as of July 31, but continued burning into August. A portion of Highway 168 was closed for 3 days due to the fire. There were four residences and 5 out-buildings destroyed before the fire was contained on August 9, 2016. The cost of containment was $10.4 million.

CZ_NAME_STR: LOS ANGELES COUNTY MOUNTAINS EXCLUDING THE SANTA MONICA RANGE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Sand Fire burned 41,432 acres in the mountains of Los Angeles county, just above the Santa Clarita Valley. The fire started in late July and was not contained until |mid-August.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Sand Fire, which started in late July, was finally contained in early August. In total, the fire burned over 41,000 acres.

The Pilot fire began on August 7 around 1106 PST near Miller Canyon OHV off of Highway 138, San Bernardino County. The fire spread rapidly to the north, with much of the total acreage burned within the first couple of days. A mandatory evacuation order was issued areas north of SR 173, south of Hesperia Lake Road, and Arrowhead Lake Road. Road closures included Highway 173 between SR 138 and Arrowhead Lake Road, as well as the Miller Canyon OHV and Forest Service Roads 2N33, 2N17X, 2N36, 2N37. Cause of the fire, as well as damaged structures and any injuries are unknown. The fire burned 8,115 acres before being fully contained on August 12 around 1200 PST.

The Mineral Fire began in 8/9/16 and was located in the foothills 9 miles southwest of Coalinga, CA. The fire burned 7050 acres before being contained on 8/18/16. The fire closed a portion of Highway 198 for a short time. There was one residence and 1 outbuilding destroyed. The cost of containment was $11.3 million.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN LUIS OBISPO COUNTY INTERIOR VALLEYS (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Chimney Fire ignited in northern San Luis Obispo county, near Lake Nacimiento. Due to hot and dry conditions, as well as historically dry vegetation, the fire grew very quickly. The fire burned into early September, before containment and scorched 46,344 acres.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two significant wildfires impacted sections of Santa Barbara and San Luis Obispo counties. The Chimney Fire, which ignited near Lake Nacimiento in San Luis Obispo county, burned over 46,000 acres. The Rey Fire, which ignited in the Santa Ynez Mountains in Santa Barbara county, burned over 33,000 acres.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Clayton Fire burned 3929 acres and destroyed 299 structures; including 189 single-family homes, 8 commercial structures, and 102 other structures such as sheds and smaller outbuildings. An additional 28 structures were damaged, though the number of structures damaged or destroyed may change as surveys are completed and additional data is confirmed. Damage to property was estimated at $1.5 million. The fire was determined to have been due to arson.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and dry conditions increased wildfire danger in mid August, with the Clayton Wildfire starting on August 13th and being contained by the 26th.

The Blue Cut fire began on August 16 around 0938 PST along Interstate 15 between Blue Cut & Kenwood, Swarthout Canyon/Devore, San Bernardino County. The fire spread rapidly to the north, with much of the total acreage burned within the first couple of days. A mandatory evacuation order was issued for over 84,000 people and 35,000 homes. Numerous road closures, including I-15 in both directions for two days, with traffic building up in both directions waiting for the interstate to reopen. The Union Pacific Railroad reported burnt trusses with railroad service stopped in both directions and won't resume until trusses are rebuilt. Numerous homes and structures destroyed (approximately 105 homes and 313 minor structures). Two firefighters sustained minor injures. Two fire engines burned over as well. The fire burned 36,274 acres before being fully contained on August 22 around 0830 PST.

The Cedar fire began on 8/16/16 5 miles north of Alta Sierra in Kern County and spread northward into Tulare County. It was human caused. The fire burned 29,322 acres and was 70 percent contained as of 8/31/16. The fire continued to burn into September. The fire forced evacuations for several communities in Kern and Tulare counties for more than two weeks and Highway 155 was closed for several days due to the fire. Six cabins in the Spear Creek Summer Homes tract in the community of Posey in Tulare County were destroyed.  The cost of containment as of 8/31 was $45 million.

The Cedar fire began on 8/16/16 5 miles north of Alta Sierra in Kern County and spread northward into Tulare County. It was human caused. The fire burned 29,322 acres and was 70 percent contained as of 8/31/16. The fire continued to burn into September. The fire forced evacuations for several communities in Kern and Tulare counties for more than two weeks and Highway 155 was closed for several days due to the fire. Six cabins in the Spear Creek Summer Homes tract in the community of Posey in Tulare County were destroyed.  The cost of containment as of 8/31 was $45 million.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Rey Fire ignited in southern Santa Barbara county, in the Santa Ynez Mountains. . Due to hot and dry conditions, as well as historically dry vegetation, the fire grew very quickly. The fire burned into early September, before containment and scorched 33,606 acres.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two significant wildfires impacted sections of Santa Barbara and San Luis Obispo counties. The Chimney Fire, which ignited near Lake Nacimiento in San Luis Obispo county, burned over 46,000 acres. The Rey Fire, which ignited in the Santa Ynez Mountains in Santa Barbara county, burned over 33,000 acres.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Grade Wildfire started around 1455 PDT on 08/24/16 2 miles north of Yreka California.  It was likely caused by human activity.  As of 0430 PDT on 08/31/16, the fire covered 710 acres and was 100% contained. 5 residences and 5 outbuildings were destroyed, and another outbuilding was damaged. 2.1 million dollars were spent in firefighting efforts.

As of 0430 PDT on 08/31/16, the fire covered 710 acres and was 100% contained. 5 residences and 5 outbuildings were destroyed, and another outbuilding was damaged. 2.1 million dollars were spent in firefighting efforts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Gap Wildfire started on 08/27/16 at around 1945 PDT. The cause was unknown, but likely human caused.  As of 09/01/0430 PST, the fire covered 13020 acres and was 5% contained. 9 homes and 14 outbuildings were lost and 5.2 million dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Gap Wildfire started on 08/27/16 at around 1945 PDT. The cause was unknown, but likely human caused. The Cedar fire began on 8/16/16 5 miles north of Alta Sierra in Kern County and spread northward into Tulare County. It was human caused. The fire burned 29,322 acres mostly during August 2016, before being fully contained on 9/30/16. The fire forced evacuations for several communities in Kern and Tulare counties for more than two weeks and Highway 155 was closed for several days due to the fire. Six cabins in the Spear Creek Summer Homes tract in the community of Posey in Tulare County were destroyed. The cost of containment was $58.4 million.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Rey Fire, in northern San Luis Obispo county, was finally contained in early September. In total, the fire burned 33,606 acres.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In early September, both the Chimney Fire (in San Luis Obispo county) and the Rey Fire (in Santa Barbara county) were finally contained. In all, the Chimney Fire scorched 46,344 acres and the Rey Fire scorched 33, 606 acres.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN LUIS OBISPO COUNTY INTERIOR VALLEYS (ZONE)

The fire burned 29,322 acres mostly during August 2016, before being fully contained on 9/30/16. The fire forced evacuations for several communities in Kern and Tulare counties for more than two weeks and Highway 155 was closed for several days due to the fire. Six cabins in the Spear Creek Summer Homes tract in the community of Posey in Tulare County were destroyed. The cost of containment was $58.4 million.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At approximately 4:30 pm Monday September 5th, a total of 5 fires constituting the Saddle Fire started on Pentz Road south of Paradise, and rapidly grew in size. There were a total of 850 acres burned by containment on the 10th. The cause of the fires was determined to be a malfunctioning vehicle exhaust system. There were 3 injuries reported. There were 3 structures destroyed, 2 of those being private homes. The fire caused several power lines to go down and it affected power to customers in the area. According to PG&E, more than 300 customers were without power and significant damage was done to the power infrastructure. Evacuations were ordered for the area.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Above average temperatures and very dry conditions increased wildfire danger in early September, with the Saddle Wildfire starting on September 5th and being contained by the 12th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Soup Complex wildfire started on 09/17/16 at 1619 PDT.  The cause remains unknown.  As of 0345 PDT on 10/01/16 , the fire covered 2647 acres and was 62% contained.  No structures were lost and 5.35 million dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Canyon Fire ignited on Vandenberg Air Force Base in Santa Barbara county. The fire burned 12,518 acres.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Canyon Fire burned over 12,000 acres of land across Vandenberg Air Force Base.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Soup Complex wildfire started on 09/17/16 at 1619 PDT.  The cause remains unknown.  As of 0430 PDT on 10/07/16 , the fire covered 2722 acres and was 70% contained.  No structures were lost and 5.4 million dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Low relative humidity and gusty winds helped the Opera Fire begin on the 30th. The fire consumed 1350 acres east of Riverside before being fully contained on May 2nd.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Santa Ana Winds developed over the region on the 29th of April as a surface high settled over the Great Basin. The event was of weak to moderate strength Santa Ana, but it brought low relative humidity values that combined with two months without significant rainfall to produce an elevated fire risk. Several small wildfires occurred in the Inland Empire on the 30th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Tower Fire occurred along Interstate 15 through the Cajon Pass. Approximately 150 acres of open country were consumed before the fire was contained on May 3rd.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Santa Ana Winds developed over the region on the 29th of April as a surface high settled over the Great Basin. The event was of weak to moderate strength Santa Ana, but it brought low relative humidity values that combined with two months without significant rainfall to produce an elevated fire risk. Several small wildfires occurred in the Inland Empire on the 30th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Deluz Fire started on Camp Pendleton Marine Base on May 19th, it was extinguished on the 26th after burning 486 acres.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry conditions helped the Deluz Fire start on Camp Pendleton Marine Base on May 19th, it was extinguished on the 26th after burning 486 acres.

The Highway fire began on June 18, 2017, 5 miles northeast of Bodfish, near Lake Isabella CA, in Kern County. The cause is under investigation. It burned 1541 acres before being contained on June 28, 2017. The fire closed part of Highway 178 near Lake Isabella from July 18 to July 20. The fire was contained on June 25, 2017. Cost of containment was $3 Million.

The Creek fire began on June 25, 2017, off Los Gatos Creek Rd, west of Derrick, or 13 miles northwest of Coalinga, CA in Fresno County. The cause is under investigation. It burned 357 acres before being contained on June 28, 2017. There was one residence and 3 sheds destroyed. The cost of containment was $1.5 million.

The Schaeffer Fire was started by lightning on June 24, 2017 in the footprint of the 2002 McNally Fire. The fire was initially allowed to burn for resources purposes, however, when the fire activity increased significantly, an Incident Command Team was assigned on July 3. The fire closed the Kern River and Western Divide ranger districts of the Sequoia National Forest for most of July. The fire burned 16,031 acres and was contained on July 31, 2017. Cost of containment was $13.1 Million.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Fay Wildfire started around 11 AM PDT on 07/05/17. As of the last report on 07/21/17, the fire was at 469 acres and was 100% contained. 2.4 million dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Fay Wildfire started around 11 AM PDT on 07/05/17. As of the last report on 07/21/17, the fire was at 469 acres and was 100% contained. 2.4 million dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN LUIS OBISPO COUNTY CENTRAL COAST (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Alamo Fire burned 28,687 acres in San Luis Obispo and Santa Barbara counties. One home was destroyed by the fire.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and dry conditions during the month resulted in two significant wildfires in Southern California. The Alamo fire burned 28,687 acres while the Whittier fire burned 18, 430 acres.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Governor Brown declared a State of Emergency for the Wall Fire, which burned 6033 acres and threatened thousands of homes. There were 6 injuries reported. The number of structures destroyed or damaged by the fire was 101. Cal Fire reported 41 homes were destroyed, and three were damaged. Forty-eight minor structures were destroyed. Seven were damaged. Two commercial structures were also destroyed. There were 4000 mandatory evacuations ordered, with 7400 under an evacuation warning.||Butte County opened a local assistance center at the Oroville Municipal Auditorium for those evacuated. ||At the height of the fire, more than 800 customers lost power due to fire damage or lines PG&E de-energized for firefighter safety. About 50 power poles burned. Crews removed 670 fire-damaged trees that posed a threat to power lines or public safety.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure brought high temperatures and very low humidity, further drying fuels and increasing fire danger.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Whittier Fire burned 18,470 acres in southern Santa Barbara county. The fire destroyed 16 homes and damaged one other.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and dry conditions during the month resulted in two significant wildfires in Southern California. The Alamo fire burned 28,687 acres while the Whittier fire burned 18, 430 acres.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Farad Fire burned 747 acres in the steep terrain on the north and west side of Interstate 80 about 1 mile west of the California-Nevada state line, mostly on the 10th and 11th. The incident caused periodic closures of Interstate 80 on the 10th into the afternoon of the 11th due to fire fighting activities. A few power poles were damaged near Interstate 80. As the burn was in steep terrain with narrow canyons, it likely contributed to mudslides and debris flows which affected Interstate 80 in August.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Farad Fire broke out on the north and west side of Interstate 80 early in the afternoon on the 10th. It was mostly wrapped up and contained by the 15th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Dobe Wildfire started around 1500 PDT on 07/13/17. The cause is under investigation. As of the last report on 07/17/17, the fire covered 410 acres and was 100% contained.  750000 dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Dobe Wildfire started around 1500 PDT on 07/13/17. The cause is under investigation. As of the last report on 07/17/17, the fire covered 410 acres and was 100% contained.  750000 dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.

The Detwiler Fire began on July 16, 2017, 15 miles northwest of Mariposa, CA. It was human caused. It burned 81,826 acres, resulting in 63 residences, 67 minor structures and 1 commercial structure being destroyed with another 13 residences and 8 minor structures damaged. The fire forced the evacuation of several small rural communities for as long as 10 days and also the entire town of Mariposa (population 18,000) for 3 days. Parts of Highways 41, 49, and 140 were closed at times during the fire. The fire was 90 percent contained on July 31, 2017, but no additional growth occurred before it was completely contained on August 24, 2017. Cost of containment was $87 Million.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A rancher was badly burned in the Maria Fire on Monday, July 17th. The fire was in Calaveras County, near Mokelumne Hill. There were 117 acres burned, with numerous structures threatened, but none reported burned. The rancher had third degree burns over 90% of his body, and passed away on July 29th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and dry temperatures brought enhanced fire danger.

All were started by lightning, the earliest starting on 8/11/17 at around 12:01 AM PDT. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fire began on August 13 of unknown cause, but was possibly lightning started. The fire began about 1 mile east of Wawona along the south fork of the Merced river in Yosemite National Park. The cost of containment was $8.6 milliion as of September 21. After the end of August the fire was being managed as it burned into rockier ground in the wilderness of Yosemite.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The South Fork Fire fire began on August 13, 2017, 1 mile east of Wawona along the south fork of the Merced river in Yosemite National Park. The fire closed several trails in the southern part of Yosemite. Thunderstorms downdrafts caused the fire to spread west and threaten the community of Wawona, which was evacuated for 6 days from August 19th to the 24th. Firefighters were able to contain the fire on the south and west side of the fire by August 26th, but the fire was being allowed to burn to the east. Containment was 44 percent by the end of August. Thereafter, the fire was being managed as it moved into rockier terrain in the wilderness of Yosemite. The fire will likely continue into October.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The human caused Pier Fire began in the early morning hours of August 29, 2017 when a stolen car was set on fire and pushed off a cliff along Highway 190, 7 miles east of Springville, CA. The fire burned 36,556 acres before being contained on September 24, 2017. There were mandatory evacuations for many small communities for several weeks and Highway 190 between Springville and Ponderosa was closed to traffic. There were 2 structures lost.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The human caused Pier Fire began in the early morning hours of August 29, 2017 when a stolen car was set on fire and pushed off a cliff along Highway 190, 7 miles east of Springville, CA. The fire burned 36,556 acres before being contained on September 24, 2017. There were mandatory evacuations for the small communities of Camp Nelson, Pierpoint Springs, Cedar Slope, Sequoia Crest, Rogers Camp, Doyle Springs, Mountain Aire and Wishon for several weeks. Much of Highway 190 between Springville and Ponderosa was closed to traffic. There were 2 structures lost. Cost of containment was $38.76 million.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Railroad Fire started just near the community of Sugar Pine along Highway 41, 8.75 miles north of Oakhurst. This area is just south of Yosemite National Park. It spread rapidly, destroying 17 structures, including at least 5 homes, a historic locomotive and the passenger car, snowplow, side dump car and refrigerator car that were attached to it.  The fire also burned into the Nelder Grove of Giant Sequoia trees, threatening significant damage.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Railroad Fire started on the afternoon of August 29, 2017, west of Highway 41, 8.75 miles north of Oakhurst, just south of Yosemite National Park near the community of Sugar Pine. The fire spread rapidly in dry brush. Highway 41 between Oakhurst and the south entrance of Yosemite National Park was closed in both directions for about a week with several small communities evacuated, including Tenaya Lodge that serves visitors to Yosemite. The fire burned 12,407 acres before being contained on September 15, 2017. Cost of containment was $20.8 million. There were 17 structures destroyed, including a historic locomotive that wasnt being used, as well as a passenger car, snowplow, side dump car and refrigerator car that were attached to it that were part of the Yosemite Mountain Sugar Pine Railroad. More than 200 wooden railroad ties also burned. The fire also burned into the Nelder Grove of Giant Sequoia trees.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Ponderosa Fire burned 4,016 acres and destroyed 54 structures, 32 homes & 22 outbuildings. There were 2 injuries. The fire cause was an illegal campfire that got out of control.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and dry conditions increased wildfire danger in late August, with the Ponderosa Wildfire starting on August 29th and continuing into September.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Slinkard Fire burned 8,925 acres west of Topaz, California, between August 29th and September 11th. The fire was suspected to be lightning-caused by a high-based thunderstorm. Extreme fire growth in cheat grass, sagebrush, and pinyon/juniper lead to evacuations in Topaz north of California 89 to the Nevada state line. U.S. 395 was closed from south of Gardnerville, Nevada, to California 108 in Bridgeport, California, from August 31st to September 2nd. California 89 was also closed from U.S. 395 to State Road 4 at Monitor Pass. Nevada 208 was also closed for a short period of time. The cost to fight the fire was at least $5.7M.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with limited rainfall produced many lightning strikes leading to several new wildfire starts in northwest Nevada and far eastern California on the 29th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Salmon August Complex included the Wallow, Island, Mary, Rush, Grizzly, Pointers, and Garden fires. All were started by lightning, the earliest starting on 8/11/17 at around 12:01 AM PDT. As of the last report at 03:30 PST on 09/28/17, the fires collectively covered 65875 acres and was 83 percent contained. 39.1 million dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Slinkard Fire burned 8,925 acres west of Topaz, California, between August 29th and September 11th. No exact end time was found for this incident. The fire was suspected to be lightning-caused by a high-based thunderstorm. Extreme fire growth in cheat grass, sagebrush, and pinyon/juniper lead to evacuations in Topaz north of California 89 to the Nevada state line. U.S. 395 was closed from south of Gardnerville, Nevada, to California 108 in Bridgeport, California, from August 31st to September 2nd. California 89 was also closed from U.S. 395 to State Road 4 at Monitor Pass. Nevada 208 was also closed for a short period of time. The cost to fight the fire was at least $5.7M.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with limited rainfall produced many lightning strikes leading to several new wildfire starts in northwest Nevada and far eastern California on the 29th of August. The Slinkard Fire which started in late August was not 100% contained until early September.

CZ_NAME_STR: LOS ANGELES COUNTY SAN FERNANDO VALLEY (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The La Tuna Fire burned 7,194 acres in the San Fernando Valley. The fire destroyed five homes in the area.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In early September, the La Tuna fire ignited in the San Fernando Valley. The fire scorched 7,194 acres, making it the largest wildfire in the city of Los Angeles in 50 years. Five homes were destroyed by the fire.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Mission Fire was located 2 miles east of North Fork in Madera County. It burned 1035 acres in the Sierra Foothills, destroyed three homes and damaged 4 other structures before being contained. The cost of containment was $13.8 million.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two fires started within a short time of each other on the afternoon of September 3, 2017, both in the foothills of the Sierra Nevada. The Mission fire began 2 miles east of North Fork in Madera county and burned 1035 acres and destroyed three residences and damaged 4 other structures before being contained on September 13, 2017.  The Peak fire began 9 miles southeast of Mariposa in Mariposa county and burned 680 acres and destroyed 2 structures before being contained on September 9, 2017. The cause of both fires is unknown.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Peak fire was located 9 miles southeast of Mariposa, in Mariposa county. It burned 680 acres and destroyed 2 structures before being contained on September 9. The cost of containment was $1 million.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two fires started within a short time of each other on the afternoon of September 3, 2017, both in the foothills of the Sierra Nevada. The Mission fire began 2 miles east of North Fork in Madera county and burned 1035 acres and destroyed three residences and damaged 4 other structures before being contained on September 13, 2017.  The Peak fire began 9 miles southeast of Mariposa in Mariposa county and burned 680 acres and destroyed 2 structures before being contained on September 9, 2017. The cause of both fires is unknown.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two fires broke out near Los Gatos due to lightning. One near Loma Prieta Ridge and the other near Twin Creeks Road |http://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2017/09/11/lightning-strikes-recorded-bay-area/|http://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2017/09/12/lightning-sparked-wildfire-burning-in-woodside/.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A disturbance rotating around an upper level low west of San Diego brought thunderstorm activity to the Bay Area on September 11. Widespread reports of lightning were received along with a few small hail reports and strong wind gusts. It has been reported that there were over 40,000 lightning strikes across the Central Coast of California during this event. Several brush fires were also ignited due to lightning strikes.

CZ_NAME_STR: SANTA LUCIA MOUNTAINS AND LOS PADRES NATIONAL FOREST (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Various lightning strikes sparked 15 fires in Monterey County that were contained on the same day http://www.mercurynews.com/2017/09/13/crews-contain-15-fires-started-by-lightning-in-monterey-county/. Timing has been estimated.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A disturbance rotating around an upper level low west of San Diego brought thunderstorm activity to the Bay Area on September 11. Widespread reports of lightning were received along with a few small hail reports and strong wind gusts. It has been reported that there were over 40,000 lightning strikes across the Central Coast of California during this event. Several brush fires were also ignited due to lightning strikes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Skeggs Fire was sparked by a lightning strike Monday night in the Santa Cruz Mountains. The fire peaked at 50 acres||http://www.fire.ca.gov/current_incidents/incidentdetails/Index/1826|http://www.mercurynews.com/2017/09/15/firefighters-fully-contain-skeggs-fire-near-woodside/.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A disturbance rotating around an upper level low west of San Diego brought thunderstorm activity to the Bay Area on September 11. Widespread reports of lightning were received along with a few small hail reports and strong wind gusts. It has been reported that there were over 40,000 lightning strikes across the Central Coast of California during this event. Several brush fires were also ignited due to lightning strikes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Estate Fire was a 65-acre grass fire which destroyed two homes, two RVs, and multiple vehicles and outbuildings. The fire was 100 percent contained by 7 pm PST. Winds gusted to 32 mph at Vacaville Airport, at 10:36 am PST. Humidity dropped to 13 percent by 12:35 pm PST at the airport.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Building high pressure over the area brought drying northerly winds to the area, creating critical fire weather conditions.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Canyon Fire began around 1300 PST, and spread rapidly near Highway 91, consuming 1700+ acres in the first 6 hours. The fire damaged 6 structures and forced hundreds of residents to evacuate in Corona. At least 8 schools were closed.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The canyon fire began shortly after 1300 PST on the 25th near Highway 91 in Orange County. The fire spread rapidly due to dry fuel conditions and very low humidity, and fire fighting efforts were hindered by a transition from light Santa Ana Winds to onshore flow. This initially pushed the fire into the foothills before sending it back eastward toward Corona. By 2100 PST on the 25th the fire was estimated at 1700+ acres and was threatening residences. Winds calmed over the ensuing days and the fire was quickly contained at 2662 acres. The cause of the wildfire was determined to be a roadside flare.

Strong downslope winds combined with a hot dry airmass resulted in extreme fire behavior. It is speculated that above normal winter rains yielded abundant fuels that became primed for rapid intense fire spread by late summer and early fall.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Tubbs Fire began the night of October 8th and was officially contained on the 30th to the north east of Santa Rosa. Cause of the fire is unknown. A total of 36,807 acres were burned, 5,300 structures were destroyed, and there were 23 fatalities, all of which were in Sonoma County|http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-fires-20171018-story.html|http://www.pressdemocrat.com/news/7702145-181/sonoma-county-fire-victim-total?utm_campaign=trueAnthem%3A+Trending+Content&utm_content=5a1f154704d301157a6fde91&utm_medium=trueAnthem&utm_source=twitter&artslide=0.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure building into the Great Basin lead to gusty northerly to northeasterly winds across a portion of our CWA. Existing low relative humidity values  and dry fuels were also observed. As a result, the several fires that developed grew and spread rapidly to become one of the deadliest wildfire outbreaks in state history. Many of the individual fires merged into what became known as the Central LNU Complex and Southern LNU Complex Fires. When all was done over 100,000 acres of land was destroyed, thousands of structures and homes were lost, and 44 people died across Northern California. In addition to the loss of human life, countless pets and livestock were lost in the fires.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Atlas Fire (Southern LNU Complex) started the night of October 8th and was officially contained on the 27th. A total of 51,624 acres were burned, 481 structures destroyed, and there were 6 fatalities in Napa County|http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-fires-20171018-story.html.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure building into the Great Basin lead to gusty northerly to northeasterly winds across a portion of our CWA. Existing low relative humidity values  and dry fuels were also observed. As a result, the several fires that developed grew and spread rapidly to become one of the deadliest wildfire outbreaks in state history. Many of the individual fires merged into what became known as the Central LNU Complex and Southern LNU Complex Fires. When all was done over 100,000 acres of land was destroyed, thousands of structures and homes were lost, and 44 people died across Northern California. In addition to the loss of human life, countless pets and livestock were lost in the fires.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Nuns Fire began the night of the 8th and was officially contained on the 30th. A total of 56,556 acres were burned, 1200 structures were destroyed, and there were 2 fatalities, one in Sonoma County and one in Napa County|http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-fires-20171018-story.html.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure building into the Great Basin lead to gusty northerly to northeasterly winds across a portion of our CWA. Existing low relative humidity values  and dry fuels were also observed. As a result, the several fires that developed grew and spread rapidly to become one of the deadliest wildfire outbreaks in state history. Many of the individual fires merged into what became known as the Central LNU Complex and Southern LNU Complex Fires. When all was done over 100,000 acres of land was destroyed, thousands of structures and homes were lost, and 44 people died across Northern California. In addition to the loss of human life, countless pets and livestock were lost in the fires.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Atlas Fire Fire burned 51,624 acres in Napa and Solano counties, with 481 structures destroyed and 90 damaged.|Wind gusts were up to 49 mph at Travis AFB, 48 mph at Vacaville Nt Airport.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Breezy northerly winds with low humidity and dry fuel brought critical fire conditions. Wind gusts ranged from 40 to 50 mph in the Central Valley. These enhanced the development of the Wind Complex, which included the Cascade, Lobo, McCourtney and LaPorte wildfires.  Other fires include the Atlas, Sulphur, Cherokee, and Honey wildfires.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Wind Fire Complex included the Cascade, LaPorte, Lobo, and McCourtney fires.|Total acreage of the Wind Complex was 17,037 acres. There was 1 injury and 4 fatalities. There were 398 structures destroyed, 203 residences, 194 outbuildings & 1 commercial structure. There were 16 structures destroyed, 6 residences & 10 outbuildings.|Wind gusts were up to 46 mph at Oroville Dam, 41 mph at  Chico Airport,  39 mph|3 miles SSW Paradise.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Breezy northerly winds with low humidity and dry fuel brought critical fire conditions. Wind gusts ranged from 40 to 50 mph in the Central Valley. These enhanced the development of the Wind Complex, which included the Cascade, Lobo, McCourtney and LaPorte wildfires.  Other fires include the Atlas, Sulphur, Cherokee, and Honey wildfires.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Sulphur Fire was part of the Mendicino Lake Fire Complex. It started on|October 8, 2017, burned 2,207 acres, and was contained on October 27, 2017.|Approximately 169 buildings (residences, outbuildings and commercial buildings) were|destroyed or damaged. The fire burned in watersheds that drain directly to Clear Lake or to much smaller Borax Lake. Clear Lake supplies municipal water for several communities.|Wind gusts were up to 63 mph 8 miles ENE Hidden Valley Lake,  50 mph 1 mile SSE Wilbur Springs,   45 mph 5 miles E Talmage.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Breezy northerly winds with low humidity and dry fuel brought critical fire conditions. Wind gusts ranged from 40 to 50 mph in the Central Valley. These enhanced the development of the Wind Complex, which included the Cascade, Lobo, McCourtney and LaPorte wildfires.  Other fires include the Atlas, Sulphur, Cherokee, and Honey wildfires.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Pocket Fire began early on the 9th and was officially contained on the 31st. A total of 17,357 acres were burned and 540 structures were destroyed. There were no fatalities associated with this fire.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure building into the Great Basin lead to gusty northerly to northeasterly winds across a portion of our CWA. Existing low relative humidity values  and dry fuels were also observed. As a result, the several fires that developed grew and spread rapidly to become one of the deadliest wildfire outbreaks in state history. Many of the individual fires merged into what became known as the Central LNU Complex and Southern LNU Complex Fires. When all was done over 100,000 acres of land was destroyed, thousands of structures and homes were lost, and 44 people died across Northern California. In addition to the loss of human life, countless pets and livestock were lost in the fires.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Canyon 2 Fire began around 0900 PST on the 9th near the 91 Freeway and Gypsum Canyon Rd. in Anaheim Hills. The fire spread rapidly threatening numerous structures. In the first 24 hours the fire consumed more than 7,000 acres. In total 25 structures were destroyed, 55 were damaged and 9,217 acres burned. Four injuries were also reported. The cause of the fire was reported to be embers from the Canyon Fire which began September 25 and contained October 4th. Damage value is an estimate.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate to strong Santa Ana winds surfaced west of the mountains as high pressure built over the Great Basin on the 9th. Surface pressure gradients favored the Inland Empire and Orange County for the strongest winds. In most places peak wind gusts were 35-55 mph, but local gusts to 70 were reported. The downsloping flow sent relative humidity values crashing. The Canyon 2 Fire began near Anaheim Hills ultimately scorching more than 9,000 acres and damaging or destroying 80 structures. Isolated damage also occurred below the Cajon Pass.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Thomas Fire ignited in early December in the coastal valleys of Ventura county, near Thomas Aquinas College. At the time of ignition, fuel conditions were at record dry levels for early December. The combination of gusty Santa Ana winds and the dry fuel conditions allowed the fire to spread quickly across sections of Ventura county. The fire eventually moved into southern Santa Barbara county. The fire was not officially contained until early January 2018. In all, the Thomas Fire burned 281,893 acres, making it the largest recorded fire in the state of California. During the height of the fire, one firefighter died when he was burned over.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong surface high pressure building in the Great Basin generated strong and gusty Santa Ana winds across sections of Ventura and Los Angeles counties. North to northeast wind gusts up to 73 MPH were reported. During this event, the Thomas Fire ignited across Ventura county, eventually spreading into Santa Barbara county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Lilac Fire began on the 7th near Interstate 15, and spread rapidly through the San Luis Rey River Basin near Bonsall. The fire consumed 4,100 acres, destroyed 157 structures and damaged 64. Over 100,000 residents were forced to or advised to evacuate and 20,000 people lost power. The fire was fanned by sub 10% relative humidity values and wind gusts over 50 mph. The fire was 100% contained on December 16th, but the majority of damage occurred in the first 48 hours. Damage value is an estimate.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level trough swept through the Rockies on the 3rd of December, ushering a strong surface high into the Great Basin. The high peaked at 1048 mb on the 7th and brought a prolonged period of strong Santa Ana Winds and very dry weather to Southern California. The most intense winds occurred on the 7th. The Lilac Fire began on the 7th near Interstate 15, and spread rapidly through the San Luis Rey River Basin near Bonsall. Damage to trees and power lines also occurred, along with some road closures.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Patterson Fire ignited around 1 pm PST on May 17th. Six homes were evacuated around 1500 PST on Hidden Falls Road and Vista Road, and one unoccupied structure was destroyed in the fire. The fire rapidly grew to approximately 1,200 acres by 1830 PST on the 17th. Evacuations were lifted around 2100 PST on the 17th. The fire was contained around 1800 PST on May 18th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire ignited a few miles south of Winchester in Riverside County on May 17th. Lower relative humidity and wind speeds between 15-20 mph helped exasperate the fire. Evacuations were put in place for six homes near the fire, and one structure was destroyed.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A brush fire broke out in Aliso Viejo around 1300 PST on June 2nd and spread to around 200 acres. Erratic winds and dry fuels helped to exasperate the fire. Thousands of homes were evacuated in Aliso Viejo and Laguna Beach due to the fire. The Top of the World neighborhood in Laguna Beach was evacuated as well. No structures were damaged in the fire. Five firefighters suffered non-life threatening injuries. Authorities determined that a young boy accidentally set the fire.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A brush fire broke out in the Aliso Viejo Canyon Park around 2pm on 6/2/2018. The fire scorched approximately 200 acres and forced evacuations of thousands of residents in the Aliso Viejo and Laguna Beach. No structures were damaged. Five firefighters suffered non-life threatening injuries.

CZ_NAME_STR: LOS ANGELES COUNTY MOUNTAINS EXCLUDING THE SANTA MONICA RANGE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Stone Fire burned 1,352 acres in the mountains of Los Angeles county.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Stone wildfire ignited in the mountains of Los Angeles county. The fire burned 1,352 acres.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Apple Fire in Tehama County (Off Apple Rd & Paskenta Rd, west of Corning), burned 2,956 acres with 3 residential structures and 2 outbuilding destroyed. The fire was contained by June 14.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unseasonable heat, low humidity, and very dry fuels created critical conditions for wildfire.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Chrome Fire in Glenn County (Hwy 162 and Forest Hwy 7, north of Elk Creek), burned 2,290 acres with 1 outbuilding destroyed. The fire was contained on June 21.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unseasonable heat, low humidity, and very dry fuels created critical conditions for wildfire.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Pawnee Fire in Lake County (Pawnee Rd & New Long Valley Rd, northeast of Clearlake Oaks), burned 15,185 acres with 22 structures destroyed and 1 injury. The fire was contained by July 8.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and Dry Conditions Northern California Wildfires, June 9-21, 2018.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Martinez Fire broke out around 1400 PST on June 23rd. Dry conditions and temperatures in the 120s helped exasperate the fire. Seven homes were destroyed. Approximately 30 tribal members were displaced from their homes and lost nearly all of their possessions. Three firefighters suffered minor injuries in the blaze.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fire broke out at the Torres Martinez Desert Cahuilla Reservation in the Coachella Valley on June 23rd. Seven homes were destroyed and the fire affected 30 tribal members in total. Members were displaced from their homes and lost all of their possessions.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The County Fire in Yolo and Napa counties (east of Lake Beryessa), burned 90,288 acres with 20 structures destroyed and 1 injury. The fire was started by an improperly installed electric livestock fence unit. The fire was contained on July 17.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unseasonable heat, low humidity, and very dry fuels created critical conditions for wildfire.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An improperly installed electric fence sparked a fire in Yolo County. Under Red Flag conditions the fire spread to Napa County on the morning of July 1st. The County Fire grew to 90,288 acres and destroyed 20 structures and caused 1 injury. Cal Fire incident information http://www.fire.ca.gov/current_incidents/incidentdetails/Index/2101.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Red Flag conditions exacerbated a fire sparked in Yolo County at the end of June that moved into Napa County in the beginning of July.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Klamathon Wildfire started on 07/05/18 at 0031 PDT by someone burning debris.   As of the last report at 22/0330 PST, the fire covered 38008 acres and was 100 percent contained.  33.5 million dollars had been expended on firefighting efforts. One death was reported and 82 structures were lost.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Klamathon Wildfire started on 07/05/18 at 0031 PDT by someone burning debris.   As of the last report at 22/0330 PST, the fire covered 38008 acres and was 100 percent contained.  33.5 million dollars had been expended on firefighting efforts. One death was reported and 82 structures were lost.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The West Fire started around 1015 PST on 07/06 and quickly spread to 400 acres by 1600 PST. The fire started for unknown reasons alongside eastbound I-8 at West Willows Road in Alpine.  Extreme temperatures and low relative humidity helped exasperate the fire. Most of the Alpine community was evacuated from their homes. The fast-moving brush fire destroyed or damaged approximately 50 structures. One firefighter was injured while battling the blaze. In total, the fire burned 505 acres and was fully contained 7/10 around 1600 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The West Fire started on 7/06 in Alpine and quickly spread to over 400 acres in a few short hours. The cause of the fire is unknown. Extreme temperatures from high pressure aloft and low relative humidity helped to exasperate the fire. Evacuations were put into place, and approximately 50 structures were damaged or destroyed. One firefighter was injured. The fire was fully contained on 7/10.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Ferguson fire began July 13, 2018 and continued burning into August. Tragically, 2 firefighters were killed. A CalFire bulldozer operator died on July 14 when his dozer rolled off a sharp ridge. A hotshot from Sequoia/Kings Canyon National Park was killed when he was hit by a falling tree on July 29. One structure was destroyed and 57,041 acres had burned by July 31. The cost of containment was $64.3 Million as of July 31.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Ferguson Fire started on July 13, 2018 at 2136 PDT in the South Fork Merced River drainage, 10 miles north of Mariposa, CA in Sierra National Forest. The cause of the fire is under investigation. The fire started in an area that has steep, rugged terrain with scarcely any road access and a heavy presence of beetle-killed trees.  On the morning of July 14, a heavy equipment operator was killed in a bulldozer rollover accident. The fire grew rapidly under hot and dry weather conditions. Strong inversions each day resulted in smoke issues in the fire area that limited aircraft operations. Smoke impacts from the fire spread throughout Yosemite National Park, the Sierra Nevada and foothill and into the San Joaquin Valley. Highway 140 leading into Yosemite National Park was closed on July 14 and remained closed through the end of July and into August. Smoke impacts in Yosemite resulted in dangerous air quality causing Yosemite Valley and most of the eastern part of the park to be closed to visitors on July 25. This closure continued into early August. Highway 41 leading into Yosemite from the south was also closed. Several communities just outside of Yosemite, including El Portal, Foresta, and the park employee housing at Rancheria Flat were subject to evacuations. From July 24 to 31, additional evacuations and repopulations of other areas continued to occur. On July 29,    another tragic accident occurred when a tree fell, hitting and killing a firefighter.  This fire continued to burn actively into August. By July 31, it had burned 57,041 acres and cost $64.3 Million.
