EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Natchez Wildfire was caused by lightning. The time of ignition was around 1830 PDT on 07/15/2018.  As of 0330 PDT on 08/01/18, the fire covered 6174 acres and was 15 percent contained.  0 structures were lost and 9.7 million dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Natchez Wildfire was caused by lightning. The time of ignition was around 1830 PDT on 07/15/2018.  As of 0330 PDT on 08/01/18, the fire covered 6174 acres and was 15 percent contained.  0 structures were lost and 9.7 million dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Martinez Fire broke out around 1400 PST on July 23rd. Dry conditions and temperatures in the 120s helped exasperate the fire. Seven homes were destroyed. Approximately 30 tribal members were displaced from their homes and lost nearly all of their possessions. Three firefighters suffered minor injuries in the blaze.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Martinez Fire broke out on the Torres Martinez Reservation in Mecca around 1400 PST on July 23rd. Seven homes were destroyed and 30 tribal members were displaced. Three firefighters suffered minor injuries.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Carr Fire began on the afternoon of July 23, 2018, at the intersection of Highway 299 and Carr Powerhouse Road, near French Gulch in Shasta County. The fire is reported to have been started accidentally by a vehicle towing a trailer that had a tire blow out, causing the steel rim to scrape along the pavement, generating sparks that ignited dry vegetation along the edge of the highway. Local winds generated by the fire are reported to have caused the fire to spread quickly.||At the end of July, the fire was the sixth most destructive fire in California history at 112,888 acres, with 1,378 structures destroyed, 965 of them homes. The fire was not fully contained until August 30, reaching 229,651 acres in size with a total of 1,079 residences, 22 commercial structures, 503 outbuildings destroyed. There were also 190 residences, 26 commercial structures, and 61 outbuildings damaged. About 38,000 people were evacuated from their homes. There were a total of 8 deaths from the fire, 3 of them firefighters. A large fire whirl in Redding has been reported as being responsible for 4 of the deaths, and this has been listed as a separate event. Damage costs to insured buildings are estimated at $1.5 billion for the Carr Fire.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Large wildfires developed across Northern California at the end of July during a period of high temperatures, low humidity and unusually dry fuels. A powerful fire whirl developed with the Carr Fire, creating significant wind damage to western Redding and rapid fire growth. The Mendicino Complex became the largest wildfire in California history. A state of emergency was declared at state and federal levels due to the fires.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Cranston Fire started on 7/25 around 1100 PST in the Riverside County Mountains. By 1700 PST on 7/25, the fire had rapidly grown to 1,200 acres. In total, the Cranston Fire burned 13,000 acres, resulted in over 500 people being evacuated, and scorched 5 structures. The cause of the fire was determined to be arson. The Cranston Fire was fully contained on 8/13.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Cranston Fire started around 1100 PST on 7/25 in the Riverside County Mountains near the town of Idyllwild. Nearby communities in Idyllwild, Mountain Center and Fern Valley were evacuated. In total, the fire scorched 13,000 acres, 5 structures and resulted in many road closures. The fire was fully contained on August 13.

CZ_NAME_STR: MOUNTAINS SOUTHWEST SHASTA COUNTY TO NORTHERN LAKE COUNTY (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Mendocino Complex Fire (made up of the River and Ranch Fires) spread across Colusa County, Glenn County, Lake County, and Mendocino County, becoming the largest wildfire in California history at 459,123 acres. The Mendocino Complex Fire was not contained until September 18. There were 157 residential buildings destroyed, 123 others destroyed. In addition, there were 13 residential buildings and 24 other buildings damaged. The fires caused at least $56 million in insured property damage. The city of Lakeport, communities of Kelseyville, Lucerne, Upper Lake, Nice, Saratoga Springs, Witter Springs, Potter Valley, and Finley, parts of Hopland, and the tribal communities of Hopland Rancheria and Big Valley Rancheria were evacuated. There was 1 firefighter killed (on August 13), 4 firefighters were injured.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Large wildfires developed across Northern California at the end of July during a period of high temperatures, low humidity and unusually dry fuels. A powerful fire whirl developed with the Carr Fire, creating significant wind damage to western Redding and rapid fire growth. The Mendicino Complex became the largest wildfire in California history. A state of emergency was declared at state and federal levels due to the fires.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Steele Fire began on July 28th and was contained on August 2nd. Eight structures were destroyed and 4 were damaged http://www.fire.ca.gov/current_incidents/incidentdetails/Index/2184.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fire broke out near Lake Berryessa in Napa County on July 28th. Due to the fire being located in a densely populated area, evacuations were issued. The fire was contained on August 2nd after burning 135 acres, destroying 8 structures, and damaging 4.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Cranston Fire started on July 25th and continued to burn through August 13th when it was fully extinguished. It started on 7/25 around 1100 PST in the Riverside County Mountains. By 1700 PST on 7/25, the fire had rapidly grown to 1,200 acres. In total, the Cranston Fire burned 13,000 acres, resulted in over 500 people being evacuated, and scorched 5 structures. The cause of the fire was determined to be arson.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Cranston Fire began in late July and continued to actively burn through August 13th, 2018. It started around 1100 PST on 7/25 in the Riverside County Mountains near the town of Idyllwild. Nearby communities in Idyllwild, Mountain Center and Fern Valley were evacuated. In total, the fire scorched 13,000 acres, 5 structures and resulted in many road closures.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Ferguson fire began on the Sierra National Forest just west of Yosemite, and spread to parts of the Stanislaus National Forest as well as into southern and western Yosemite National Park.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Ferguson Fire started on July 13, 2018 at 2136 PDT in the South Fork Merced River drainage, 10 miles north of Mariposa, CA in Sierra National Forest. The cause of the fire is under investigation. The fire started in an area that has steep, rugged terrain with scarcely any road access and a heavy presence of beetle-killed trees. On the morning of July 14, a heavy equipment operator was killed in a bulldozer rollover accident while constructing line in a steep canyon. The fire grew rapidly under hot and dry weather conditions. Strong inversions each day resulted in smoke issues in the fire area that limited aircraft operations. Smoke impacts from the fire spread throughout Yosemite National Park, the Sierra Nevada and foothill and into the San Joaquin Valley. Highway 140 leading into Yosemite National Park was closed on July 14 and remained closed through August 14. Smoke impacts in Yosemite resulted in dangerous air quality causing Yosemite Valley and most of the eastern part of the park to be closed to visitors on July 25. This closure continued until August 14. Highway 41 leading into Yosemite from the south was also closed and did not reopen until August 24. Several communities just outside of Yosemite, including El Portal, Foresta, and the park employee housing at Rancheria Flat were subject to evacuations. From July 24 to 31, additional evacuations and repopulations of other areas continued to occur. On July 29, another tragic accident occurred when a tree fell, hitting and killing a firefighter. The weather moderated on August 6, which gave firefighters the opportunity to reinforce containment lines, mop up hot spots, and complete firing operations to keep the fire from spreading further into Yosemite National Park.  The closure of Yosemite National Park for nearly three weeks had local and global impacts on those who had planned to travel to visit during that time. Economically, businesses were impacted in the gateway communities who depend on summer tourist season to sustain them through the year. |By August 18, the fire was contained and had burned 96,901 acres at a suppression cost of $117 Million. There were 19 injuries to firefighters and 10 structures destroyed.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Natchez Wildfire was caused by lightning. The time of ignition was around 1830 PDT on 07/15/2018. As of 0330 PDT on 09/01/18, the fire covered 27076 acres and was 70 percent contained. 0 structures were lost and 34.8 million dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Natchez Wildfire was caused by lightning. The time of ignition was around 1830 PDT on 07/15/2018. As of 0330 PDT on 09/01/18, the fire covered 27076 acres and was 70 percent contained. 0 structures were lost and 34.8 million dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Steele Fire began on July 28th and was fully contained on August 2nd. Eight structures were destroyed and 4 were damaged http://www.fire.ca.gov/current_incidents/incidentdetails/Index/2184.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fire broke out near Lake Berryessa in Napa County on July 28th. Due to the fire being located in a densely populated area, evacuations were issued. The fire was contained on August 2nd after burning 135 acres, destroying 8 structures, and damaging 4.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Donnell Fire began on August 1, 2018, along Highway 108 in Stanislaus National Forest in Tuolumne County. The cause of the fire is unknown. The fire burned 36,450 acres, 54 structures destroyed and 81 minor structures destroyed. of them homes. Among the destroyed buildings was the historic Dardanelle Resort and Dardanelle Bridge. The fire was not fully contained until early October. There were a total of 9 injuries from the fire.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Large wildfires developed across Northern California early August during a period of high temperatures, and low humidity.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Hirz Fire began on August 9, 2018, near Lakehead by Shasta Lake, in Shasta-Trinity National Forest in Shasta County. The fire was determined to be human caused. The fire burned 46,150 acres and caused evacuations through the area, but no structures were destroyed and no injuries were reported. The fire was not fully contained until September 12. The fire came close to the Carr Fire. The Delta Fire burned into the western perimeter of the Hirz Fire on September 10.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Large wildfires developed across Northern California early August during a period of high temperatures, and low humidity.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Holy Fire began in the Santa Ana Mountains around 2:15 PM PST on August 6th. The hot and dry conditions helped to exasperate the fire further. By the morning of August 7, the fire had increased in size to 4,000 acres and by August 8, it had grown to 6,200 acres. By August 9, more than 21,400 people in 7,400 residences were placed under mandatory evacuation in south Corona, Lake Elsinore, and several communities in the Santa Ana Mountains. Ortega Highway was closed for an indefinite period of time, due to fire danger between Antonio Parkway in San Juan Capistrano and Grand Avenue in the Lake Elsinore. The fire size in total ended up growing to over 23,000 acres. Eighteen structures were destroyed in Orange and Riverside Counties. No major injuries or deaths were reported. The fire was fully contained on September 13th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Holy Fire started around 2:15 PM PST on August 6th and spread rapidly through the Santa Ana Mountains. Hot temperatures and dry conditions helped exasperate the fire even further. Evacuation orders were issued for parts of Trabuco Canyon, including the entire community of Holy Jim. The fire grew in total to over 23,000 acres and was fully contained on September 13th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Stone Wildfire was started by lightning around 0800 PDT on 08/15/18.  As of the last report at 0330 PST on 08/30/2018, the fire covered 39387 acres and was 100 percent contained.  2 structures were lost and 16.6 million dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Stone Wildfire was started by lightning around 0800 PDT on 08/15/18.  As of the last report at 0330 PST on 08/30/2018, the fire covered 39387 acres and was 100 percent contained.  2 structures were lost and 16.6 million dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Natchez Wildfire was caused by lightning. The time of ignition was around 1830 PDT on 07/15/2018. As of 0330 PDT on 10/01/18, the fire covered 38134 acres and was 84 percent contained. 0 structures were lost and 43.7 million dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Natchez Wildfire was caused by lightning. The time of ignition was around 1830 PDT on 07/15/2018. As of 0330 PDT on 10/01/18, the fire covered 38134 acres and was 84 percent contained. 0 structures were lost and 43.7 million dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Delta Fire began on September 5, 2018, near Lakehead by Shasta Lake, in Shasta-Trinity National Forest in Shasta County. The fire was determined to be human caused. The fire burned 63,100 acres and caused evacuations through the area, with 20 structures destroyed and no injuries reported. The fire was not fully contained until October 7. The fire came close to the Carr Fire. The Delta Fire burned into the western perimeter of the Hirz Fire on September 10.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large fire developed during an extended period of hot, dry weather with gusty winds.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Natchez Wildfire was caused by lightning. The time of ignition was around 1830 PDT on 07/15/2018. As of 0330 PDT on 10/01/18, the fire covered 38134 acres and was 84 percent contained. 0 structures were lost and 43.7 million dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Natchez Wildfire was caused by lightning. The time of ignition was around 1830 PDT on 07/15/2018. As of 0330 PDT on 10/01/18, the fire covered 38134 acres and was 84 percent contained. 0 structures were lost and 43.7 million dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A small 17 acre fire broke out that became known as the Rincon Fire off of Highway 9 north of Santa Cruz. One firefighter was injured https://www.ksbw.com/article/update-rincon-fire/24683131?utm_campaign=KSBW&utm_content=5be1f9ec04d30130ee666ef9&utm_medium=twitter&utm_source=trueAnthem:+New+Content.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An offshore wind event brought elevated fire concerns for the region in early November. One small fire broke out in Santa Cruz County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Camp Fire began on the morning of November 8, 2018, by Camp Creek Road, near Pulga in Butte County. The fire was not fully contained until November 25. This fire was the most destructive wildfire in California history, destroying much of the city of Paradise, the community of Concow, and damaging the towns of Pulga and Magalia. There were 18,804 structures destroyed, 13,696 of them single homes, along with 514 commercial structures and 3,718 outbuildings and 153,336 acres burned. There were a total of 86 deaths from the fire, with 12 civilians and 5 firefighters injured. There were 3 people missing as of 1/24/2019, when Butte County Sheriff closed their missing persons call center for the Camp Fire. Damage costs to insured buildings has been estimated to be at least $10 billion. |Conditions which lead to this fire included several recent years with drought conditions, late spring rainfall bringing additional growth of grass for fuel, dry weather for seven months prior to the fire, very low humidity due to several north wind events, record dry fuel and gusty northeast winds the day of the fire. Local wind gusts to 40 to 50 mph were measured nearby at Jarbo Gap, with a peak gust in the early morning of 52 mph. These winds caused the fire to spread very quickly. The fire forced the rapid evacuation of over 27,000 people from Paradise, Magalia, Centerville, Concow, Pulga, Butte Creek Canyon, Berry Creek and Yankee Hill. The fire also threatened the communities of Butte Valley, Chico, Forest Ranch, Helltown, Inskip, Oroville, and Stirling City. All residents were not allowed to return home until December 15, when the final evacuation orders were lifted. |Smoke from the fire was dense at times across much of Northern California, concentrated by strong atmospheric inversions. Air quality was reported by the Air Resources Board as some of the worst on record, causing many schools to close and events to be canceled across the area. Visibility was below 1/2 mile at times.|The cause of the fire is under investigation, though there evidence suggests it occurred near damaged power lines.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An extended period of dry weather through the summer and fall with above normal temperatures coupled with a gusty north to northeast wind event created a situation for extremely rapid fire growth. A large wildfire developed, the deadliest and most destructive in history for California.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Hill Fire burned 4,531 acres in Ventura county, near the community of Camarillo. The fire started during a strong Santa Ana wind event. Northeast winds gusting in excess of 60 MPH along with very dry conditions allowed the fire to spread very quickly. During the fire, four structures were destroyed.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Hill Fire started in early November during a strong Santa Ana wind event. The combination of gusty winds and very dry conditions allowed the fire to grow quickly, eventually charring 4,531 acres.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Hill Fire burned 4,531 acres in Ventura county, near the community of Camarillo. The fire started during a strong Santa Ana wind event. Northeast winds gusting in excess of 60 MPH along with very dry conditions allowed the fire to spread very quickly. During the fire, four structures were destroyed.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Hill Fire started in early November during a strong Santa Ana wind event. The combination of gusty winds and very dry conditions allowed the fire to grow quickly, eventually charring 4,531 acres.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Woolsey Fire burned 96,949 across in Ventura and Los Angeles county. The fire ignited during a strong Santa Ana wind event. Gusty north to northeast winds (in excess of 60 MPH) and very dry conditions allowed the fire to spread very quickly. In total, the Woolsey Fire destroyed 1,643 structures (including 400 homes) and damaged an additional 364 structures. Three deaths were attributed to the fire. Two deaths occurred when an SUV was overrun by flames and the third death occurred in a destroyed home.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Woolsey Fire burned 96,949 acres in Ventura and Los Angeles counties, destroying over 1500 structures. The fire ignited during a strong Santa Ana wind event and the combination of gusty winds and very dry conditions allowed the fire to spread very quickly.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: On June 8, conditions were favorable for wildfire growth as relative humidity values fell into the teens and northerly winds gusted up to 25-45 mph. Prior to the start of this event, the local utility company decided to de-energize power lines per CA Public Utility Commissions (CPUC) Public Safety Power Shutoff (PSPS) guidelines. Eventually, a fire did start at 1350PST in Yolo County, which became known as the Sand Fire. There were 2512 acres of land burned over a period of 8 days, along with 7 structures destroyed. The fire also led to road closures from Highway 16 to Highway 20 to the town Brooks in addition to the evacuation of residents living along County Road 41.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A upper level low passed through the region, which brought elevated fire weather concerns to northern California. Areas impacted within Sacramento's forecast area include the Sacramento and San Joaquin Valleys for areas generally below 1000 feet.

CZ_NAME_STR: EAST BAY HILLS AND THE DIABLO RANGE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: San Jose Fire Department reported a vegetation fire in the San Jose Foothills that damaged one home. The hot temperatures made fire fighting efforts difficult resulting in one firefighter suffering from heat exhaustion http://www.ktvu.com/news/ktvu-local-news/firefighter-suffers-heat-exhaustion-battling-house-fire-in-east-foothills-of-san-jose.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of high pressure and strong offshore flow resulted in an early season heat wave across the Bay Area from June 9th to the 11th. Multiple daily records were broken across the region and multiple power outages were reported due to the heat. Approximately 26,000 people across the region lost power on Monday followed by an additional 30,000 on Tuesday. Three fatalities were reported during the heat event. One man died as a direct result of heat related illness while two others drowned while attempting to cool down during the heat wave. Hot temperatures and dry grass resulted in a vegetation fire that spread to a residence.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Rock Fire started Tuesday night June 25th, 4 miles Del Puerto Canyon Rd, which is west of Patterson. It grew to 2422 acres over 24 hours and according to a CalFire via a media interview, the fire was burning near several Native American archaeological sites belonging to the Yokuts. Crews took extra precautions not to disturb the soil of these sites and at the time of the media report, it was unknown if the fire had done any damage. Additionally, it was also noted in a media interview that some acres of ranch land were burned but no buildings or structures were.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A broad trough passing over the Pacific Northwest brought breezy winds to the San Joaquin Valley. These conditions, combined with dry fuels led to a increased fire danger for the region.

CZ_NAME_STR: NORTHEAST SISKIYOU AND NORTHWEST MODOC COUNTIES (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Tucker Wildfire started around 28/1545 PDT.  As of 0430 PST on August 1, the fire covered 14217 acres and was 30 percent contained.  0 structures were lost and 1.5 million dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Tucker Wildfire started around 28/1545 PDT.  As of 0430 PST on August 1, the fire covered 14217 acres and was 30 percent contained.  0 structures were lost and 1.5 million dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.

CZ_NAME_STR: NORTHEAST SISKIYOU AND NORTHWEST MODOC COUNTIES (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Tucker Wildfire started around 28/1545 PDT.  As of the last report on 04/0330 PDT, the fire covered 14150 acres and was 100 percent contained.  0 structures were lost and 3.7 million dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Tucker Wildfire started around 28/1545 PDT.  As of the last report on 04/0330 PDT, the fire covered 14150 acres and was 100 percent contained.  0 structures were lost and 3.7 million dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A brush fire in Oakley prompted evacuations and a preemptive power shutoff for 5600 customers. Fire officials said 58 acres were burned and 2 structures were destroyed https://www.nbcbayarea.com/news/local/Firefighters-Battle-Vegetation-Fire-in-Oakley-525973021.html.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A brush fire in Oakley prompted evacuations and a preemptive power shutoff for 5600 customers. Fire officials said 58 acres were burned and 2 structures were destroyed.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 5 acre vegetation fire broke out at Bay Ave. and Phyllis Ave. in Moreno Valley late on August 15th. 2 single family homes were destroyed, as well as 3 outbuildings and 9 vehicles.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An uppper level high centered over western Arizona ushered in hot weather to parts of Southern California. The deserts and inland valleys experienced much warmer than normal temperatures, with August 14th and 15th being the hottest days of the event. Temperatures were hottest in the Coachella Valley, where Thermal reached 120 degrees and Palm Springs reached 119 on August 15th. Ramona reached 100 degrees and Lake Elsinore reached 105 degrees on August 14th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: CalFire reported that a wildfire occurred on the morning of August 22 and lasted through the evening of August 26. This fire was named the Mountain Fire and burned 600 acres of land. It damaged 5 residential buildings and 2 additional structures in addition to destroying 7 residential buildings and 7 other structures.  A local news paper also reported that about 14 wooden power poles were damaged and that the local power company worked actively to replace them. CalFire also noted that there were 3 cases of minor injuries, and that all the victims were treated and released. There were numerous evacuations, around 3,885 residents, and road closures within the area which were all lifted on the by the evening of August 24.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure brought hot and dry weather to northern California from August 23 through August 26, 2019. Temperatures were forecast to be 5 to 10 degrees above normal.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Long Valley Fire started near the Red Rock exit along US Highway 395 and spread across the California/Nevada border into northwestern Nevada the 24th before being contained the 27th. The fire burned 2438 acres, and one structure was destroyed. The Federal Emergency Management Agency stated that the fire threatened 250-300 homes in and around Rancho Haven (Nevada). The fire also threatened five buildings, infrastructure, utilities, equipment, farms, ranches, and a watershed in the area. Mandatory evacuations were ordered for approximately 800 people before containment was reached. Firefighting costs were approximately $600K, according to the Nevada Bureau of Land Management.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Warm temperatures, along with dry conditions, occurred the 23rd through the end of the month. Breezy conditions occurred on the 24th and 25th, but combined effects of winds and humidity did not reach critical fire weather criteria.

CZ_NAME_STR: SOUTHERN SALINAS VALLEY / ARROYO SECO / LAKE SAN ANTONIO (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two small grass fires broke out in southern Monterey County injuring multiple firefighters and threatening three structures as well as prompting evacuations https://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2019/09/01/firefighters-burned-evacuations-prompted-by-2-grass-fires-in-monterey-county/. Number of injuries unclear.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two small grass fires broke out in southern Monterey County on Sunday September 1st. Multiple CalFire firefighters were injured.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Walker Fire burned in Genesee Valley in the Plumas National Forest east of Taylorsville from the afternoon of the 4th through the 25th. Smoke from this fire affected parts of western Nevada and northeast California, with the most widespread smoke reaching the Reno Metropolitan area on the 8th. This fire would eventually burn 54,612 acres before heavy rain on the 16th ended nearly all remaining fire activity, with full containment achieved on the 25th. Several evacuations were ordered for the Genesee Valley corridor, the Ward Creek area, the Flournoy Bridge area, and Antelope Lake. According to the Plumas National Forest, 9 structures were destroyed in the fire and the cost was estimated to be near $35,100,000.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: At the beginning of September, little to no rainfall fell on areas of the northern Sierra and mountains west of Susanville. Dry and warm conditions also persisted. A large wildfire started during this period.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Tenaja Fire started on September 4th in the town of La Cresta in Riverside County and quickly grew to over 1,900 acres over the course of two days. 1,200 people were evacuated, and many schools closed due to the poor air quality. Two structures were damaged and three firefighters suffered minor injuries. The cause of the fire is still under investigation, but lightning may be the cause. The fire was contained on September 14th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper level high pressure centered over the Four Corners ushered in moisture from the southeast into SoCal starting on Labor Day. Monsoon thunderstorms impacted the mountains and deserts September 2 through 5th. The event started with a nocturnal MCS over the Coachella Valley early in the morning on September 2nd, dumping 1-1.5 inches over a couple of hours. Even more thunderstorms formed Monday afternoon, especially in the mountains. Hail was reported on I-8 Monday afternoon. Storms continued each afternoon and evening in the mountains through September 5th. Some thunderstorms even reached the San Diego County coast on September 4th. Widespread outflow wind gusts of 30-45 mph were reported on the coast and in the valleys on September 4th.|At the end of September, 24-26, tropical moisture was wrapped into southern California from a closed upper low. This initially brought Santa Ana winds and very warm temperatures to the coast and on 25-26 brought scattered thunderstorms to the San Diego mountains. The flooding rains were confined to the Mojave Desert and Imperial Valley.

CZ_NAME_STR: EASTERN SIERRA SLOPES OF INYO COUNTY (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Taboose Fire burned 10,296 acres and four vehicles. The event continued into October.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Taboose Fire began southwest of Big Pine on the afternoon of September 4 due to a lightning strike. The fire destroyed four vehicles at Red Lake Trailhead on September 7, and eventually reached 10,296 acres before being contained on October 16. One firefighter was injured during containment operations.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms moved across the area on 9/5/19.  Dozens of fires were initiated by lightning.  One of them was the Lime Wildfire, which was started by a lightning strike at 05/1119 PDT.  As of the last report on 22/0430 PDT, the fire was at 1872 acres and was 99 percent contained.  0 structures were lost and 9.0 million dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms moved across the area on 9/5/19.  Dozens of fires were initiated by lightning.  One of them was the Lime Wildfire, which was started by a lightning strike at 05/1119 PDT.  As of the last report on 22/0430 PDT, the fire was at 1872 acres and was 99 percent contained.  0 structures were lost and 9.0 million dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.

CZ_NAME_STR: MOUNTAINS SOUTHWEST SHASTA COUNTY TO NORTHERN LAKE COUNTY (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: On September 5 thunderstorms developed over interior northern California sparking several wildfires within the region. This particular fire was named the Red Bank Fire and it grew up to 8,838 acres. This fire damaged or destroyed 2 structures and caused road closures and mandatory evacuations. Evacuations were lifted by the evening of September 8.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low with embedded disturbances brought isolated showers and thunderstorms to the region. Model data indicated that any available moisture would be|above 700 millibars so rainfall with any thunderstorms would be limited. These conditions, combined with seasonably dry fuels and moderate to poor humidity recoveries, led to fire weather concerns for northern California.

CZ_NAME_STR: MOUNTAINS SOUTHWEST SHASTA COUNTY TO NORTHERN LAKE COUNTY (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: On September 5 thunderstorms developed over interior northern California sparking several wildfires within the region. This particular fire was named the South Fire and it grew up to 5,332 acres, with the majority of the fire growth occurring between September 5-21. Terrain is steep and rugged out there, which made containment difficult and called for road closures at times. The last major update that the Shasta-Trinity National Forest Service put out was on September 21, 2019; however, on November 27, 2019 at 10AM PST, they reported the fire was officially 100% contained and controlled.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low with embedded disturbances brought isolated showers and thunderstorms to the region. Model data indicated that any available moisture would be|above 700 millibars so rainfall with any thunderstorms would be limited. These conditions, combined with seasonably dry fuels and moderate to poor humidity recoveries, led to fire weather concerns for northern California.

One of them was the Kidder 2 Wildfire, which was started by a lightning strike at 05/1845 PDT. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms moved across the area on 9/5/19.  Dozens of fires were initiated by lightning.  One of them was the Kidder 2 Wildfire, which was started by a lightning strike at 05/1845 PDT.  As of the last report on 21/0430 PDT, the fire was at 227 acres and was 100 percent contained.  0 structures were lost and 840 thousand dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: On September 7, a fire broke out in Butte County and burned 496 acres of land, destroying 2 buildings one residential and outbuilding. The fire grew fast enough to warrant mandatory evacuations and road closures, which were all eventually lifted by the evening of September 9th. The fire was declared contained on September 13, 2019 at 6PM PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A short wave trough moved over the region bringing synoptic cooling and cloudiness with it. Drier fuels were still in place and locally breezy winds were expected, thus there was a small risk for wildfire development.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Horseshoe Fire broke out around 1700 PST on September 14th in Riverside County. 60 homes were evacuated in a small community. The fire was 520 acres and was fully contained on September 17th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper level high pressure over the Great Basin brought heat, high winds and low relative humidity to Southern California. Many locations in the Inland Empire reached 100-105 degrees on the 13th. Orange and San Diego County valleys reached 90-99 degrees on the 13th. The Coachella Valley saw the highest temperatures in the region with highs topping out around 110F on Friday. Similar high temperatures occurred on the 14th. A weak Santa Ana event occurred with peak wind gusts ranging from 20-40 mph, highest in the mountains. Numerous small wildfires broke out due to the low humidity and gusty winds. One of the largest fires was the Horseshoe Fire near Hemet. It prompted evacuations of a small community near North Warren Road. No injuries or damages were reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A vegetation fire broke out in Napa County destroying one outbuilding https://www.fire.ca.gov/media/9865/american_incident10_07pm_final.pdf.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Warm and dry conditions along with offshore winds created elevated fire concerns for the region. A small vegetation fire broke out in Napa County that destroyed one structure.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A small wildfire broke out in the hills near Moraga overnight prompting evacuations for nearby homes. Ultimately no structures were destroyed https://www.eastbaytimes.com/2019/10/10/fire-crews-battle-merrill-fire-in-moraga/.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong and gusty northerly winds developed over the North and East Bay Hills. This along with a very dry airmass over the region, created critical fire weather conditions for the greater Bay Area. Scattered wildfires broke out across Northern California on Thursday the 10th at least one of which prompted the issuance of evacuations.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Sandalwood Fire started the morning of October 10th and resulted from a trash truck dumping burning garbage onto vegetation. A mobile home park was evacuated. A total of 16 structures were damaged and 74 structures were destroyed. Two people died as a result of this fire. The fire was fully contained on 10/14 with a final acreage of 1,011 acres.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure over the Great Basin brought moderate Santa Ana winds to southern California October 10th and 11th. Peak wind gusts of 60-65 mph were observed in the Cajon Pass, San Bernardino, Fontana and Fremont Canyon. Peak wind gusts of 55 mph were recorded at Cuyamaca Lake and the I-8 pass in San Diego County. Most of San Diego County had wind gusts of 35-45 mph. Humidity values were in the single digits throughout much of the region. Four wildfires started during this event - two of which were impactful. The Sandalwood Fire destroyed 75 mobile homes in Redlands and the Reche Fire caused evacuations in Moreno Valley.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Reche Fire started on 10/10 and quickly grew to 350 acres near a residential area. This forced the evacuation of many homes in Moreno Valley. In total, the fire was 350 acres, damaged 1 structure and destroyed 1 structure. The fire was fully contained on 10/13.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure over the Great Basin brought moderate Santa Ana winds to southern California October 10th and 11th. EVENT_NARRATIVE: On October 10 a prescribed burn, which was started on September 30, was declared a wild fire incident. Extreme fire weather conditions were forecast which led to the growth of the prescribed burn. In total 3435 acres were burned across the month of October. The Forest Service noted that 7 injuries or illnesses happened on this fire.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extreme fire weather conditions were forecast for Oct 9 and 10 as northern California was caught between a ridge over the eastern Pacific and a trough over the Great Basin. This caused the pressure gradients to tighten over the county warning area, which lead to strong northerly and easterly winds. With these winds forecast, dry conditions in place, and fuels being primed a Red Flag Warning was issued for most of interior northern California. Fortunately no major wildfires resulted from this but a controlled burn got out of control and utility power lines did suffer from some wind damage.

CZ_NAME_STR: LOS ANGELES COUNTY MOUNTAINS EXCLUDING THE SANTA MONICA RANGE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Saddleridge Fire burned 8799 acres across the foothills of the San Fernando Valley as well as the Santa Clarita Valley and the Los Angeles county mountains. The combination of warm and dry Santa Ana winds and critically dry vegetation allowed for significant fire growth. The fire destroyed 19 residences and damages 88 additional residences. One civilian death was reported (due to cardiac arrest) and eight firefighters were injured.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Saddleridge Fire burned over 8700 acres in the foothills of the San Fernando Valley in Los Angeles county. The combination of warm and dry Santa Ana winds as well as critically dry vegetation allowed for rapid fire growth. Over 100 residences were either damaged or destroyed by the fire. Additionally, there was one civilian death was reported due to cardiac arrest.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Kincade Fire broke out on the night of Oct 23rd. GOES-17 satellite imagery detected the fire at approximately 9:21 PM PDT. The fire burned through early November. At the end of October the Fire burned 76,825 acres, 266 structures were destroyed, 47 were damaged, and 4 first responders were injured with one injury deemed serious https://www.fire.ca.gov/incidents/2019/10/23/kincade-fire/. The fire prompted numerous emergency evacuations throughout Sonoma County.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of offshore wind events plagued much of California towards the end of October. Cut off lows (also known as insider sliders) moved into the Great Basin as an upper ridge sat over the eastern Pacific. Strong surface high pressure also building over the Great Basin and a trough along the California coast provided the set up for strong and dry offshore winds over the greater Bay Area. Two more such events would go on to occur before the end of the month providing what would be historic critical fire weather conditions for the region. The first event brought strong N to NE winds to the region, particularly the North Bay, where gusts of 50 to 70 mph were observed. Healdsburg Hills North Station had a peak gust of 76 mph the night of the 23rd. These conditions fed the rapid growth of the Kincade Fire that broke out late in the evening on the 23rd, and at the end of the month was still burning. Additionally, near record breaking high temperatures were observed in parts of the area on the 24th and 25th. Prior to the event PG&E shut off power to  roughly 1 million people across the state of California.

CZ_NAME_STR: COASTAL NORTH BAY INCLUDING POINT REYES NATIONAL SEASHORE (ZONE)

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Miller wildfire erupted in Valley Center and burned 37 acres. The brush fire was in heavy fuel but response was rapid. 3 buildings were destroyed. Evacuations occurred on Cole Grade and Miller Lanes.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper level high pressure over the Great Basin ushered in gusty Santa Ana winds, hot temperatures and single digit relative humidity. Many SoCal locations took the nation's high temperature between October 21-24. Although it was hot and dry October 21-22, winds were not very strong. The stronger winds occurred on October 24-25, where widespread wind gusts of 50-60 mph winds occurred in the mountains and passes, with isolated gusts of 70+ mph. The highest wind gust was 78 mph at Sill Hill in San Diego County. Five small fires started between October 24-25. The Miller Fire in Valley Center burned 70 acres in heavy vegetation.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several wildfires broke out into Sunday morning around the region. One of them (Cypress Complex) was sparked early Sunday morning prompting the issuance of limited evacuations of nearby neighborhoods. Ultimately no structures were destroyed https://www.fire.ca.gov/incidents/2019/10/27/cypress-complex/.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of offshore wind events plagued much of California towards the end of October. Cut off lows (also known as insider sliders) moved into the Great Basin as an upper ridge sat over the eastern Pacific. Strong surface high pressure also building over the Great Basin and a trough along the California coast provided the set up for one of the strongest dry offshore winds over the greater Bay Area since the 2017 North Bay Fires. Winds remained elevated for at least 24 hours with gusts in the hills 60 to 80 mph. A peak gust of 102 mph was recorded near the Kincade Fire. These winds promoted rapid growth of the Kincade Fire and along with very dry conditions allowed for multiple new wildfires to spark in the greater Bay Area. A large amount of the community in Sonoma County was evacuated downwind of the Kincade Fire in response. Prior to the event PG&E shut off power to over 2 million people across the state of California.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two fires sparked around the same time Sunday morning opposite of the Carquinez Strait one in Vallejo and the other in Crockett. The fire on the Contra Costa County side was named the Sky Fire. Both fires caused evacuations in Contra Costa and Solano Counties while shutting down I-80 and the Carquinez Bridge. The Sky Fire in the end burned around 150 acres and did not damage any structures https://www.fire.ca.gov/incidents/2019/10/27/sky-fire/ |https://www.sfchronicle.com/california-wildfires/article/Vallejo-Fire-Interstate-80-Carquinez-Bridge-14566204.php.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Getty Fire started in late October in the Santa Monica Mountains, near the Getty Museum, and burned into early November. The combination of warm and dry Santa Ana winds and critically dry vegetation allowed the fire to grow quickly, eventually burning 745 acres. The fire destroyed 10 residences and damaged 15 other residences.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Getty Fire burned over 700 acres across the Santa Monica Mountains, near the Getty Museum. The combination of warm and dry Santa Ana winds and critically dry vegetation allowed for rapid fire growth. The fire damaged or destroyed 25 residences.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A hotspot was detected in Sonoma County southwest of Cloverdale off of the Kincade Fire. Do not have information as to when that spot was put out.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The third and final in a series of offshore wind events arrived at the end of October resulting in another round of Red Flag Warnings and Wind Advisories. This final event was not as strong as the previous and was more in line with the first offshore event that sparked the Kincade Fire. Under a very dry air mass widespread single digit humidity values were observed in the hills, along valley floors, and in some coastal areas. The Oakland Airport sounding also recorded record low moisture content for several launches in a row. For full detailed summary of these three events see the following site: https://www.weather.gov/mtr/FireWeatherOctober2019.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Easy Fire burned 1806 acres across the coastal valleys of Ventura county, near the community of Simi Valley. The combination of warm and dry Santa Ana winds and critically dry vegetation allowed the fire to spread quickly. Three firefighters were injured.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Easy Fire started in late October across the coastal valleys of Ventura county, near the community of Simi Valley. The fire continued to burn into early November, before being contained. The fire burned over 1800 acres.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Water Fire broke out in the Nuevo area around 0700 PST on October 30th. The fire was 5 acres and destroyed 3 structures and 2 vehicles. No injuries occurred. The fire was fully contained by 1130 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure over the Great Basin brought high winds and single digit relative humidity to southern California. Gusty Santa Ana winds were reported in the mountains and passes, with peak gusts topping out 60-70 mph. The windiest location was Fremont Canyon at 73 mph. A few small wildfires broke out across the region. The Water Fire was the smallest, but most destructive fire during this time period, destroying 3 structures and 2 vehicles. The 46 Fire charred 300 acres and prompted the evacuations of approximately 3600 residents, with no structures destroyed or injuries reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hillside fire erupted at 140 am along Highway 18. This wildfire destroyed 3 homes and damage 6 others. Up to 1300 persons were evacuated. Neighbors went door to door at 2 am to wake up people. The fire consumed about 250 acres near Muscoy in San Bernardino. The fire burned downhill due to 40-50 mph wind gusts (Santa Ana) in lower Waterman Canyon. This wildfire rescue made the A&E Network Rescue series as #1 in 2019. 1 fire fighter was hospitalized for smoke inhalation.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Kincade Fire broke out on the night of Oct 23rd. The fire was put out on the evening of November 6th. In all, the fire burned 77,758 acres, 374 structures were destroyed, 60 were damaged, and 4 first responders were injured with one injury deemed serious https://www.fire.ca.gov/incidents/2019/10/23/kincade-fire/. The fire prompted numerous emergency evacuations throughout Sonoma County.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Kincade Fire was sparked in the evening of October 23rd during the first of a series of offshore wind events. The second event in late October promoted the rapid spread of the Kincade Fire across portions of Sonoma County. Much of the county was evacuated during this time and wind gusts were recorded as high as 102 mph in the vicinity of the fire. The fire continued to burn into early November.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Maria Fire started in late October across the valleys of Ventura county, near the community of Santa Paula and burned into early November. Due to warm and dry Santa Ana winds as well as critically dry vegetation, the fire continued to burn into early November, eventually burning 9999 acres. Fortunately, no significant damages or injuries were reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Maria Fire started in late October across the valleys of Ventura county, near the community of Santa Paula. Due to warm and dry Santa Ana winds and critically dry vegetation, the fire burned into early November, eventually burning 9999 acres.

CZ_NAME_STR: SANTA LUCIA MOUNTAINS AND LOS PADRES NATIONAL FOREST (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Plaskett Fire began in early June and burned for two weeks https://www.fireweatheravalanche.org/wildfire/incident/116481/california/plaskett-fire.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In early June, warm and dry conditions acted to dry out fuels across the region. Several small vegetation fires were started and spread quickly due to breezy winds in the area prompting evacuations in some instances. Ultimately no structures were damaged and no injuries reported.

CZ_NAME_STR: SANTA CLARA VALLEY INCLUDING SAN JOSE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Colleen Fire was started on June 4th near San Jose along with several additional small vegetation fires. Residents in the area were ordered to evacuate but were later allowed to return to their homes https://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2020/06/04/multiple-vegetation-fires-reported-in-south-san-jose/.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In early June, warm and dry conditions acted to dry out fuels across the region. Several small vegetation fires were started and spread quickly due to breezy winds in the area prompting evacuations in some instances. Ultimately no structures were damaged and no injuries reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind-driven grass fire reported in the San Francisco neighborhood of Potrero Hill. Evacuations were issued, the fire was contained with no structures damaged https://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2020/06/05/grass-fire-in-san-franciscos-potrero-hill-forces-evacuations/.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper low along with a second shortwave trough moved through the region the first weekend of June. A strong onshore pressure gradient brought gusty winds to much of the area. Observations showed gusts of 40 to 60 mph throughout the Bay Area and Central Coast. These winds fueled multiple grass and vegetation fires throughout the area, some of which prompted evacuations.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Lakeville Fire broke out Friday afternoon near Petaluma in Sonoma County. Exact end time uncertain https://www.mercurynews.com/2020/06/06/map-seven-fires-amid-high-winds-in-the-bay-area/.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper low along with a second shortwave trough moved through the region the first weekend of June. A strong onshore pressure gradient brought gusty winds to much of the area. Observations showed gusts of 40 to 60 mph throughout the Bay Area and Central Coast. These winds fueled multiple grass and vegetation fires throughout the area, some of which prompted evacuations.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire broke out during the afternoon hours which threatened 100 structures, destroyed 3 structures, and caused evacuations and road closures. By June 10, the fire was considered contained by mid morning. Cause of the fire is under investigation.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A broad trough brought gusty winds to the Delta region, which combined with fine fuels, led to elevated fire weather conditions.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Gulch Fire broke out on Saturday afternoon about a mile from where the Lakeville Fire began near Petaluma https://www.mercurynews.com/2020/06/06/map-seven-fires-amid-high-winds-in-the-bay-area/. Timing approximated.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper low along with a second shortwave trough moved through the region the first weekend of June. A strong onshore pressure gradient brought gusty winds to much of the area. Observations showed gusts of 40 to 60 mph throughout the Bay Area and Central Coast. These winds fueled multiple grass and vegetation fires throughout the area, some of which prompted evacuations.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Willow Fire broke out in Contra Costa County late Saturday afternoon. Like the other wildfires that day, this one was aided in spread by gusty winds https://www.mercurynews.com/2020/06/06/map-seven-fires-amid-high-winds-in-the-bay-area/. Exact end time uncertain.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper low along with a second shortwave trough moved through the region the first weekend of June. A strong onshore pressure gradient brought gusty winds to much of the area. Observations showed gusts of 40 to 60 mph throughout the Bay Area and Central Coast. These winds fueled multiple grass and vegetation fires throughout the area, some of which prompted evacuations.

CZ_NAME_STR: SOUTHERN SALINAS VALLEY / ARROYO SECO / LAKE SAN ANTONIO (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Bradley Fire broke out just north of Bradley in Monterey County on Monday afternoon https://www.fire.ca.gov/incidents/2020/6/8/bradley-fire/. Although winds had begun to die down at this point, breezy conditions still fueled the spread of the fire.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper low along with a second shortwave trough moved through the region the first weekend of June. A strong onshore pressure gradient brought gusty winds to much of the area. Observations showed gusts of 40 to 60 mph throughout the Bay Area and Central Coast. These winds fueled multiple grass and vegetation fires throughout the area, some of which prompted evacuations.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Lime Fire scorched 803 acres near the Lake Piru area in Ventura county.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Lime Fire ignited in Ventura county, near the Lake Piru area. The fire burned a total of 803 acres.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN LUIS OBISPO COUNTY CENTRAL COAST (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Avila Fire scorched 445 acres near the community of Avila Beach in San Luis Obispo county.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Avila Fire burned 445 acres near the community of Avila Beach in San Luis Obispo county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Walker Fire broke out in Calaveras County on June 16 and burned for 4 days. Two structures were destroyed and the fire burned 1455 acres.  The cause of the fire remains under investigation.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A broad trough and associated cold front brought dry and gusty winds to the region. North to northwesterly wind gusts of 30 to 35 mph were forecast for much of the valley and lower foothills these days, which combined with primed fine fuels and warmer weather led to fire weather concerns.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Calfire Butte County Unit reported on Twitter grass fire began around noon on June 17. Later that afternoon, Calfire reported forward progress stopped, and that the fire was at 75% containment and burned 95 acres. This fire destroyed 4 houses and caused road closures and evacuations while the fire was on going. Cause of fire is under investigation.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A broad trough and associated cold front brought dry and gusty winds to the region. North to northwesterly wind gusts of 30 to 35 mph were forecast for much of the valley and lower foothills these days, which combined with primed fine fuels and warmer weather led to fire weather concerns.

CZ_NAME_STR: SANTA LUCIA MOUNTAINS AND LOS PADRES NATIONAL FOREST (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Ridge Fire broke out in Monterey County burning dry grass, shrub, and oak https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/6784/.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Persistently warm and dry conditions combined with breezy onshore afternoon and evening winds increased fire weather concerns across the region. Multiple wildfires broke out in late June across Monterey County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Stage Fire broke out northeast of Salinas in late June and burned 52 acres https://www.fire.ca.gov/incidents/2020/6/21/stage-fire/.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Persistently warm and dry conditions combined with breezy onshore afternoon and evening winds increased fire weather concerns across the region. Multiple wildfires broke out in late June across Monterey County.

CZ_NAME_STR: SANTA LUCIA MOUNTAINS AND LOS PADRES NATIONAL FOREST (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Hunter Fire broke out near Lockwood in Monterey County. Multiple evacuations were issued https://kion546.com/news/2020/06/21/fire-burning-south-of-lockwood/.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Persistently warm and dry conditions combined with breezy onshore afternoon and evening winds increased fire weather concerns across the region. Multiple wildfires broke out in late June across Monterey County.

CZ_NAME_STR: SOUTHERN SALINAS VALLEY / ARROYO SECO / LAKE SAN ANTONIO (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Rico Fire broke out in Monterey County near San Ardo at 2:15 pm local time https://www.fire.ca.gov/incidents/2020/6/22/rico-fire/.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Persistently warm and dry conditions combined with breezy onshore afternoon and evening winds increased fire weather concerns across the region. Multiple wildfires broke out in late June across Monterey County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A brush fire developed just west of Niland around sunset, near the intersection of Nieto and Noffsinger roads. The fire quickly became out of control, spreading rapidly east due to strong gusty winds. Winds at the start of the fire were observed gusting up to 25-30 mph out of the west to southwest. This made the fire difficult for fire fighters to attack the fire and the fire ended up spreading through the center of Niland. The forward progress of the fire was not stopped until 2 AM PDT that night and not fully contained until almost 8 AM PDT the morning of the 29th. Due to the fire, power was lost to the area, around 130 people were evacuated, around 40 homes were destroyed, and there was one fatality.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Near sunset on the 28th, a brush fire started in Imperial county California and quickly became out of control due to strong winds. The fire spread into the small town of Niland destroying numerous houses and structures.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: San Bernardino National Forest reports 62.5 acre Mount R Fire, which closed a portion of California State Route 330 between Live Oak Drive to Highland Boulevard.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Mount R Fire burned in the early part of the month with minor impacts.

CZ_NAME_STR: EAST BAY HILLS AND THE DIABLO RANGE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Sheridan Fire broke out in dry brush in the hills of Alameda County. Breezy winds initially fueled the spread of the fire before it was contained https://www.fire.ca.gov/incidents/2020/7/4/sheridan-fire/.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure over the desert southwest brought warm and dry conditions across the Central Coast and Bay Area around the Fourth of July. A handful of wildfires that broke out that weekend were aided by breezy onshore winds towards the end of the weekend and into the start of the following week. Some of the fires prompted the issuance of evacuations across the region.

CZ_NAME_STR: EAST BAY HILLS AND THE DIABLO RANGE (ZONE)

Some of the fires prompted the issuance of evacuations across the region.

A handful of wildfires that broke out that weekend were aided by breezy onshore winds towards the end of the weekend and into the start of the following week. Some of the fires prompted the issuance of evacuations across the region.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The California Fire started in Contra Costa County near I-80. Part of Cummings Skyway near where the fire was burning was closed https://www.fire.ca.gov/incidents/2020/7/6/california-fire/. End time is approximate.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure over the desert southwest brought warm and dry conditions across the Central Coast and Bay Area around the Fourth of July. A handful of wildfires that broke out that weekend were aided by breezy onshore winds towards the end of the weekend and into the start of the following week. Some of the fires prompted the issuance of evacuations across the region.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: One of the Navy's vessels in the San Diego Bay, the U.S.S. Bonhomme Richard, caught fire the morning of July 12th and lasted for four days. Copious amounts of smoke entered the atmosphere creating poor air quality in the greater San Diego metro, along with a total of 68 military and civilian firefighters injured during the blaze.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Arson was attributed to the burning of the Navy's Bonhomme Richard ship, which lasted 4 days with over 60 injuries of navy and fire rescue personnel in the San Diego Bay.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Mineral fire was first spotted around 5 PM on the 13th of July, with nearly 1000 acres burned by days end. The next several days resulted in significant fire growth and numerous evacuation notices within the region. Highway 198 between Coalinga and Monterey County was closed which impact commerce, though the greatest impact was the loss of seven structure. Full containment of the fire was seen on 26th, though growth ended days prior.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: See event.

CZ_NAME_STR: MOUNTAINS OF SAN BENITO COUNTY AND INTERIOR MONTEREY COUNTY INCLUDING PINNACLES NATIONAL PARK (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Coyote Fire broke out in San Benito county west of Panoche prompting evacuations and destroying a few buildings https://kion546.com/news/2020/07/15/cal-fire-responds-to-coyote-fire-in-san-benito-county/.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire sparked in Fresno county and was burning towards the Monterey County line in mid July. The fire necessitated evacuations for parts of Monterey County. The evacuation notices were lifted several days later. The Coyote Fire broke out a couple of days later in nearby San Benito County destroying a few structures and also prompting evacuations. Smoke from both fires made its way into the Bay Area.

CZ_NAME_STR: SANTA LUCIA MOUNTAINS AND LOS PADRES NATIONAL FOREST (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Mineral Fire sparked in Fresno County on July 13th and slowly spread westward towards Monterey County. Areas were evacuated for several days https://www.ksbw.com/article/mineral-fire-prompts-evacuations-in-southeast-monterey-county/33341821.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire sparked in Fresno county and was burning towards the Monterey County line in mid July. The fire necessitated evacuations for parts of Monterey County. The evacuation notices were lifted several days later. The Coyote Fire broke out a couple of days later in nearby San Benito County destroying a few structures and also prompting evacuations. Smoke from both fires made its way into the Bay Area.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Holland Fire broke out northeast of Brentwood on the 20th prompting evacuations around the area https://www.fire.ca.gov/incidents/2020/7/20/holland-fire/. No structures were ultimately destroyed https://www.eastbaytimes.com/2020/07/20/firefighters-battle-east-contra-costa-grass-fire/.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Holland Fire broke out northeast of Brentwood in late July. The vegetation fire was fueled by breezy winds that afternoon and prompted evacuations near the Brentwood Marina.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: San Bernardino County Fire Department responded to the Easton Fire near the city of Highland on July 20th. The fire was put out the next afternoon with a total of 71 acres.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure over the Desert Southwest led to hot temperatures in the deserts of Southern California. Temperatures ranged from just above the century mark to 117 degrees in areas of the Coachella Valley. A small wildfire broke out in the San Bernardino Mountains on July 20th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Badger Wildfire started on 07/18/20. The cause was under investigation.  As of the last report at 0630 PDT on 07/29/20, the fire burned 557 acres and was 100% contained.  4.0 million dollars were expended on fire fighting efforts.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Badger Wildfire started on 07/18/20. The cause was under investigation.  As of the last report at 0630 PDT on 07/29/20, the fire burned 557 acres and was 100% contained.  4.0 million dollars were expended on fire fighting efforts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The July Complex consists of the Caldwell, Allen and Dalton fires.  They were started by lightning on 07/22/20 at around 1015 PDT.  As of 08/01/20 at 06:30 PDT, the fires had burned 83261 acres and were 77 percent contained.  21.0 million dollars had been expended on firefighting efforts.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The July Complex consists of the Caldwell, Allen and Dalton fires.  They were started by lightning on 07/22/20 at around 1015 PDT.  As of 08/01/20 at 06:30 PDT, the fires had burned 83261 acres and were 77 percent contained.  21.0 million dollars had been expended on firefighting efforts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Blue Jay fire began on the afternoon of July 24th due to a lightning strike near the White Wolf Campground. The fire burned in generally wilderness, though did close several trails within the park.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: See event.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: USFS San Bernardino and CalFire worked on the Apple fire which began July 31st. The fire burned 33,424 acres into mid August 2020. 3 injuries on wildfire. 4 homes destroyed.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Apple wildfire erupted near Cherry Valley. The cause was determined to be a faulty vehicle. The wildfire consumed 33,424 acres as it burned into mid August.
